webTitle: Brown gains one and loses four for Croatia game

fields.headline: Brown gains one and loses four for Croatia game
fields.trailText: Not for the first time, withdrawals have taken their toll on Craig Brown's squad and yesterday saw four players make the trip back to Glasgow.
fields.body:
Scotland have suffered a familiar toll of withdrawals in the build-up to tomorrow's Group Six World Cup qualifier against Croatia in Zagreb.

Craig Brown's squad had arrived in the capital without Barry Ferguson and Paul Lambert, who would normally patrol the midfield as key members of an otherwise limited squad. And yesterday four others were put on a flight back to Glasgow.

Christian Dailly, who was in an ugly aerial collision during Saturday's 2-0 win against San Marino, was finally diagnosed as having broken his nose in three places. Jackie McNamara joined him with sciatica, Neil McCann has an injured ankle and Billy Dodds's wife Caron is on the verge of giving birth, hence her husband's departure.

It all left Brown wearing his familiar wry smile at the trials of being a national manager. "I've got three kids and I wasn't at the birth of any of them; it wasn't the done thing in my day," he said.

"But I totally respect the wishes of Billy Dodds, who had warned me this might happen. As for the other injuries, there's nothing I can do."

On the plus side, however, Craig Burley arrived yesterday having recovered from a hamstring injury, thus offering the Scots another option in midfield, and the striker Mark Burchill has been promoted from the Under-21 side. Brown may also be tempted to offer a first start in a Scotland shirt to Manchester City's Paul Dickov.

Reports that Croatia's Davor Suker would miss out proved incorrect. The home coach Miroslav Blazevic had just told the press that the striker was injured when his briefing was interrupted by a call from the team doctor informing him that the West Ham player could manage 45 minutes.

Wales's John Robinson has declared himself fit for Group Five duty in Poland after carrying a knee injury during Saturday's 1-1 draw with Norway. "It took some time to shrug it off," the winger said. "It did hurt, but I'm fit for another crack."

Northern Ireland's Damien Johnson has recovered from the groin strain that forced him to miss the 1-1 draw with Denmark and is fit for the match in Iceland, who have yet to take a point in Group Three.

"We have a platform after taking four points against Malta and Denmark so let's see if we can build on that," said Sammy McIlroy, the Northern Ireland coach. "Come March we would have seven points with the Czech Republic coming to Windsor Park, and that gets me tingling right away."

The Republic's Matt Holland is likely to start on the bench again for tomorrow's visit of Estonia, who top Group Two with six points, despite scoring the goal that earned them a draw in Portugal. However, Blackburn's Damien Duff is pushing Kevin Kilbane and Jason McAteer for a place.

fields.headline: Brazil romp inspired by Romario
fields.trailText: Romario followed up his hat-trick against Bolivia last month by scoring four as Brazil hammered Venezuela 6-0 in their latest World Cup qualifying game.
fields.body:
Brazil, and the veteran striker Romario in particular, showed on Sunday that they are back in World Cup business after last week's sacking of the coach Wanderley Luxemburgo by hitting Venezuela for six.

Romario, who obliged with a hat-trick against Bolivia last month in his first international for more than two years, scored another four in the oil city of Maracaibo, including three in an eight-minute spell in the first half.

"Everybody knows that scoring goals is what I do, there's nothing new about that. Just keep calling me up and the team will keep winning," said the 34-year-old Vasco da Gama striker, who led Brazil to World Cup victory in 1994.

However Argentina beat Uruguay 2-1 to remain five points clear of Brazil and Paraguay in the South American group from which the top four will qualify for the finals in Japan and Korea, with the fifth-place nation playing off with the winners of the Oceania group.

webTitle: German football: Daum moves to 'protect' his name

fields.headline: Angry Daum moves to 'protect' his name
fields.trailText: Christoph Daum, Germany's troubled coach-in-waiting, will supply urine, blood and hair samples for tests to prove he does not take cocaine. Daum, who is set to take over the national team from Rudi Völler next summer, has been engulfed by recent sex and drugs allegations and said he wanted to "protect" his name.
fields.body:
Christoph Daum, Germany's troubled coach-in-waiting, will supply urine, blood and hair samples for tests to prove he does not take cocaine. Daum, who is set to take over the national team from Rudi Völler next summer, has been engulfed by recent sex and drugs allegations and said he wanted to "protect" his name.

The samples will be sent to an independent laboratory in Cologne and the results will be available in about four weeks.

The Bayer Leverkusen coach told a press conference yesterday: "I was forced to do this because of my responsibility towards my family and my club. I also had to protect my good name.

"However, I won't give the result of the test to the media but to my family, the DfB [German football federation] president-in-waiting Gerhard Mayer-Vorfelder, Franz Beckenbauer and Leverkusen's general manager Reiner Calmund.

"Obviously these people have the right to announce the outcome to the German public."

Daum had previously refused to take a drugs test and had cited the principle that he was innocent until proven guilty.

Bayern Munich's commercial manager Uli Hoeness had sparked a highly public clash with Daum when he said the Leverkusen coach was unfit to take over the national team because of lurid allegations of improper behaviour in his private life. Daum has said he will sue Hoeness for libel.

Daum also faces inquiries into his financial affairs after prosecutors in Munich and Cologne launched preliminary investigations into allegations of fraud and embezzlement.

Meanwhile, Red Star Belgrade have been fined £15,000 because of their supporters' unruly behaviour during the Uefa Cup defeat of Leicester City in Vienna last month when Ade Akinbiyi and Andy Impey were subjected to racist chanting.

Flares were also launched by Red Star supporters into the section reserved for Leicester fans and one landed near the Leicester goalkeeper Tim Flowers.

The Besiktas striker Pascal Nouma has been given a three-match ban for hitting the Leeds defender Danny Mills in the face with his arm during last month's Champions League match at Elland Road. The referee did not see the incident and it went unpunished at the time but it was reported by the game's Uefa delegate. The Frenchman will miss the return match in Istanbul next Wednesday.

Rangers have been fined nearly £2,000 by Uefa for having four men - Allan Johnston, Ronald de Boer, Stefan Klos and Kerimoglu Tugay - booked during the Champions League victory in Monaco last month. Monaco had three players cautioned but escaped a fine.

webTitle: 'Clicks and mortar' offers the best bargains

fields.headline: 'Clicks and mortar' offers the best bargains
fields.standfirst: The virtual incarnations of high street retailers offer big price reductions on the net
fields.trailText: The virtual incarnations of high street retailers offer big price reductions on the net
fields.body:
Internet shoppers can save around 13% by ordering their goods from the online operations of existing high street retailers.

The finding, released today at the launch of credit card provider Goldfish's e-tail price index (ePI), suggests that as the retail e-economy moves towards the £23bn a year mark in 2005, online price competition is heating up. 'Clicks and mortar' companies are undercutting 'pure' internet operations by 12.7% in a bid to gain market share.

Goldfish also found that the prices for similar online products vary significantly. Consumers can pay up to 42.5% more for fresh vegetables at the most expensive e-tailer than the average price. The disparities also include 37.5% for selected alcoholic drinks, 30.5% for tinned gods and 25% for health products such as vitamins and condoms.

The survey further suggested that online prices fluctuate more than on the high street. The Office for National Statistics' Retail Price Index (RPI) - the old-economy inflation tracker - shows prices rising 0.7% between July and September, whereas Goldfish's ePI found them falling 2.4% during the same three month period.

Goldfish says that while prices will probably continue to fluctuate widely, most e-tailers will still be cutting prices in an effort to win loyal customers. This is to the advantage of 'clicks and mortar' retailers, especially household names, since they are better placed to swallow price cuts as they don't rely exclusively on internet sales. The next few months may see more 'pure' internet operations fold under huge advertising costs and falling revenue.

This is compounded by the fact that prices for goods and services such as holidays, books and CDs, which make up 71% of online retail sales, have fallen furthest. Holiday sales are down 9.7%, CDs are down 4.5% and books are down 2%.

The Goldfish ePI is understood to be the only index of UK online consumer prices. It is produced on a monthly basis and tracks a basket of 1,300 products, the prices of which are checked at over 150 e-tailers, starting in July 2000. The Index will be calculated each month.

The company says the index should not be compared like-for-like with the retail price index because many of the goods and services included in this overall study are not sold online. However, as and when new products are sold online they will be added to the index.

webTitle: Link tipped to run universal bank

fields.headline: Link tipped to run universal bank
fields.standfirst:
Banks see scheme as a costly lifeline for the Post Office
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Link cash machine network last night emerged as the leading contender to run the controversial Post Office- based universal bank.
fields.body:
The Link cash machine network last night emerged as the leading contender to run the controversial Post Office- based universal bank.

Industry sources say Link, which connects all the hole-in-the-wall machines around the country, could provide the technology to hook up the big banks with the 18,000-strong post office network.

This would solve one of the barriers to creating the universal bank, which is being designed to provide bank accounts to some 3m recipients of social security payments who do not have accounts.

Some of the big banks are concerned they could end up paying as much as £400m a year to provide accounts to the "financially excluded". Privately, they describe the move as more of an attempt to throw a lifeline to the Post Office.

The banks, which expect to hear as soon as today precisely how much the government believes the project will cost, are already connected to each other by Link and could use the same technology to set up connections with the Post Office.

"Link could facilitate the operation of the universal bank and also the so-called basic bank accounts," one source said.

The basic accounts, which do not allow overdrafts, are being set up by the banks under instruction from the Treasury.

Link refused to comment yesterday although the government is understood to be keen that only one organisation runs the operation.

The Treasury, Department of Trade and Industry and the Post Office yesterday refused to disclose their estimates of the cost of running the universal bank.

In the face of concerns that the eventual cost could run to between £150m to £400m annually, the Post Office said: "We don't recognise these figures or anything close to them". However, one of the high street banks, HBSC, was prepared to admit last night that it expects its annual cost to be £20m alone.

Through letters to the chief executives of the high street banks this week, the DTI is expected to try to allay concerns about the cost of running the universal bank.

The New Economics Foundation lobby group last night called for banks to contribute just 0.2% of their profits to support a network of "community" banks.

The research, by Derek French of the Campaign for Community Banking Services, argues that the clearing banks could share the branches which could be in pubs or churches.

fields.headline: Zan Lyons
fields.standfirst: Spitz, London ***
fields.trailText: Zan Lyons looks like he's doing the graveyard shift. Bathed in blue light, his ultra-slim frame rocks gently beside a tiny stack of equipment, fingers never leaving the faders and knobs. All around, like a musical scrapyard, lie the remains of the evening's earlier music-making: guitars, keyboards, drums. The Grim Reaper of digital music has arrived. Lyons cheerily resists describing his music as dark - he prefers to hear it as sound from the subconscious. Perhaps we should say unconscious, looking at the track titles: Suicide, Desolate, Serial Killer Stories. This is not slapstick.
fields.body:
Zan Lyons looks like he's doing the graveyard shift. Bathed in blue light, his ultra-slim frame rocks gently beside a tiny stack of equipment, fingers never leaving the faders and knobs. All around, like a musical scrapyard, lie the remains of the evening's earlier music-making: guitars, keyboards, drums. The Grim Reaper of digital music has arrived. Lyons cheerily resists describing his music as dark - he prefers to hear it as sound from the subconscious. Perhaps we should say unconscious, looking at the track titles: Suicide, Desolate, Serial Killer Stories. This is not slapstick.

His music is like Beauty and the Beast. It starts clean and quiet, always distant: forlorn voices; pure chimes; synthesised strings; gentle electric humming. And while you admire this delicate crystal sound someone arrives with a bloody great electric sledgehammer and knocks it into sand. Just then, a small but devoted group of up-for-it types appear at the front from nowhere and do their best to divorce a few limbs. A couple do some wrestling in the corner, while the oblong-specs team search for a bassline.

When digital musical equipment first came into existence, its selling points were clarity, accuracy and lack of distortion. But when pushed to the limits, it makes it own special noise - a snowstorm of information. Drum'n'bass often visits these outer reaches in small bursts, but it usually has many other layers in action at the same time, like the parts of a clockwork movement.

Lyons deliberately works at the extremes without filling in the middle. Huge beats are distorted, sometimes to the point where there is no discernable original sound. It is as if he is taking a block of white noise and sculpting it to create rhythm, which sometimes pushes it towards a thrash metal sound. Any concept of a bassline just melts under the heat. When he drives the equipment even further, so the beat dissolves into a monolithic screech, half the crowd plug their ears while the other cheer him on as if they're watching someone hold his hand over a flame. They want to see how long he will last. Then it stops, and the slower, pure sounds will briefly sing through, often to beautiful, chilling effect.

Those dramatic edges are the music's trademark, but it would be hard to survive on them for long. It's not that Lyons should start doing weddings and kids' parties, but throwing some light on the middle ground without losing the dark feel would give his music the third dimension that it sometimes needs.

fields.headline: Merger mania
fields.standfirst:
Britain leads the global takeover boom; but apart from a few boastful chief executives, do companies, shareholders or anyone else benefit?
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The UK is at the forefront of a global boom in mergers and acquisitions (the takeover of one company by another), investing abroad last year more than any other country. Mega deals, such as Vodafone's takeover of AirTouch and BP's of Amoco, resulted in foreign investment from the UK worth almost $200bn in 1999, leapfrogging America as the biggest outward investor for the first time since 1988.
fields.body:
The UK is at the forefront of a global boom in mergers and acquisitions (the takeover of one company by another), investing abroad last year more than any other country. Mega deals, such as Vodafone's takeover of AirTouch and BP's of Amoco, resulted in foreign investment from the UK worth almost $200bn in 1999, leapfrogging America as the biggest outward investor for the first time since 1988. The chart shows UK in and outflows compared with France, traditionally also a big investor.

For the chief executives of acquiring companies and their advisers, such deals bring golf-club bragging rights and enormous financial rewards, yet results for their shareholders are often disappointing. Studies keep showing that most mergers fail. The shares of the company being acquired often rise in value but those of the predator fall. A KPMG study last year showed that 53% of mergers destroyed shareholder value. Mark Sirower, a professor at New York University and adviser to Boston Consulting Group, puts the failure rate at about 65%.

Given the portents, it would not be unreasonable to expect bosses everywhere to give up on acquiring new firms and concentrate on organic growth. Instead, the pace of mergers is accelerating, not just within countries but between them too. Figures collected by the UN conference on trade and development (Unctad) show cross-border mergers and acquisitions (M&As) drove foreign investment volumes to a new record of $856bn last year. It reckons the total may well pass $1,000bn this year.

Most deals are conducted between firms in the developed world. Companies based in the EU were the most acquisitive, with the UK accounting for 39% of total EU outflows. The boom in Europe is being driven in part by the arrival of the euro, which contributes to greater price transparency and increased competition, putting more pressure on firms to restructure and consolidate their operations.

It is also a facet of globalisation and the desire of companies to become top dog, not just in their native country or region but the world. In the same way that a global marketplace for goods and services is emerging, so too is one for firms. The process is aided by information technology which makes distant business units easier to manage; changes in financial markets, which allow deals to be financed through share swaps rather than cash; and deregulation.

The market expects corporate leaders to deliver double digit growth every year. The only way to do that, especially in mature industries, is to buy other companies, thereby gaining instant access to new production and strategic assets. Yet, by buying other companies, bosses put their own company at risk of failure. However, trying to grow the business organically is not an option either because of the danger of being left behind by competitors if one of their takeover deals defies the odds and succeeds.

Part of the motive for doing such deals is that it allows chief executives to boast. Yet mistakes made in the thrill of the chase can be very costly to the individuals concerned. The collapse of the planned merger between the two Ger man banks Deutsche and Dresdner earlier this year tarnished the reputations of both. Deutsche Bank's management was exposed as divided and confused. Dresdner lost Bernhard Walter, its chairman, who resigned. Senior members of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, its investment banking unit, walked out.

If collateral damage were limited to a few high-profile resignations, the M&A boom would not be a cause for concern. But the ramifications are often felt across a much broader horizon than the individual and the company.

In the developing world, foreign direct investment is dominated by so-called greenfield investment, that is the establishment of new foreign affiliates. But cross- border M&A activity is on the rise there too, accounting for a third of foreign investment in 1999. Greenfield investment is regarded as a good thing for generating new jobs and providing a more stable source of foreign capital than hot money flows into shares or other financial investments. But the impact of M&A on development is double edged and uneven, says Unctad. Rather than adding to productive assets in a country, M&As simply transfer ownership of existing ones. In the case of a firm which would otherwise go bankrupt, the arrival of a new foreign owner is obviously beneficial. But often transfer of ownership can lead to job losses, not gains, as the acquiring company reorganises production in line with its corporate strategy rather than to the benefit of the host country.

Foreign investment carried by M&As can also threaten competition. Acquiring companies may get a stranglehold on an industry, restricting choice and keeping prices high. Developing countries rarely have effective competition policies to counter such threats.

Unctad draws parallels between the emergence of a national market in the US at the end of the 19th century and a global one today. Then, a massive M&A boom and resulting concerns about competition prompted the federal government to develop anti-trust legislation (today the US has one of the most effective competition regimes in the developed world). Now that the world economy is experiencing a similar transformation, a global response is required to safeguard consumer interests.

Mark Atkinson is the Guardian's economics correspondent

mark.atkinson@theguardian.com
fields.bodyText: The UK is at the forefront of a global boom in mergers and acquisitions (the takeover of one company by another), investing abroad last year more than any other country. Mega deals, such as Vodafone's takeover of AirTouch and BP's of Amoco, resulted in foreign investment from the UK worth almost $200bn in 1999, leapfrogging America as the biggest outward investor for the first time since 1988. The chart shows UK in and outflows compared with France, traditionally also a big investor. For the chief executives of acquiring companies and their advisers, such deals bring golf-club bragging rights and enormous financial rewards, yet results for their shareholders are often disappointing. Studies keep showing that most mergers fail. The shares of the company being acquired often rise in value but those of the predator fall. A KPMG study last year showed that 53% of mergers destroyed shareholder value. Mark Sirower, a professor at New York University and adviser to Boston Consulting Group, puts the failure rate at about 65%. Given the portents, it would not be unreasonable to expect bosses everywhere to give up on acquiring new firms and concentrate on organic growth. Instead, the pace of mergers is accelerating, not just within countries but between them too. Figures collected by the UN conference on trade and development (Unctad) show cross-border mergers and acquisitions (M&As) drove foreign investment volumes to a new record of $856bn last year. It reckons the total may well pass $1,000bn this year. Most deals are conducted between firms in the developed world. Companies based in the EU were the most acquisitive, with the UK accounting for 39% of total EU outflows. The boom in Europe is being driven in part by the arrival of the euro, which contributes to greater price transparency and increased competition, putting more pressure on firms to restructure and consolidate their operations. It is also a facet of globalisation and the desire of companies to become top dog, not just in their native country or region but the world. In the same way that a global marketplace for goods and services is emerging, so too is one for firms. The process is aided by information technology which makes distant business units easier to manage; changes in financial markets, which allow deals to be financed through share swaps rather than cash; and deregulation. The market expects corporate leaders to deliver double digit growth every year. The only way to do that, especially in mature industries, is to buy other companies, thereby gaining instant access to new production and strategic assets. Yet, by buying other companies, bosses put their own company at risk of failure. However, trying to grow the business organically is not an option either because of the danger of being left behind by competitors if one of their takeover deals defies the odds and succeeds. Part of the motive for doing such deals is that it allows chief executives to boast. Yet mistakes made in the thrill of the chase can be very costly to the individuals concerned. The collapse of the planned merger between the two Ger man banks Deutsche and Dresdner earlier this year tarnished the reputations of both. Deutsche Bank's management was exposed as divided and confused. Dresdner lost Bernhard Walter, its chairman, who resigned. Senior members of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, its investment banking unit, walked out. If collateral damage were limited to a few high-profile resignations, the M&A boom would not be a cause for concern. But the ramifications are often felt across a much broader horizon than the individual and the company. In the developing world, foreign direct investment is dominated by so-called greenfield investment, that is the establishment of new foreign affiliates. But cross- border M&A activity is on the rise there too, accounting for a third of foreign investment in 1999. Greenfield investment is regarded as a good thing for generating new jobs and providing a more stable source of foreign capital than hot money flows into shares or other financial investments. But the impact of M&A on development is double edged and uneven, says Unctad. Rather than adding to productive assets in a country, M&As simply transfer ownership of existing ones. In the case of a firm which would otherwise go bankrupt, the arrival of a new foreign owner is obviously beneficial. But often transfer of ownership can lead to job losses, not gains, as the acquiring company reorganises production in line with its corporate strategy rather than to the benefit of the host country. Foreign investment carried by M&As can also threaten competition. Acquiring companies may get a stranglehold on an industry, restricting choice and keeping prices high. Developing countries rarely have effective competition policies to counter such threats. Unctad draws parallels between the emergence of a national market in the US at the end of the 19th century and a global one today. Then, a massive M&A boom and resulting concerns about competition prompted the federal government to develop anti-trust legislation (today the US has one of the most effective competition regimes in the developed world). Now that the world economy is experiencing a similar transformation, a global response is required to safeguard consumer interests. fields.headline: Shirazeh Houshiary
fields.standfirst: Lisson Gallery, London **
fields.trailText: In this exhibition, which claims to have been inspired by Zurbaran's The Veil of St Veronica, Shirazeh Houshiary presents us with paintings that at first seem simple monochromes, their white surfaces as smoothly consistent as the white walls they hang upon. Then you become aware of a misty presence floating inside the whiteness.
fields.body:
In this exhibition, which claims to have been inspired by Zurbaran's The Veil of St Veronica, Shirazeh Houshiary presents us with paintings that at first seem simple monochromes, their white surfaces as smoothly consistent as the white walls they hang upon. Then you become aware of a misty presence floating inside the whiteness. It's a minute difference, a tonal contrast, creating a disturbance of the visual field. There's another whiteness inside the whiteness (and in one, another blackness inside the blackness), a numinous presence. You are overwhelmed by this mystical cloud of unknowing.

Or that's what you're supposed to feel. Houshiary is heir to a mystical vein in modern art whose Sistine Chapel is Rothko's room of near-black paintings in Houston. Entitled Self Portraits, Houshiary's paintings imply a journey of self-discovery. Hung far apart in the generous spaces of the Lisson Gallery, they defy you not to be moved by their spiritual power.

I wasn't moved. These paintings play a trick on your senses. You find yourself doubting the boundary between one object and another as the paintings float in space. But, like a magic act, it has a perfectly rational explanation.

Moving closer, you discover that each one has an area - a blob in the middle, or a band across the top - that is not smooth white at all but marked with graphite lines forming calligraphic patterns. In the past Houshiary has inscribed Islamic holy words in her paintings and sculptures; here there is no decipherable language. The effect of this muted pattern is clever; it alters the texture of the painting just enough to create the oscillation that had been so mysterious. Optics, then, not God.

Once you work this out, it's as flat as a cheap conjuring act. Houshiary is no David Blaine, plying her craft on the sidewalk. You wonder if she's ever walked down a street. This is the kind of art that can only function in the theatre of the gallery. It depends on placing, hanging, getting things just so. It's easy to imagine these paintings decorating a certain kind of modern interior, yet they are in bad taste: tacky parodies of monochromes. They introduce a rhetorical figurative element - you are supposed to imagine a cloud, a misty sunrise, the face of God - instead of paring painting down to stark facts with the kind of honesty that distinguishes the white paintings of Agnes Martin or Robert Ryman.

This is empty stuff.

fields.headline: Panic buyers boost sales
fields.trailText: Panic buying by households during the fuel crisis boosted retail sales last month, the British Retail Consortium reports today.
fields.body:
Panic buying by households during the fuel crisis boosted retail sales last month, the British Retail Consortium reports today.

Grocery stores did well as consumers grabbed essentials but non-food stores were hit when families were forced to leave their cars at home.

Sales rose 2.9% over the year to September, according to the BRC, from the 1.7% growth recorded in August. Fuel shortages distorted the figures by shaving at least £200m off sales in the week of peak disruption.

Government figures separately show British companies suffering a double whammy of higher oil prices and a falling sterling exchange rate against the dollar, which is pushing up raw material costs.

Manufacturing input costs climbed 2.8% in September, says the office for national statistics, the largest monthly jump since May. There are few signs of higher inflation in the pipeline as firms appear to be absorbing increased costs. The price of goods leaving the factory rose just 0.3%.

Fuel and raw materials tend to be priced in dollars so last month's fall in the dollar-pound rate pushed up import prices across the board, according to Geoffrey Dicks, UK economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland.

"Where they are competing against euroland suppliers they are up against the weakness of the euro," he said. "Profit margins are being squeezed at both ends."

fields.headline: Brundibar
fields.standfirst: Bloomsbury Theatre, London ****
fields.trailText: "This is more than an opera," we were told in an introduction to Hans Krasa's Brundibar, and it's absolutely true. The circumstances of this opera's early performances have a power and significance far beyond the work itself. Brundibar was written in 1938 by the Czech composer Hans Krasa and playwright Adolf Hoffmeister. Krasa revised the opera in 1943 after being deported to Terezin, the ghetto town that was to be the last stop before Auschwitz for so many Jews.
fields.body:
"This is more than an opera," we were told in an introduction to Hans Krasa's Brundibar, and it's absolutely true. The circumstances of this opera's early performances have a power and significance far beyond the work itself. Brundibar was written in 1938 by the Czech composer Hans Krasa and playwright Adolf Hoffmeister. Krasa revised the opera in 1943 after being deported to Terezin, the ghetto town that was to be the last stop before Auschwitz for so many Jews.

Brundibar, a simple tale of good triumphing over evil, of children and animals working together to outwit the grown-ups, was performed by the children of Terezin 55 times. One performance, given during the inspection of Terezin by the International Red Cross, was even the subject of a Nazi propaganda film. Yet of the hundreds of children who gave these weekly concerts, only four are known to have survived. One of them, Paul Aron Sandfort, was present here to speak about his experiences. After hearing him talk dispassionately, it was impossible not to be moved by the performance that followed.

The children of Jeunesses Musicales were performing under considerable pressure - London was the final stop on a tour that had seen them perform the Brundibar in eight countries in just 10 days. The start was delayed as their train from Brussels had run late; straight after the 40-minute performance they were due to catch the train back again. But they were a resilient bunch, and the principals, hailing from all over northern Europe (with the exception of Britain) performed with commitment and obvious enjoyment. The production itself was a hotch-potch of colour, not stylish but easy to understand - which was necessary, as in every country on the tour the children were performing in Yiddish.

Accompanying them was a band of young players drawn from the Jeunesses Musicales World Orchestra, conducted by Michel Tilkin. The score of Brundibar was written for professional players. While the lines for voices were simple, the orchestra added a good deal of colour, with some warm string writing and bold, languid trumpet melodies.

Krasa, a protege of Zemlinsky, was deported to Auschwitz in 1944 and didn't live to capitalise on the talent he had shown as a composer. If Jeunesses Musicales's project is realised, there will soon be performances of Brundibar mounted all over the world. Brundibar may not be the work that Krasa would most have liked to be remembered by, but it remains a potent memorial to him and to the children of Terezin.

fields.headline: Bedbound
fields.standfirst: New Theatre, Dublin  ****
fields.trailText: Playwright-director Enda Walsh, whose Disco Pigs is currently being made into a film, is on similar territory with Bedbound, his dank, puke-stained new yarn. Again, it is a two-hander, this time about a father and daughter who are hemmed into a room only big enough for a filthy bed.
fields.body:
Playwright-director Enda Walsh, whose Disco Pigs is currently being made into a film, is on similar territory with Bedbound, his dank, puke-stained new yarn. Again, it is a two-hander, this time about a father and daughter who are hemmed into a room only big enough for a filthy bed.

From time to time, the father roars up in his dirty, frayed suit and trumpets about how he ruthlessly fought to become the leading furniture dealer in Cork. Along the way, he sacrificed himself, the daft minions who worked for him, his marriage and his infirm daughter, whom he imprisoned in barbaric, bloody-minded shame. After periodic brainstorms, he buries himself abjectly in the bedspread. Then the wraith-like daughter, who cannot bear the silence, begins to voice her own headful of memories.

Apart from brief, abusive interchanges, the pendulum swings rhythmically between their separate monologues. She at first cowers before his physical menace, yet as he lays bare more atrocities, she gains power, culminating in a redemptive moment that dubiously celebrates their squalid, mutual dependency.

Walsh is still dredging the dialect and landscape of gutty, underclass Cork, and once again, he puts a galloping topspin to the manic deliveries, leaving you grappling with the onslaught of forceful, wilfully queasy vocabulary. He gets fierce performances from his actors. Peter Gowen thrashes out a sweat-dripping picture of the self-pitying, murderous father, while Norma Sheehan nicely renders the defiant whine of the Cork accent. Physically too, she twists herself into pathetic contortions, with a psychiatric strobe of tics. And she goes way beyond realism in the heart-rending scene when the father reads her a page of a romantic novel.

It's an odd piece, with its mixture of child world and murderous male instincts. One wonders whether a less young-headed style might have better put across the tale. You can see the bones of the plot poking through the skin. But it carries a memorable whack.

 Until October 14. Box office: 00-353-1-677 2600.

fields.headline: LSO/Pappano
fields.trailText: The Greek philosopher Epicurus argued that religion instilled a terror of death and eternal punishment in its adherents. It would seem that Gabriel Fauré, though a fervent Catholic, thought on similar lines: when he came to write his Requiem in 1888, he removed the prospect of damnation from Christian eschatology by jettisoning the bulk of the text of the Dies Irae. The end result avoids apocalyptic cataclysm and focuses on consolation - and can lead to terrible drawbacks in performance, as conductor after conductor laces Fauré's pacific vision with cloying sentimentality.
fields.body:
The Greek philosopher Epicurus argued that religion instilled a terror of death and eternal punishment in its adherents. It would seem that Gabriel Fauré, though a fervent Catholic, thought on similar lines: when he came to write his Requiem in 1888, he removed the prospect of damnation from Christian eschatology by jettisoning the bulk of the text of the Dies Irae. The end result avoids apocalyptic cataclysm and focuses on consolation - and can lead to terrible drawbacks in performance, as conductor after conductor laces Fauré's pacific vision with cloying sentimentality.

Antonio Pappano chose it as the main work in the second of his London Symphony Orchestra concerts, and, as might be expected, subjected it to a drastic rethink, resulting in the most intense performance I've ever heard. Saccharine piety is replaced by a dramatic conflict between austerity and sensuousness. Sorrowing humanity seems trapped in ritual lamentation, surrounded by sparse orchestral textures. The Offertorium gives us a glimpse of souls in Purgatory hovering between light and darkness. The pleasures of Paradise are ushered in with shimmering tone colours.

More than once you're aware of Fauré's debt to Brahms's Requiem: the comparable withdrawal of the upper strings to darken the texture in moments of anguish; the similar antithetical deployment of baritone and soprano soloists to represent human vulnerability. Simon Keenleyside's utterances combine lyricism with a declamatory sensuality. Dorothea Röschmann's extraordinary soprano seems poised angelically in the air. The choral singing is rapt and eloquent. Pappano conducts without a baton, his hands slowly unfurling with infinite beauty and grace.

Before the interval, he presented us with the Symphonie Liturgique by the French-Swiss composer Arthur Honegger. Written in 1946, it might have been nicknamed "Apocalypse Now" for it equates the second world war with God's unleashing of His wrath upon mankind. Either you can cope with its sentiments or you can't, though it remains a formidable, if flawed score.

Pappano can't quite disguise the fact that the slow movement goes on far too long and repeats its material once too often. The outer sections are terrifying, however. The first movement, all flaring brass, shrieking woodwind and relentless ostinati, is Hell in sound. The finale is a pulverising march that depicts mankind turned into a robotic killing machine. It's scary stuff and a tour de force for both Pappano and the LSO, who perform it to perfection.

webTitle: Jazz review: Fred Hersch/ Four In Perspective

fields.headline: Fred Hersch/ Four In Perspective
fields.standfirst: Caedmon Hall, Gateshead  ****
fields.trailText: Fred Hersch is one of the most formidably complete piano improvisers playing today, and yet he has a fraction of the public profile of his former pupil Brad Mehldau. He would have to qualify for sainthood for his feelings on this matter not to be mixed.
fields.body:
Fred Hersch is one of the most formidably complete piano improvisers playing today, and yet he has a fraction of the public profile of his former pupil Brad Mehldau. He would have to qualify for sainthood for his feelings on this matter not to be mixed.

Though his rich, orchestral technique makes Hersch a compelling solo recitalist, he is a selfless collaborator with musicians whose angles on jazz are quite different from his own. Four In Perspective sets Hersch with three very personal British stylists - vocalist Norma Winstone, trumpeter Kenny Wheeler and percussionist Paul Clarvis.

In the early stages of their first tour date, all four searched for common routes. Initially the local players were more relaxed with homegrown materials such as Wheeler's typically plangent Everybody's Song But My Own. Fred Hersch's compositions are an amalgam of theatrical atmospherics, buoyant Latin music and playful nudges in the ribs of old jazz styles that recall the antics of the Dutch free-improv surrealists. As the gig went on, the quartet blossomed.

Since the late 1980s Hersch has worked extensively for gay causes, and one of the most gripping episodes in the performance was Blues for Matthew Sheppard, an evocation of the last hours of a murdered gay man, chillingly caught by Clarvis's desert-wind noises and Wheeler's skewed-pitch exhalations.

Once the playfully adaptable Clarvis and Hersch discovered a vivacious dialogue between the piano and the bodhran drum, the splicing of free-jazz, ragtime and Dixieland in Nostalgia worked better than its incongruities might have implied. The encore, Janeology (from Hersch's work with saxophonist Jane Ira Bloom), with Hersch and Clarvis throwing tempo conundrums at each other, was postbop to put you on the edge of your seat.

 Four In Perspective are at Dean Clough, Halifax (01422 255266), tomorrow, then tour.

fields.headline: Seethru so transparent
fields.trailText:

Said site contains a thinly veiled attack on the shadow home secretary's brave stand against that hardcore criminal element, cannabis smokers, under the headline "Widdecombe you hilarious clown". This is an outrageous misrepresentation of the facts and a clear example of political bias - La Widdecombe has never been funny in her life.


Barely believable
Kevin Brown, founding partner of Soul and a successful and no doubt wealthy ad man, is simply unable to resist starring in his own ads. However, friends of his have this week admitted he's now taken things too far by stripping down to the short and curlies - something he appears to have plenty of - for the sake of the Daily Star's "MegaStar" campaign. The poster features a nude - and rather flushed - Mr Brown covering (just) his modesty with a board advertising the site. Mark Cranmer, chief executive at Starcom Motive and a dear friend of his, said: "Kevin has a long history of exhibiting himself. He's done ads promoting gambling, alcohol and now blatant sex. I feel he should have asked for his legs to be retouched, though, because he seems to be suffering from the skinny legs/far gut syndrome that comes to all men as they get older. I love Kevin, but he is mad." Even one of Kevin's co-founders is advising people to turn a blind eye to the stunt. "I wouldn't look at it if I were you - you might find it offensive," he said. You're not wrong, Duncan.

Caught out on a techie point
Programmers panning TV shows? Geeks up in arms about TV stars? What the heck is going on? Anyone would think the BBC had made a show about a dot.com start-up. TV audiences may be unimpressed by This Life 2, the one set in a new media start-up and called Attachments, but those whose lives BBC2 is trying to mimic are even more unimpressed. True, World Productions may have done some homework, but those finicky techies are taking umbrage at any slight faux pas - such as transferring files by throwing floppy disks across the office and talking about downloads and demos as a revenue model. Those that haven't vented their spleen already are invited to do so at Everyonehatesattachments.com. But be careful, these hardcore new media types don't take prisoners.

Invaluable sentiment
Granada Media chairman Charles Allen began his first address to troops of his newly acquired United News & Media by declaring how much his company values programme-makers. Not such a surprising sentiment, you'd imagine, coming from the boss of a company with a significant TV production arm - but the jaws of senior United TV execs hit the floor all the same. Apparently the only word they were used to hearing from former boss Clive Hollick in the same sentence as "value" is "shareholder".

When the caption fits...
Sir Christopher Bland got a morning grilling from the delectable Sophie Raworth (isn't Jeremy looking fetching too with his matching purple tie?) on BBC breakfast news today. Pity about the caption though, which read: "Fiona Mannion: mini owner".

expectingcomplaints.com
Monkey apologies for allowing a cad like Danny Kelly to blatantly pull the wool over readers' eyes in Monday's edition of the Media Guardian. Asked about his favourite websites, Kelly named expectingrain.com and woolyrockstars.com. Pernickety readers, i.e. those that go through absolutely everything with a fine-tooth comb, immediately pointed out that the latter website does not in fact exist. More importantly neither the .com or the .co.uk domain names for Woolyrockstars have been registered. Was Kelly making a mockery of us all or was he merely pointing out a new market niche? Kelly says neither: "I'm very much afraid this thing does exist. The url, however, is woollyrockers.com. Check it out!!" Duh! Monkey did and fell in love with the Bee Gees doll. Could Kelly have created a monster?

Minutes matter
What's this? The BBC's famously impartial news reporting standards slipping over its own 10pm news bulletin announcement? The Monkey has got its paws on an internal email from BBC Online producer James Thornet that was sent round after the news broke to BBC online hacks out in the sticks. He draws his colleagues' attention to the fact that the switch to 10pm means the regional bulletin tacked on at the end of the proper, grown-up news will be extended to a massive six-and-a-half minutes. "We must put this story at the top of online news stories asap," says the excitable Thornett. Is he worried viewers in the regions wouldn't notice the difference otherwise?

Only slimline warriors need apply
Monkey has received an email from Rainbow network, home of Xena fans (see proud to portly, below), anxious to set the record straight. "Firstly, the generosity of Channel 5 in offering Rainbow a box of T-shirts goes without saying - we were delighted to receive them, and we had loads of entrants to the competition in which they were the prize. On opening the eagerly awaited box of goodies, however, we could tell straight away that there was no way, with the best will in the world, anyone other than a small teenager or large Teddy bear was going to be able to get into them.
We closed the competition as images of irate readers struggling to get an arm in a size 6 garment sprang to mind. As Tamara, the Xena co-ordinator at Channel 5, said: 'Annoyingly our merchandise person fits these and didn't consider the more womanly figure, ie me.' We're with you, Tamara!
Some lucky winners did decide to hang on to their prizes, although we still have 35 or so here in the Rainbow office. Send us your address and we'll happily send you one." Monkey is unsure about being compared to a large teddy bear, but may well have to take up Rainbow's kind offer in the spirit of investigation.



Sticky gimmicks
Monkey was amused to discover an overflowing pot of honey in the post today. The honey pot subsequently attacked all surrounding computers and made everything in the office sticky. Eugh. The penny finally dropped when Monkey found the attached (and at this point very sticky) note, saying that eBay was stickier than QXL. Point taken. But did it really have to destroy my workspace to tell me that?

Clash of the dot.com giants
Plunging dot.com stock prices are nothing new, but the long-term ramifications are starting to impact heavily on those big boys we call Amazon and eBay. Rumours have started to surface about a mooted merger between the two e-commerce giants, which have both been rocked by the recent downturn in dot.com fortunes. A tie-up would make sense, particularly for Amazon, which is struggling to convince investors of its long-term earnings. Perhaps it should take a leaf from eBay's gimmick book and start sending out plants and pots of bottled Amazon river water to prove to investors that Amazon can make things grow. Just a (naff) suggestion.

Proud to portly
Channel 5 kindly sent 50 of its finest Xena, Warrior Princess T-shirts to the gay and lesbian website Rainbownetwork.com for a competition giveaway, on account of the pigtailed one being terribly popular with the target audience. Channel 5 was staggered, then, when Rainbow very apologetically sent them all back. It seems the T-shirts are of the cropped belly button-baring variety and, after a bit of market research in the office, Rainbow discovered they were too petite for its users. Seems a shame to let them go to waste, so Monkey is happy to try to squeeze into one to show support.

Bad taste sensation
GMTV managing director Christopher Stoddart is so concerned about reports of tasteless office banter that he has issued an email to all staff reminding them of the company's equal opportunities policy. In a carefully worded memo, he also reminded staff of the company's grievance procedure and told them that they mustn't feel frightened of whistle-blowing on their bosses. "From time to time we will be drawing your attention to important company policies which we all need to follow. Our equal opportunities policy is particularly important because its scope is both on-screen and off-screen," he wrote. "Should any employee have a complaint under this policy [or for any other reason] he should feel free to raise the matter." He continued: "If it concerns their line manager, then they may wish to consult personnel." Who on earth has prompted this and what on earth did he or she say? Answers on the back of a cornflakes box, please.

Rings a bell
Readers of the Scotsman who also take Sunday Business may be suffering from a sense of déja vu. A few weeks ago top Sunday Biz hack Richard Northedge wrote a coruscating profile of some suit or other doing something fantastically important in the City. Two weeks later a frighteningly similar article (exactly the same except for two small amendments) appeared in the Scotsman's revamped business section, albeit under a different byline. Perhaps Northedge should sue for plagiarism. But then the ed-in-chief of the pink Sunday is one Andrew Neil, who is also in charge of the Scotsman. Other Sunday Business hacks should expect further doppelganger copy to start appearing north of the border under increasingly ludicrous invented bylines.

Not quite all over for Wembley commentator
The man who coined the immortal phrase "They think it1s all over..." really did think Wembley was going to be all over without him. Kenneth Wolstenholme, commentator at the historic 1966 England World Cup victory at Wembley over Germany, hadn't been invited to the England-Germany match on Saturday, the final game before the stadium is demolished. Now Sport First has hired the game's most memorable voice to write about the last match. What a joy, says Kenneth. Well, it is now!

What's in a suffix?
Associated New Media finally came clean with its plans and new name for lead balloon CharlotteStreet.com this week, scotching rumours that it was going to launch you.co.uk. Instead we're to get femail.co.uk and rumour has it this new strategy of using the mail suffix will be applied to a number of Associated New Media websites. Staunch Royalist The Mail is said to be keen to develop a site devoted to that bastion of British culture, the Royal family (no, not the TV programme) but unfortunately for The Mail, a certain carrier of letters has already had the foresight to register royalmail.co.uk. Keen checkers of domain name registrations however, will be aware that Associated has already registered travelmail.co.uk, shopmail.co.uk, moneymail.co.uk and financialmail.co.uk. In fact the only one that is still available is showbizmail.co.uk - better snap it up quick.

Email the Media Monkey at Monkey@mediatheguardian.com

webTitle: Anwar's majestic century sends Sri Lanka packing

fields.headline: Anwar's majestic century sends Sri Lanka packing
fields.trailText: Saeed Anwar struck an unbeaten century as Pakistan powered into the semi-finals of the ICC Knockout tournament yesterday with a nine-wicket victory over Sri Lanka in Nairobi.
fields.body:
Saeed Anwar struck an unbeaten century as Pakistan powered into the semi-finals of the ICC Knockout tournament yesterday with a nine-wicket victory over Sri Lanka in Nairobi.

Wasim Akram and Azhar Mahmood claimed three wickets apiece as the Sri Lankans were dismissed for 194 in 45.4 overs, the lowest score of the tournament so far.

Anwar's 105 not out, his 18th one-day century, then guided Pakistan to 195 for one with over six overs to spare aided by Imran Nazir, who was run out for 40, and Yousuf Youhana, who finished undefeated on 42.

Sri Lanka, who won the toss and opted to bat, made a terrible start which was in stark contrast to their 108-run victory over West Indies in the preliminary round.

Aviska Gunawardena, who scored a century against West Indies, and Marvan Attapattu were both out in the first four overs before their side had reached double figures.

The Sri Lanka skipper Sanath Jayasuriya shared a third-wicket stand of 55 with Mahela Jayawardena but the captain's 39 was his team's highest individual score.

The only other partnership of note was between Russel Arnold (38) and the wicketkeeper Romesh Kaluwitharana (27) with 56 runs for the sixth wicket.

Pakistan will now play the winner of today's quarter-final between New Zealand and Zimbabwe.

India bundled the world one-day champions Australia out of the tournament on Saturday, beating them by 20 runs in their quarter-final.

Chasing 266 to win, Australia at 159 for three seemed well on course, despite having their innings reduced by two overs because of their earlier slow bowling rate.

Although the opener Mark Waugh fell cheaply for seven, Adam Gilchrist (33) and Ian Harvey (25) repaired the damage before Michael Bevan (42) and Ricky Ponting (46) put on 73 for the fourth wicket.

But the Australian gamble of packing the side with bowlers backfired as a couple of smart catches and two great run outs left them short of batting talent.

Earlier, Yuvraj Singh hit a superb 84 runs in his first innings for India. The left-handed middle-order batsmen hit 12 fours in his 80-ball innings before he finally skyed a ball and was caught and bowled by Shane Lee .

There was an extraordinary contest between the Indian opener Sachin Tendulkar and the Australian fast bowler Glenn McGrath.

Tendulkar had given India a flying start by hitting three sixes in consecutive overs off McGrath, but Brett Lee ended the contest when Tendulkar edged to Damien Martyn at first slip. His 38 came off 37 balls. McGrath had a nightmare day, conceding 61 off his nine overs and failing to take a wicket.

India will play the winner of tomorrow's quarter-final between England and South Africa.

fields.headline: Oxford sink into depression
fields.trailText: Swindon 2 - 1 Oxford
fields.byline: Richard Rae at the County Ground
fields.body:
Poor Oxford. Nothing seems to be going right for them and, in a thunderous and hugely competitive derby, their luck ran out too. Managerless and bottom of the table, they played with immense spirit, created the better chances and still, somehow, contrived to lose.

Colin Todd, meanwhile, has Swindon passing the ball nicely, but rather like their manager in his defensive prime, they retain the capacity to make lapses under pressure.

So though Swindon looked the neater team, Oxford's directness made them the more threatening. Bart Griemink was forced into several acrobatic saves, the best from Matt Murphy's point-blank header. When Lee Jarman drove the resulting corner against the post, Oxford must have feared the worst.

The more so when soon afterwards Swindon scored a simple opener. Martin Williams headed Matt Hewlett's cross back across goal, where Alan Reeves swept it home from six yards.

But Oxford were not without the class to respond. Guy Whittingham, on loan from Portsmouth, had already missed one simple chance but made amends on the hour, connecting with Sam Rickett's pass.

With time running out, however, Todd made a double substitution, of which he is entitled to be proud. Within 90 seconds both substitutes had contributed to a sweeping move that one of them, Giuliano Grazioli, finished from Sol Davis's low cross.

webTitle: Own goal leaves Hill a mountain to climb

fields.headline: Own goal leaves Hill a mountain to climb
fields.trailText: Luton 0 - 1 Millwall
fields.body:
It is a question that has been asked in the battered boardrooms of the lower league, the marble halls of the Premiership and is being asked now in the corridors of power at Lancaster Gate. Should you appoint a manager with a playing pedigree at your club or country, or go for someone who has cut their coaching teeth elsewhere?

On the evidence of Millwall's win here yesterday, the latter is definitely preferable. Three weeks ago, the Londoners axed Keith Stevens and Alan McLeary - stalwart former Lions both - in favour of Mark McGhee.

Luton, on the other hand, appointed Ricky Hill in the summer in succession to Lennie Lawrence. The silky midfielder shone in the Bedfordshire side's decade in the top flight between 1982 and 1992. But if yesterday is anything to go by, he has a tough task on his hands.

Battered in the first half, Luton responded in the second before Gavin McGowan hacked Christophe Kinet's cross into his own net. It was just reward for Millwall's resilience and Luton's lack of a killer pass in attack.

McGhee was respectfully upbeat: "Some people needed to be convinced I was the right man for the job but hopefully two wins in my first two games have done that. However, when I came here the team was already playing well and was confident. There was lots of good work done before I arrived and I've just been trying to continue that."

Hill has former Luton players as assistant manager, scout and physio. It is a deliberate policy. "We need people who have an affiliation for the club, have Luton at heart and are willing to do the work," he says. "Obviously the fans are going to be a little more sympathetic to my cause. But it is like a marriage. When things are going well we love each other but when they are not it hits the fan."

With only seven points from his first 11 games maybe a little marriage guidance would not go amiss.

Three weeks ago, the Londoners axed Keith Stevens and Alan McLeary - stalwart former Lions both - in favour of Mark McGhee. Luton, on the other hand, appointed Ricky Hill in the summer in succession to Lennie Lawrence. The silky midfielder shone in the Bedfordshire side's decade in the top flight between 1982 and 1992. But if yesterday is anything to go by, he has a tough task on his hands. Battered in the first half, Luton responded in the second before Gavin McGowan hacked Christophe Kinet's cross into his own net. It was just reward for Millwall's resilience and Luton's lack of a killer pass in attack. McGhee was respectfully upbeat: "Some people needed to be convinced I was the right man for the job but hopefully two wins in my first two games have done that. However, when I came here the team was already playing well and was confident. There was lots of good work done before I arrived and I've just been trying to continue that." Hill has former Luton players as assistant manager, scout and physio. It is a deliberate policy. "We need people who have an affiliation for the club, have Luton at heart and are willing to do the work," he says. "Obviously the fans are going to be a little more sympathetic to my cause. But it is like a marriage. When things are going well we love each other but when they are not it hits the fan." With only seven points from his first 11 games maybe a little marriage guidance would not go amiss.

fields.headline: Lack of belief costs Wednesday
fields.trailText: Sheff Wed 1 - 2 West Brom
fields.body:
Just as the warm, sunny afternoon descended into a wintry deluge yesterday, so doom and gloom returned to engulf Sheffield Wednesday.

The home side's bright start was forgotten in the soggy chill as Jason Roberts slid home West Bromwich's winner; even the Hillsborough band dropped their instruments to boo.

"That was probably our best defeat so far," said the Wednesday manager Paul Jewell ruefully. "If we had a bit more belief in the final third we would have done better."

As if to prove as much, both his strikers were substituted, with Gilles de Bilde set to join Aston Villa today on a two-month loan. The Belgian was anonymous yesterday and left the pitch to loud abuse from the stands. "It's just not going to happen for him here," added Jewell. "And Sibon stormed off at the end. At least he stormed off somewhere."

The home team started like a side weighed down by five successive league defeats. Inside three minutes Roberts saw his curled effort tipped wide by Chris Stringer. Then, from the resulting corner, an airborne Neil Clement steered a shot against the angle of post and bar.

Wednesday were as rattled as the woodwork but steadily found their feet down the flanks. Wednesday's right side is borrowed from Premiership clubs - Robbie Stockdale from Middlesbrough and Terry Cooke from Manchester City - but in the surging runs of Alan Quinn, back from international duty with Ireland, and Owen Morrison there is home-grown hope.

Indeed it was Morrison who opened the scoring, trapping Aaron Lescott's scuffed effort and, while the Albion defence appealed for off-side, placing his shot beyond Brian Jensen. Within two minutes, however, Roberts had out-jumped Steve Harkness to flick Lee Hughes's cross inside Stringer's near post.

"We weren't at the races at times, but to come here and get a 1-1 draw wasn't really what we needed," said the Albion manager Gary Megson.

The former Wednesday midfielder watched the excellent Stringer deny Roberts and Hughes with smart saves before Wednesday's fragile confidence was exploited for a decisive second 14 minutes from the end. Hughes squared the ball across the six-yard box for Roberts to prompt the boo-boys.

webTitle: County scrape draw but look doomed

fields.headline: County scrape draw but look doomed
fields.trailText: Stockport 1 - 1 Portsmouth
fields.body:
It was written in the stars. Take one side without a home win and the other still searching for their first three points on the road. Put them together and there is only ever going to be one outcome.

A single home victory in the year 2000 spells relegation in anyone's book. And for 80 minutes yesterday County played with the look of doomed men. Portsmouth's first-half superiority was almost embarrassing yet their failure to turn possession into goals, with the exception of Lee Mills's close-range shot from Shaun Derry's cross in the 15th minute, would ultimately prove costly.

When both Steve Claridge and Derry wasted clear chances late in the game you always felt there would be a sting in the tale for the south coast side.

It arrived with two minutes remaining thanks to Kevin Cooper's volley from the edge of the area after the Pompey defence had only partially cleared a corner. Seconds later Cooper was within inches of stealing all three points with a low shot that grazed a post.

The stalemate left both managers pondering their job security. "I'll just keep on doing what I do until someone else tells me otherwise," said Tony Pulis, Pompey's manager.

His opposite number Andy Kilner tried to talk up his team's performance by claiming, falsely, that his team had the lion's share of the chances. "The players are apprehensive at home," he said. "The crowd get on their backs and they immediately go into their shells."

Next up at Edgeley Park are Bolton, unbeaten away this season. For Kilner and County the omens are not good.

webTitle: Adebola makes it a happy return

fields.headline: Adebola makes it a happy return
fields.trailText: At Crewe, come rain or shine, the manager stays. It poured on Dario Gradi yesterday, 17 years in charge, but he is well used to home defeats, especially in this division, where Crewe's presence is one of the game's small wonders. He has brought them gloriously up from the old Fourth.
fields.body:
At Crewe, come rain or shine, the manager stays. It poured on Dario Gradi yesterday, 17 years in charge, but he is well used to home defeats, especially in this division, where Crewe's presence is one of the game's small wonders. He has brought them gloriously up from the old Fourth.

In the end Birmingham, who go fourth, were too strong physically and financially, imposing their experience on a side that typically included three 20-year-olds and six former trainees. Typically, too, it was a former Crewe player, Dele Adebola, who swung the game City's way.

Crewe's gift is in making gems - or sometimes polishing other people's - and selling them to keep the system going. "The academy cost half a million pounds a year to run," said Gradi. Adebola, sold for £1m, was two years' worth. It was a measure of City's different situation that he is currently transfer-listed and started on the bench.

Gradi admitted afterwards that he would love to see Adebola return but admitted such a move was unlikely.

"Dele would make a difference to us, but then he's a £1m player so he should. I haven't got any £1m players," he said. "He is much the same as he was when he was here. He doesn't chase every ball but he's a handful and very powerful."

Adebola's influence was immense, unsettling Crewe's defence and opening doors by a mixture of force and finesse. Until his replacement of Peter Ndlovu the first half was like the first half at Wembley, only with England playing England. The ball was released without care and returned as likely as not by an opponent.

Crewe, successful with three at the back at Tranmere, retained the formation. It worked well enough defensively, with Steve Macauley commanding, but Birmingham's midfield four pressed Crewe's midfield five so well that Crewe's front two became isolated and forlorn.

Trevor Francis, Birmingham's manager, said he had identified the middle three as Crewe's fulcrum. Martin O'Connor, Bryan Hughes and Danny Sonner stopped it functioning and the play seized solid in Crewe's half, Birmingham lacking wit and width, Crewe unable to release themselves.

Adebola set up the only chance of the first half, Geoff Horsfield pushing it wide. Early in the second his aerial menace caused havoc after Stan Lazaridis crossed, allowing Hughes to drive in the loose ball. After that Birmingham's ascendancy was such that it might have been six.

Jason Kearton kept out shots by Darren Purse, O'Connor and David Holdsworth but, when Adebola got the better of Dave Walton, Marcelo Cipriano slipped home a cross. Adebola signed off with a last minute bullet against the far post.

Beforehand Crewe had played Jerusalem but their arrows of desire were not arrows of direction. They had none on target, indeed none at all until they were two down.

Gradi admitted: "Our play on the ball was poor." He may not ever be up to taking them further but late last night there was still no sign of a resignation.

fields.headline: King Kevin abdicates again
fields.trailText: David Lacey Kevin Keegan has quit at the worst possible moment but, for experienced Kev-watchers, this selfish decision hardly comes as a surprise.
fields.body:
Of the 10 men who have been in charge of the England football team over the past 54 years, Kevin Keegan will be remembered as a cheerleader who denied Wembley one last hurrah and then quit while he was behind.

Keegan's sudden resignation five minutes after his team had lost Saturday's World Cup qualifier 1-0 to Germany concludes the most bizarre period yet in the quirky history of national managers.

The England coach had taken over 20 months earlier following the Football Association's decision to sack Glenn Hoddle once the prime minister, put on the spot in a day-time TV chat show, had muttered that if Hoddle really had implied the disabled were paying for the sins of past lives he ought to go.

In view of what has happened now Hoddle might have been referring to the FA international committee, for if ever a body is reaping the whirlwind of past misdeeds it is surely this one.

Bobby Robson took England to the semi-finals of the 1990 World Cup but his contract was not renewed, Terry Venables had already decided not to sign a fresh contract by the time England reached the last four of Euro 96, the committee having expressed doubts about his legal wrangles with Alan Sugar and the Department of Trade and Industry, and Hoddle's sin was to express his beliefs clumsily to a national newspaper.

The timing of Keegan's departure was totally predictable. His temperament and lack of tactical nous made him a bad choice from the start.

When he originally agreed to take the job for four matches, while remaining manager of Fulham, Keegan promised that the players would sing the national anthem with passion and bring a similar mood to their performances. Well, not all of the team were singing before Saturday's match and not enough of them were in harmony during the game to form a barber's shop quartet.

Keegan also stressed that in no way would he leave Fulham once his four-match stint had ended. After two games in charge, however, he decided that "it's time to stop playing games - I want the job". On Saturday he again decided it was time to stop playing games, only now he believed he was not up to the job after all. In other words after taking the England post saying I'm sorry I'll read that again he has abandoned it admitting I'm sorry I haven't a clue.

Keegan's plea of mea culpa - "I'm blaming nobody but myself. I wasn't good enough" - the revelation that during England's awful first half that he did not know what to do, his apparent self-sacrifice in order to hand the squad over to someone with more knowledge and the hardly original thought that he wants to spend more time with his family will cut little ice with experienced Kev-watchers.

He has walked out after a defeat that made it imperative that he stayed for at least four more days in order to give England the best chance of repairing the damage, serious though hardly mortal, to their chances of qualifying for the World Cup caused by an initial home defeat. Instead of which Howard Wilkinson, the FA's technical director, will again pop up like George, the inflatable automatic pilot in Airplane, to take over the team for Wednesday's qualifier in Finland.

When Don Revie quit on England during a World Cup qualifying campaign the FA tried, unsuccessfully, to ban him from football for 10 years. True, Keegan did not conduct covert negotiations with the United Arab Emirates before giving his resignation exclusively to a newspaper but his defection is scarcely more admirable.

If, as he insists, he enjoyed the full support of everybody at the FA from the chairman to the Lancaster Gate cat then surely he could have given the job one more chance.

Keegan's excuse that the fans who clamoured successfully for his appointment had helped him make up his mind on Saturday by booing him as he left the arena is barely worth consideration. If every England manager had walked out after being jeered at Wembley Alf Ramsey, Ron Greenwood, Bobby Robson, Graham Taylor and Glenn Hoddle would not have lasted anywhere near as long as they did.

According to Adam Crozier, the FA's chief executive who has limited experience of these things: "It is never easy to say I'm not going to be England coach any more. To walk away from that is a very courageous thing to do." Yet surely it would have been even more courageous to stay put, tough it out, and risk the probability of being ditched by the FA if the team also lost in Helsinki.

It is not as if Keegan had a rough ride from the media, who let him down relatively lightly after the debacle of Euro 2000. Keegan was never vilified in the press as Robson was more than once. He was never lampooned as cruelly as Taylor nor hung out to dry like Hoddle. The heat in Keegan's kitchen barely rose above gas mark one.

Crozier was nearer the mark, albeit unwittingly,when he observed that "I think Kevin Keegan knew he was making the right decision for Kevin Keegan". That is surely the point.

On Saturday Keegan made all the right self-deprecatory noises in the interviews. He is a master of the soundbite and it is a pity that his tactical know-how in handling reporters' questions was not matched by an ability to organise the England team.

"I just feel that for Kevin Keegan there is nothing more in football I want to do," he said a trifle wistfully. Presumably this precludes returning to TV as a soccer pundit. Surely he can never sit in judgment on England again having admitted that he did not know enough when he was in charge.

webTitle: Wilkinson sends for Teddy as England regroup

fields.headline: Wilkinson sends for Teddy as England regroup
fields.trailText: England's caretaker manager has called Man Utd's Sheringham into the England squad, while Stuart Pearce and Brian Kidd temporarily join the coaching staff.
fields.body:
Howard Wilkinson resumed as England's caretaker coach yesterday calling for pride and performance when the team Kevin Keegan left behind take on Finland in Wednesday's World Cup qualifier in Helsinki.

The 1-0 defeat by Germany on Saturday, which was swiftly followed by Keegan's resignation, has already severely dented England's chances of qualifying automatically for the 2002 tournament as group winners. But they can still reach the play-offs as runners-up, since Finland, Greece and even Albania may take points off one another.

Last night Wilkinson, the Football Association's technical director, was looking on the bright side. "We've got 21 points to play for," he said, "and that is a better situation than Kevin faced when he took the job on."

Yet he has only three days, and two training sessions, in which to restore England's spirits. "It's a matter of giving them a way to play and trying to create that way of playing," Wilkinson explained. "That and talking about pride and performance. But these are top performers and top performers do get not where they are without having pride."

Wilkinson has been dealt an even poorer hand than he had after Glenn Hoddle was dismissed by the FA in February last year. Then he had a week to prepare for a friendly against France at Wembley, which England lost 2-0.

Now he has to try and beat the Finns without David Beckham, who went home yesterday after aggravating the knee injury that was threatening to keep him out against Germany. "Beckham has a medial-ligament problem which he has had for a couple of weeks," said Wilkinson, "and he needs to do something about it."

Also out is Steven Gerrard, who missed Saturday's match with a recurring groin injury. Paul Scholes (foot), Gary Neville (toe) and Graeme le Saux (calf) are having treatment but Wilkinson feels that none of these three is a serious doubt.

Teddy Sheringham is being called in as Wilkinson seeks the attacking experience England will need if they are seriously to entertain thoughts of winning in Helsinki. Some felt that the 34-year-old Manchester United player had shown sufficiently good form this season for Keegan to recall him for the Germany game.

Sheringham last appeared for England 16 months ago when he won his 38th cap in the disappointing 1-1 draw with Bulgaria in Sofia that left England's chance of qualifying for last summer's European Championship still in the balance. Wilkinson clearly sees his ability to link up the play and bring those around him into attacking movements as crucial to England's chances of beating Finland.

Yesterday he found himself virtually without a backroom staff after Arthur Cox and Peter Beardsley, both connected with Keegan in his Newcastle days, resigned as assistant coaches. Brian Kidd, head of youth development at Leeds United, and West Ham's Stuart Pearce have agreed to fill in for the next three days.

Wilkinson said he had been shocked and saddened by Keegan's decision to quit. "I spoke to him on Saturday morning and nothing he said indicated that this was a remote possibility," he said.

The former England midfielder Sammy Lee will step up to take charge of Wilkinson's Under-21 side for tomorrow's European Championship qualifier in Finland.

Lee, a regular member of the Under-21 backroom team, first under Peter Taylor and then Wilkinson, will be assisted by the former Manchester United and Chelsea manager Dave Sexton, who has had a spell as the Under-21s' coach himself.

They will be forced to make at least one change from the side that conceded a late equaliser to Germany in Friday's 1-1 draw as the Liverpool defender Stephen Wright was sent off in that game and is suspended for a match.
