fields.headline: Wales stall on uphill journey
fields.standfirst:
Wales 1 - 1 Norway
Blake 60 Helstad 80
fields.trailText: Norway's tactics are not rocket science, unless one is talking about Stephenson's Rocket. But their frustrating habit of defending in numbers and flooding midfield has bamboozled enough opponents to lift the Scandinavians to 11th in the world rankings.
fields.byline: Martin Thorpe  at the Millennium stadium
fields.body:
Norway's tactics are not rocket science, unless one is talking about Stephenson's Rocket. But their frustrating habit of defending in numbers and flooding midfield has bamboozled enough opponents to lift the Scandinavians to 11th in the world rankings.

From that point of view, 113th-placed Wales can take some comfort from the fact that they managed to draw against superior opponents and in fact came within 10 minutes of victory.

However, a point at home was never going to be enough for a Welsh side who had already lost their opening qualifier in Belarus and are now bottom of Group Five below mighty Armenia.

With a daunting tie in Poland to come on Wednesday, Wales's chances of qualifying for their first World Cup finals in 42 years are in danger of disappearing faster than Kevin Keegan's limo out of Wembley.

Nevertheless, an impressively loyal crowd of 51,000 applauded their team off the pitch despite the loss of two home points. Expectations are measured differently in the Millennium stadium than they are beneath the twin towers. The players had given their best, and though that will never set the world on fire, that is all anybody can ask.

Welsh optimism was initially rewarded with a cracker of a goal on the hour. Andy Melville found Gary Speed, who swung in a pinpoint cross, and Nathan Blake directed a stunning header into the top corner.

Wales should have capitalised as Norway became increasingly ragged. But despite great work from Ryan Giggs, John Hartson twice wasted chances.

Ten minutes from time Wales paid the price. Paul Jones could only parry Oyvind Leonhardsen's shot to Thorstein Helstad, and the substitute shot against the post before scrambling the rebound over the line. As ever, Wales's journey is uphill.

fields.headline: Healy's appetite sustains Irish
fields.standfirst:
Northern Ireland 1 - 1 Denmark
Healy 38, Rommedahl 60
fields.trailText: Sammy McIlroy, Northern Ireland manager, reckons that David Healy, Manchester United reserve centre-forward, could at last be the answer to a goal famine that has plagued Irish squads for more than half a century.
fields.body:
Sammy McIlroy, Northern Ireland manager, reckons that David Healy, Manchester United reserve centre-forward, could at last be the answer to a goal famine that has plagued Irish squads for more than half a century.

"That was a classic strike," commented McIlroy. "With his hunger for goals, he can eventually break Colin Clarke's record of 13."

Healy pounced on Jesper Gronkjaer's slovenly back pass and from 25 yards struck the ball right-footed into the net to bring his goal tally to five in six internationals.

The United starlet described how he took his goal just as simply. "I never expected to get the chance," he said, "but I saw a gap and I hit it."

McIlroy added: "He took a lot of punishment from the Danish defenders, who tightly marked him, but came back for more. Fans will talk about that goal for years to come."

McIlroy also described Healy as a true goalscorer. "He expects to score every time he takes to the field. When he doesn't he is disappointed."

George Best also praised Healy. "That is phenomenal," said the former Northern Ireland great. "He is a youngster of great promise but it's just a pity it didn't herald a Northern Ireland victory."

Denmark (4-4-2) Schmeichel; Helveg, Gravesen, Henriksen, Heintze; Rommedahl, Tofting, B Nielsen, Gronkjaer (Bisgaard, 61min); Tomasson, Sand (Jensen, 83).

Referee: V Pereira (Portugal).

webTitle: FA rewrites rulebook to find the right man

fields.headline: FA rewrites rulebook to find the right man
fields.standfirst: The search is on for a new - and possibly foreign - manager
fields.trailText: The search is on for a new - and possibly foreign - England manager
fields.body:
Somewhere in a dusty folder in a rusting filing cabinet deep in the basement of Lancaster Gate, there is a piece of paper listing the rules for appointing the national team manager. And uppermost among them is that the job can only be awarded to an Englishman.

But the Football Association's chief executive Adam Crozier has already made it clear that the New FA, as they might be called, are ready to tear up the rules and appoint the best man, whether from Tooting or Timbuktu.

Unless, while reworking the rulebook, the FA tear up an unwritten law of football politics - never to forgive or forget old enmities - by reappointing Terry Venables, the FA may actually have little option other than to appoint a manager for whom English is a second language. They came close enough with Glenn Hoddle.

Though Venables is unlikely to return, he cannot be discounted because his many supporters have already got the bandwagon rolling and, under Crozier, the FA likes to be seen as an administration that has more listening skills than the government.

Frighteningly, Howard Wilkinson, the FA's technical director and acknowledged as the most unreconstructed long-ball man in England, now seems to be putting himself in the frame.

If he and Venables are ruled out, the FA would have only 11 English Premiership managers to choose from and two of those, Hoddle and Bobby Robson, have already had the job. If they are not considered it is a painfully thin-looking list.

You can tell that by the way John Gregory, who has done a decent job at Aston Villa without threatening to make them either successful or entertaining, is once again listed as one of the favourites. But the only two serious candidates, Bobby Robson apart, would seem to be Peter Taylor and Bryan Robson and both would be considered something of a gamble.

As brilliantly as he did as the England Under-21 manager Taylor is only two months into his first Premiership job at Leicester and may be unable to work with Wilkinson, who took Taylor's international role with considerably less success.

Bryan Robson has had limited success as manager of Middlesbrough. But his main problems have been caused by some disastrous transfer dealing, which would not be a factor with England.

The FA's priority in making their decision must not be convenience but getting the right man, though foreign candidates such as France's World Cup-winning manager Aimé Jacquet and the sacked Internazionale coach Marcello Lippi have the benefit of being available as well as possessing the right credentials.

Of course, if we are to have a foreigner, we might as well have one of our own, so to speak, with the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger the outstanding and most obvious choice. The FA, though, would face a messy and protracted fight with Arsenal to gain his services. And that is in the unlikely event of Wenger wanting the job.

webTitle: Daum to face down his critics

fields.headline: Daum to face down his critics
fields.trailText: Christoph Daum, due to take over the German team from Rudi Völler next year, refused yesterday to take a hair analysis test to dispel rumours he has used cocaine.
fields.body:
Christoph Daum, due to take over the German team from Rudi Völler next year, refused yesterday to take a hair analysis test to dispel rumours he has used cocaine.

Daum plans to hold a press conference today to rebut the charges of prostitute and drug use made by Bayern Munich manager Uli Hoeness, which set off one of the most bitter feuds in German soccer history.

The Bayer Leverkusen coach, said he has other methods to prove he doesn't use drugs. "I don't need to take a hair analysis test, but I have other findings I will present at a later time," said Daum, adding a test would violate his legal rights.

German interim coach Rudi Völler and the Bayern Munich president Franz Beckenbauer are among those to have supported Daum. Beckenbauer said the right decision was made to hire Daum for the job while Völler reiterated his decision to quit the job next year, despite having led a revived German team to three successive victories.

"Christoph Daum has earned it as a person and a coach to take over this job. My mind hasn't changed - I won't take the job," said Völler.

webTitle: Brown and Scots keep their heads

fields.headline: Brown and Scots keep their heads
fields.standfirst: San Marino 0 - 2 Scotland Elliott 71, Hutchison 73
fields.trailText: Scotland are continuing their unlikely charge and sitting at the top of Group Six. There has been mayhem and madness around the Scottish camp in recent days but that did not stop them putting San Marino to the sword. Given San Marino's total population of 24,000, this was just as well.
fields.byline: Graham Spiers at the Stadio Olimpico
fields.body:
Scotland are continuing their unlikely charge and sitting at the top of Group Six. There has been mayhem and madness around the Scottish camp in recent days but that did not stop them putting San Marino to the sword. Given San Marino's total population of 24,000, this was just as well.

There had already been one British international manager's head placed on a spike on Saturday, and for 70 minutes of this match it looked like Craig Brown might be joining Kevin Keegan. Scottish football has been parlous for years but defeat or even a draw here would still have been ignominious. San Marino have played 47 matches and lost 46 of them.

Brown, who was taking charge of his 62nd successive Scotland match, breaking the records held by Jock Stein and Andy Roxburgh, was already in hot water over what has become known as the Jim Leighton Affair.

With absurd timing, Leighton has brought a mixture of scandal and farce to this Scotland six-day trip. The 91-times-capped goalkeeper had famously fallen out with Alan Hodgkinson, the former England keeper who works with the Scottish squad, yet still asked Brown if he could come on the trip as a coach.

It has since emerged that Leighton had good reason for wanting to don his SFA blazer. He had fancied touring San Marino and Croatia to continue his beat as a radio summariser. But Ebbe Skovdahl, the manager of Aberdeen, where Leighton works as a goalkeeping coach, did not want him away from the club for so long. A quick call from the ever-willing Brown to Skovdahl helped fulfil Leighton's wish by giving it the air of an international call-up.

But Leighton, in the very days that he was away with Scotland, had attacked Hodgkinson, Brown and the SFA in a book that is being serialised in a tabloid back home. The revelations have caused uproar and brought severe embarrassment to Brown.Leighton was suspended by the SFA and packed home on a mercy flight yesterday.

The Scots at least put this behind them to wear San Marino down. Matt Elliott, the big Londoner, was put in attack by Brown in the second half and placed a deft header past Fred Gasperoni after 71 minutes. Don Hutchison, the tall Geordie, made it two for the Scots, prodding the ball home from seven yards.

A gang of 3,000 Tartan Army members had been singing of Keegan's glorious downfall. As the minutes ticked away, though, their nervousness had become almost pitiable.

Two early goals and two in the last eight minutes secured Belgium an easy 4-0 victory over Latvia on Saturday, moving them into second place behind Scotland in Group Six. Marc Wilmots and Bob Peeters opened the scoring and Jurgen Cavens and Gert Verheyen completed the job.

San Marino (4-5-1): F Gasperoni; Gennari, Gobbi, Matteoni (Valentini, 73min), Bacciocchi; B Gasperoni, Manzaroli, Zonzini (Della Valle, 79), Muccioli, Marani; Montagna (De Luigi, 60).

Scotland (3-4-3): Sullivan; Hendry, Elliott, Dailly (Weir, 35); McNamara, Hutchison, Cameron, Naysmith; Gallacher (Dickov, 67), Dodds, McCann (Johnston, h-t).

Referee: T Orrason (Iceland).

fields.headline: Rights of passage
fields.standfirst: The Human Rights Act came into force a week ago, making the European Convention part of our law.  Lord Hope of Craighead, a law lord, warns judges not to be too trigger-happy in shooting down claims
fields.trailText: The Human Rights Act came into force a week ago, making the European Convention part of our law. Lord Hope of Craighead, a law lord, warns judges not to be too trigger-happy in shooting down claims
fields.body:
Those who doubt the wisdom of the Human Rights Act tend to see the rights and freedoms in the European Convention on Human Rights in terms of absolutes - leading on the one hand to a culture of rights without responsibilities, and on the other to a situation where rights are at risk of being removed by judges who are unelected and unaccountable. There is a balance to be struck if our human rights law is to win and retain public confidence.

The court's task is to strike a fair balance between the interest of the community and the protection of the individual. I agree with those who say that the purpose of the Convention is to create a fair and decent society, not to let criminals off the hook, and that victims and witnesses have rights too.

Some guidance as to where this will all lead us is available from north of the border. The system of devolution that was created for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland requires the devolved legislatures and executives to legislate and to act in a manner compatible with the Convention rights. In Scotland, since devolution in May 1999, lawyers have been active in raising issues about possible incompatibility. But statistics about the success rate of Scottish cases are an imperfect guide to what will happen north and south of the border now that the Human Rights Act has come into force. [The Human Rights Act covers all public authorities; the Scotland Act, under which cases have been brought north of the border since May 1999, covers only the devolved legislature and executive.] In Scotland the great majority of issues raised have been in criminal cases, not in the much wider field over which the Human Rights Act now extends and these issues have been directed almost entirely to the acts of the public prosecutor. So the development of the case law has been on a narrow front.

The low success rate in Scotland (one assessment suggests that of more than 600 legal challenges in the past 12 months only 16 have been successful) is largely due to the fact that many challenges relate to elements of the right to a fair trial, such as delay, admissibility of evidence and the effect of prejudicial publicity. The Scottish judges have been following the European Court of Human Rights in deciding that the fairness of the trial must be determined in the light of the proceedings as a whole, and are discouraging attempts to have these issues determined before conclusion of the trial. But now that the way is open for challenges across the entire field of action by public authorities the success rate is much less predictable. My guess is that it is likely to increase.

What is likely to happen next? Judges are urging lawyers to be restrained in the cases they bring, and are urging their colleagues to be robust in refusing to allow such challenges, as indeed they should be if they are plainly unmeritorious. On the other hand, the Lord Chancellor has said that the value of the Human Rights Act lies in the fact that people will be saved the trouble of taking their cases to the court in Strasbourg. It seems to me that there is an uneasy relationship between these two points of view.

If people are to be saved the trouble of going to Strasbourg they will have to be able to obtain their remedy here. The fact that it is simpler and quicker to apply to the courts of this country is bound to lead in the short term, as it has in Scotland, to a great increase in the number of cases. But I do not see this as reason for treating such applications any more robustly than any other kind of application, or for asking lawyers to exercise greater restraint in bringing them than they would in other cases. The tradition in this country is that the courts are open to any person who feels his rights have been infringed. Lawyers owe a duty of care to their clients, and the House of Lords recently held that even in the courtroom they no longer have immunity against claims for negligence. So the judges are in no position to complain if counsel err on the side of caution in their own interest in making these applications. They must also appreciate that the courts, as public authorities, are themselves under a duty of compliance with the Convention rights. The UK will still be under an obligation in international law to bring its domestic law into line with the Convention as interpreted by that court, even if this conflicts with the view taken by our judges. So I would favour caution, in the initial stages at least, rather than robustness - lest, in a fit of enthusiasm for throwing cases out, the judges find themselves on the wrong end of a challenge under article six of the Convention, the right to a fair hearing.

 This is an edited extract of a lecture by Lord Hope to the law reform group Justice.

webTitle: Keegan's tactical failing: he was not simple enough

fields.headline: Keegan's tactical failing: he was not simple enough
fields.trailText: Ron Atkinson Kevin Keegan may have had the qualities to succeed as England coach. But too many players stayed in their shells when the heat was on.
fields.body:
I am not a member of the anti-Keegan brigade by any means. In fact I believe that if the players had given Kevin as much as he gave them over the past 10 months, he would still be in charge of England this morning.

But watching at Wembley on Saturday it did strike me that Kevin has not followed what I feel is one of the most important steps for anyone moving from club management on to the international stage.

International coaches see their players so infrequently they need a definite idea of how they're going to play and have to get things across quickly. They have to look at their squad, decide what suits it best and stick with that through thick and thin. In his last two matches alone, against France and Germany, Kevin used 4-4-1-1, 4-4-2 and 3-5-2, yet all successful teams have a good, set pattern.

Germany were a useful side rather than a brilliant one, but they looked well organised and comfortable. You could see every player had a job to do and knew what he was doing. At times a lot of our players looked as if they were playing a bit off the cuff.

At club level Kevin tended to have more or less set patterns, and they were very adventurous ones. Maybe he knew he couldn't be that adventurous in internationals. It would be nice to play gung-ho but the only way you can do that is if you have 11 better players than the opposition.

Unfortunately, one of the biggest problems the England manager faces - and Kevin said this on many occasions - is that although we have some good players, a lot of them appear to be inhibited when they play for the national team.

Players with massive reputations have not always justified those reputations under Kevin. Against Germany too many went into their shell, and that's hard to legislate for.

Tactically I feel a lot of the same principles apply in club and international matches. But it's very apparent that in modern international football you need a midfield that is fairly heavy in terms of numbers and can deal with the ball. If you give the ball away too easily you get punished. It's harder to get back.

That is, to an extent, the coaches' responsibility. You've to encourage players to pass the ball and keep possession; and you've got to make players brave enough to play on the ball even if it means playing a more patient style.

In 1993, after Graham Taylor left, I was approached by the FA's ombudsman Jimmy Armfield to see if I was interested in taking the job. There was talk of a possible link-up with someone like Bryan Robson. But I said quite frankly I didn't fancy it.

People are surprised when you say that but I was with Aston Villa and we had just finished second in the Premier League. When you are in big club management I think most people would prefer that day-to-day stuff.

For me the press wasn't really a factor but I'm sure Kevin will have been astonished by the hostility of the media towards the England manager. Few people have more experience than him but he must have been hurt and surprised at how many were looking to see him fail.

Don't forget that at Newcastle and Fulham he had crowds that idolised him; and it was the same for him as a player. He has said the press gave him a fair run but I think he wants to leave without bitterness.

Of the other changes a manager faces when he works for his country, a more constricted base is an obvious one. As the manager of Newcastle the world's your field if you are looking for players. Kevin could pick up stars from abroad and mould them alongside home-grown lads. By contrast, England's players offered less scope for choice.

But there is no clear pattern to international success and failure. Don Revie looked certain to be one of the most successful managers of all time but disappointed with England.

I am impressed with how Rudi Völler has handled himself and it is obvious the players have a healthy respect for him.But then, as Keegan knows, respect is not enough. He may have been better advised to have one or two more experienced international coaches around him. Even Bobby Robson had Dave Sexton, Terry Venables and Don Howe at times.

But one thing is for certain: the job of England manager and England cricket captain are the two most unenviable in the world of sport.

webTitle: Shearer allowed too much space during Sky's extra time

fields.headline: Shearer allowed too much space during Sky's extra time
fields.trailText: Fancy that. Milosevic and Keegan in the same week. The reviled leader whose disastrous regime brought a once proud nation to its knees deposed by the will of his people, and (all together now) President Milosevic kicked out as well.
fields.body:
Fancy that. Milosevic and Keegan in the same week. The reviled leader whose disastrous regime brought a once proud nation to its knees deposed by the will of his people, and (all together now) President Milosevic kicked out as well.

I should explain. I would have come up with a more original joke, but was lulled into a state of near catatonia by Alan Shearer. Sky, who scooped the world with the Keegan story, had made the mistake of booking Kev's soporific former skipper as studio guest, and were more or less stuck with him when the England manager failed to emerge from the dressing room for his post-match interview.

Pity the poor director. For half an hour after the match, with nothing happening down below, all he had to cut to were pictures of celebrating German fans, for which I suspect instinct told him there was limited popular appetite, so he and we were left with the alternative - Shearer in conversation with Richard Keys, not exactly the ticket to lift the spirits after a miserable afternoon.

Keys understandably floundered, resorting to questions like "Just how disappointed will the lads be?" - a question I always think needs to be more precisely framed, like: "How disappointed will the lads be? As disappointed as someone who was expecting a nice sweater for Christmas and instead got handkerchiefs, or as disappointed as someone who has just lost a much-loved relative in a three-car crash on the M25?"

Shearer, true to form, was short on revelation, although he did reveal exclusively that Seaman would be "disappointed" by the goal he let in.

In the end, though, the former England captain pulled the chestnuts from the fire as he has done so many times for the national team. As news filtered through that Adam Crozier and Noel White of the FA were in the dressing room with Keegan, Shearer was able to tell Keys that this was no ordinary post-mortem. FA officials did not join manager and players in the dressing room after a match in the normal run of events, Shearer indicated. To convey all that without moving your lips is some achievement.

Finally Keegan emerged, and nothing became him quite so much as his leaving. Typically, he fulfilled his duties to TV and the FA by making his resignation speech in front of the sponsor's boards, thus ensuring that the Nationwide achieved maximum visibility throughout all the evening news bulletins and sports programmes, although whether association with the low returns and disappointing yield of the Keegan era will attract many new investors is questionable.

"What's been going on in there?" asked Sky's Claire Tomlinson. "Well, I've told the players it's my last match," said Keegan. Just like that. Very low key. And then he did a very strange thing indeed. He said he was going because he was not up to the job.

Can you think of anyone else in public life who has ever left a job for that reason? No, me neither. They leave because they've been caught with their hand in the till, or other body parts where they should not be, or to pursue other projects, or to spend more time with their family. Most of them, of course, however dismal or patently unworthy, just stay in the job.

But Keegan admitted he had given the England job his best shot, and found he just wasn't good enough. This prompted some typically incisive analysis from Richard and Alan. "He says he's not the man for the job," said Keys. "What do you think he means by that?" Well, I'm no expert, but...

Keegan's honesty does him great credit, but it doesn't make him a suitable England manager. For that, you probably need to be a bit of a bastard. Fortunately for the FA, there are plenty of those to choose from in the list of Keegan's possible successors.

Keegan's leaving made it a good day for Sky but a rotten one for ITV, whose highlights programme began at 5.25, just as Kev was turning it in.

I assume they had to sit on the story for an hour so as not to give the score away. Keegan, in fact, scuppered everybody who had arrived for the final Wembley international to write an entirely different story. By half five, my Sunday paper colleagues were probably waiting for the traffic to clear having delivered their Wembley stadium obituaries and "Keegan must go" pieces. Then he goes. The resultant ringing of mobiles must have sounded like every fruit machine in Brent was paying out at once.

Maybe the timing of Kevin's resignation was one final good turn to his players, forcing criticism of some of their performances down the page. Or maybe it was to save the rest of us from any more valedictory Wembley guff. "Join us for 11 hours of coverage on this famous weekend," Sky said in its Friday night trailer.

Martin Tyler's "the gods seem to be weeping for Wembley, and up in the heavens they'll be jostling for seats today - Bobby Moore, Stanley Matthews and all" was typical of their understated approach. Even Alan Shearer was forced to admit it was... er... a bit special.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk.

webTitle: England must rebuild to mark end of Wembley era

fields.headline: England must rebuild to mark end of Wembley era
fields.trailText: So much for the People's Choice. The sudden departure of Kevin Keegan following Saturday's defeat by Germany at Wembley illustrates with devastating clarity the danger of basing the selection of England's head coach on enthusiasm, personal popularity, and a hunch. Keegan was as accurate in his Saturday-night self-analysis - "I came up short" - as he was misguided in his decision last year to turn the original part-time commission into a permanent posting.
fields.body:
So much for the People's Choice. The sudden departure of Kevin Keegan following Saturday's defeat by Germany at Wembley illustrates with devastating clarity the danger of basing the selection of England's head coach on enthusiasm, personal popularity, and a hunch. Keegan was as accurate in his Saturday-night self-analysis - "I came up short" - as he was misguided in his decision last year to turn the original part-time commission into a permanent posting.

Perhaps this time the job will be entrusted to a man with the qualities and the qualifications necessary to meet the cruel and unusual demands of the task. But that scenario, of course, presupposes the existence of a governing body with the intelligence and willpower required to take the right decisions, rather than being guided in its choice by the instincts of the mob.

In football terms, this is England's Year Zero. Nothing new there. Similar words were said when Revie fled to Saudi Arabia, when Robson gave up, when Taylor imploded, and when Hoddle's inarticulacy blew up in his face. But this time it must be for real. Whatever the temptation to appoint a high-profile manager with a successful record, and however much the Football Association may be impressed by Rudi Völler's swift transformation of German fortunes, nothing less than a complete commitment to the root-and-branch restructuring of England's coaching will do.

In the meantime Terry Venables will swagger back into the frame, backed by his fan club in the press and opposed by senior elements in the FA's international committee, who did not take kindly to his commercial adventures last time around. The usual cast of stopgap solutions - Ron Atkinson as the Joe Mercer de nos jours , for example - will be paraded alongside the list of men who qualify solely by virtue of being English and in charge of a Premier League club, such as Bryan Robson, John Gregory and Peter Reid. But the failure of Keegan, that most English of Englishmen, means that the idea of a foreigner suddenly becomes more acceptable, with the names of Sir Alex Ferguson, Arsène Wenger, Aimé Jacquet and Marcello Lippi joining the very short and unimpressive list of native-born candidates.

That particular quartet can probably be written off. Ferguson is too Scottish and too smart. Wenger has spent too much time in England to remain unaware of the brutal fate awaiting anyone daring to step into the job. Were he to leave Arsenal and move into international management, Japan - with its less abrasive football culture and its steadily rising growth curve - would be a far more likely option. Jacquet, even if he could be persuaded to consider the offer, would be an unwise choice since his World Cup triumph of 1998 came not as a result of his individual coaching genius but as the consequence of several years of highly focused work by a large team. And, in any case, who but an Englishman would view the chance to resurrect England's fortunes as an interesting choice of encore after winning the World Cup with one's own country? Lippi, although successful with Juventus in the mid-90s, has just been fired by Internazionale after failing to make anything of a team of expensive superstars.

What a strange and bitter irony it is that the man who should by rights have been England's next head coach is now sitting at the top of the Premiership, looking down on Ferguson and Wenger. Had England been serious about following the French model of smooth and seamless transition between coaches, Peter Taylor would have been the next in line for the job. Instead, he is probably sitting in his office at Leicester City's training ground this morning thanking his lucky stars that he is no longer an employee of the FA.

There can be no excuse. The modest and unglamorous Taylor was hastily removed from the stewardship of England's Under-21 squad a year and a half ago simply to make room for Howard Wilkinson's ambition. And yet Wilkinson - the original advocate of the French method, in which modest and unglamorous men succeed each other without drama - is now being summoned in the present emergency to take on the caretaker role he performed to such undistinguished effect against France at Wembley during the post-Hoddle interregnum, despite having failed to match Taylor's impact with the Under-21s.

Maybe Taylor would have been the right man for the job - now or, preferably, in a couple of years' time - and maybe he would not. But the present mess is exactly what English football deserves, coming in the wake of a match which, having been relentlessly hyped as a combination of VE Day and Millennium Eve, not only exposed the shortcomings of the football team but took place amid a mood of such depravity as to make one wonder exactly what, in far wider terms, the English think they are doing with themselves.

The day began, for some of us, with a slide-show demonstrating the virtues of the new English National Stadium. This will contain, we were told, a luxury hotel and several acres of rentable office space. Those of us whose most recent direct experience of big new stadiums has been in Paris and Sydney found ourselves suddenly wondering why neither the Stade de France nor Stadium Australia has a hotel and rentable office space built in.

The answer, one imagines, is that neither France nor Australia is fortunate enough to possess a figure like Ken Bates, the chairman of Wembley National Stadium Ltd, who is such a fan of adding extra facilities to football stadiums that his own personal creation, the redeveloped Stamford Bridge, now resembles a shopping mall on the Las Vegas strip.

Either that, or France and Australia retain a decently proportioned sense of national pride which, long lost in England, permits them to see such money-grubbing schemes for what they are.

As for the old Wembley, it got the send-off it deserved in the minds of those for whom the warmth of nostalgia has long since been overwhelmed by a thorough dislike of the place and the noxious atmosphere it creates. On Saturday it was at its absolute worst, off the pitch as well as on it, the incessant drizzle and the pathetic attempt at an after-match firework display emphasising the mood of depression.

Some would see the wholehearted jeering of the German national anthem as a harmless display of a certain British sense of humour, not to say a fine old Wembley tradition. But the resulting embarrassment paled next to any decent response to the sound, in the minutes before half-time and with Germany firmly ensconced in the lead, of a large proportion of the crowd rising to face the section of visiting fans in the north-western curve and singing: "Stand up, if you won the war." An encore of the Dam Busters' March, with accompanying aeroplane gestures, was greeted by the German spectators with an answering volley of flashbulbs. It was not hard to imagine what they will be saying when they show their souvenir snaps to their friends in Munich and Berlin.

Imagine, too, the feelings at that moment of Keegan, whose own playing career in Germany was marked not merely by success on the pitch but by his willingness to make the effort to adapt to the culture of a foreign country and to behave in general like a citizen of the world. As he scanned the stands and heard the singing, he may have asked himself what he was doing managing a football team on behalf of that bunch of cretins in News of the World plastic bowler hats, the dark underbelly of Euroscepticism.

In the aftermath of Keegan's meltdown, there were various bland statements of intent from Adam Crozier, the FA's chief executive. But there have been few signs - in fact no signs at all - in the months since Euro 2000 to suggest that the current hierarchy has the wisdom to make the sort of far-sighted decision needed to revive the fortunes of the national team, any more than it has the genuine resolve to do something about the rotten fan culture.

If they are serious about laying the kind of foundations that brought victory in the World Cup to France two years ago, they will have to accept that qualification for the 2002 finals is not the priority. Since that would involve risking potential revenues of £50m or more, they may find this hard to accept. But to avoid the responsibility of rebuilding is to run the far more serious risk of repeating Saturday night's dismal scenario not once but over and over again.

But the resulting embarrassment paled next to any decent response to the sound, in the minutes before half-time and with Germany firmly ensconced in the lead, of a large proportion of the crowd rising to face the section of visiting fans in the north-western curve and singing: "Stand up, if you won the war." An encore of the Dam Busters' March, with accompanying aeroplane gestures, was greeted by the German spectators with an answering volley of flashbulbs. It was not hard to imagine what they will be saying when they show their souvenir snaps to their friends in Munich and Berlin. Imagine, too, the feelings at that moment of Keegan, whose own playing career in Germany was marked not merely by success on the pitch but by his willingness to make the effort to adapt to the culture of a foreign country and to behave in general like a citizen of the world. As he scanned the stands and heard the singing, he may have asked himself what he was doing managing a football team on behalf of that bunch of cretins in News of the World plastic bowler hats, the dark underbelly of Euroscepticism. In the aftermath of Keegan's meltdown, there were various bland statements of intent from Adam Crozier, the FA's chief executive. But there have been few signs - in fact no signs at all - in the months since Euro 2000 to suggest that the current hierarchy has the wisdom to make the sort of far-sighted decision needed to revive the fortunes of the national team, any more than it has the genuine resolve to do something about the rotten fan culture. If they are serious about laying the kind of foundations that brought victory in the World Cup to France two years ago, they will have to accept that qualification for the 2002 finals is not the priority. Since that would involve risking potential revenues of £50m or more, they may find this hard to accept. But to avoid the responsibility of rebuilding is to run the far more serious risk of repeating Saturday night's dismal scenario not once but over and over again.  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: Decision stuns Germany and the world

fields.headline: Decision stuns Germany and the world
fields.trailText: The flag of St George flew forlornly yesterday at the former England manager Kevin Keegan's family home, a £1.5m mansion on the outskirts of Teesside.
fields.body:
The flag of St George flew forlornly yesterday at the former England manager Kevin Keegan's family home, a £1.5m mansion on the outskirts of Teesside.

Nobody answered the electronic buzzer system at the entry to the imposing house which Keegan shares with his wife Jean and their two daughters.

Meanwhile reaction to Keegan's departure was characterised by shock and sympathy with even the Germany captain Oliver Bierhoff saying he was "sorry".

The England defender Gareth Southgate, whose controversial selection in midfield for the game against Germany was severely criticised, paid tribute to Keegan. Southgate told BBC1's Breakfast With Frost: "It was quite a surprise. But we all know that he is a man of principle."

And though West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp wondered why anyone would want the "aggravation" of the England job, Southgate's sentiments were echoed by many from Alan Shearer, who said he was "amazed" and "in shock", to Lawrie McMenemy , the former Northern Ireland manager.

"I was sat with Keegan's wife Jean when word came out and we were all stunned by it," said McMenemy, who signed Keegan at Southampton. "I think it's a great pity. The dressing room, which no matter what anyone says is the most important part of it all, was welded together. The players were all behind him. But Kevin's strong-minded and if he makes a decision no one's going to change it."

Members of the victorious German party were also bemused. "He shouldn't have resigned over that game," said the former Germany coach Franz Beckenbauer . "It was not a bad performance; in fact it was quite a good one for England. I would not have resigned under those circumstances - there must be more to it."

As a former Hamburg player Keegan might elicit particular support in Germany. Bierhoff said he felt sorry because Keegan was "a good person", but noted that the timing of the departure was not ideal.

"You could say it would have been better a time to go after Euro 2000, like our coach [Erich Ribbeck] did," he said. "Then a new man could have come in. The timing was not very good with the Finland game on Wednesday."

Not that Southgate sounded as if he held the manager responsible for the 1-0 defeat. "You can talk about formations and everyone will have their opinions," he said, "but we have to take responsibility as players for not playing well enough in the first half. There was not enough movement."

As the search for Keegan's successor gathers pace, there is plenty to point the Football Association in the direction of a foreign appointment.

McMenemy said: "I don't think there will be many left in Britain who will want to take the job or have got the experience even. It will be a poisoned chalice if we are not careful. If it was just down to the manager and the players and the staff it would be completely different. But the tension you get, particularly with England, is enormous."

Redknapp made a similar point: "With all the aggravation you get I cannot think of a worse job. Whoever takes it, after three or four months they will start to get abuse because basically we do not look good enough."

That downbeat view of England's quality did not prevent an upbeat reaction in the German newspapers to their second successive qualifying win. "World Cup - We're Coming," announced the front page of Bild am Sonntag, and the campaign to keep Rudi Völler as coach has gathered pace.

Völler is due to hand over next summer to Christoph Daum. But Welt am Sonntag suggested that he should stay put. "Under Rudi Völler and [his assistant] Michael Skibbe, Germany can celebrate its return to being world class," it wrote.

And what now for Keegan? Not football by the sound of things. "One thing about Kevin is that he doesn't need the game to have a life," McMenemy said. "He's always had a other things he can get involved in."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk.

fields.headline: England's diamond turns to dust
fields.standfirst: England 0 - 1 Germany Hamann 14
fields.trailText: The defeat that hastened Kevin Keegan's departure as England coach was largely brought about through an English diamond being trumped by German hearts. Keegan employed a tactic of the 70s and saw it outpassed, outwitted and outrun by the football of the new millennium.
fields.body:
The defeat that hastened Kevin Keegan's departure as England coach was largely brought about through an English diamond being trumped by German hearts. Keegan employed a tactic of the 70s and saw it outpassed, outwitted and outrun by the football of the new millennium.

It was England's worst performance in a qualifier since Graham Taylor's side lost 2-0 to Norway in Oslo in 1993 and was precipitated by a similarly flawed strategy. For just as Taylor had declared Gary Pallister, a centre-half, a full-back inorder to counter the threat of long high balls reaching the lofty Jostein Flo on the right, so Keegan played Gareth Southgate, a central defender, in midfield hoping to minimise the influence of Mehmet Scholl behind the German strikers.

Taylor's plan backfired from the moment that Flo switched to the left wing and took Pallister with him. Keegan's ploy foundered because Rudi Völler, the Germany coach, disobligingly played Oliver Bierhoff as a lone central striker with Scholl roaming far and wide.

Southgate was once a workaday midfielder with Crystal Palace but became an established international as the spare man in defence. He soon lost track of Scholl and thereafter appeared confused as to what his role should be.

As a result the diamond became a rhomboid with David Beckham drifting in from the right to search for the ball, Nick Barmby uncertain as to whether he should do likewise on the left, and Paul Scholes inundated by Germans when the opposition broke away.

Things might have been better, during that apocalyptically bad first half for England, had the full-backs Gary Neville and Graeme le Saux provided the team with consistent width and supplied the quality of centres needed to disturb Germany's back three.

Neville, however, simply froze at the idea of crossing the halfway line and Le Saux, though willing to move forward on the left, was increasingly hampered by a tight muscle. After half-time Neville gave way to the pacy Kieron Dyer and Southgate went back into defence. England had a better shape but by then the shape of the match was unalterable.

Most of the time England's two strikers, Andrew Cole and Michael Owen, scarcely brought a wrinkle to the foreheads of Jens Nowotny and the other German defenders, so poor was the service from midfield and the wings. To the end Nowotny was able to stride upfield to help set up chances which might have increased England's humiliation, always assuming this was possible.

The amount of freedom Germany were allowed in midfield was embarrassing. Dietmar Hamann is a competent footballer for Liverpool in the Premiership but the way England played he was allowed to become another Günter Netzer.

Likewise Carsten Ramelow and Michael Ballack had all the time and room they needed to bring the ball out of defence and swing lazily past what was often token opposition. On the right wing Marco Bode, tall, athletic and with good close control, reminded Wembley of just how far Neville has receded as an international defender, and on the left the 20-year-old Sebastian Deisler put into perspective all those optimistic noises about the quality of youngsters England are supposed to possess.

Yes, Joe Cole, Gareth Barry and Titus Bramble might, just might, become decent international players, and others will have good careers in the Premiership. But compared with Argentina, say, the budding talent in England with genuine world-class potential would not fill a window box.

England are caught in a three-way trap, with promising young players not yet ready, some of the thirtysomethings past their sell-by dates and too many of those in between simply not up to international standard.

Nick Barmby, for example, was rightly talked up for a recall before Euro 2000 because he was in form and Keegan had no one else with left-wing inclinations. But on Saturday he was in a position to be compared with Deisler and in truth there was no comparison.

Tony Adams was England's best player, especially when trying to stop the tide before half-time. But a successor should have come along before now. As for David Seaman, the goal he conceded after 14 minutes was, on the evidence of his erratic form for Arsenal over the past 18 months, an accident waiting to happen.

Hamann's free-kick, taken from a central position at a range of more than 30 yards, brushed Scholes's boot but was still saveable. Seaman, however, was out of position and dived too late to do anything but get a hand to it.

Maybe England had not wanted to offend German sensitivities by building a wall. Certainly their idea of a wall belonged to A Midsummer Night's Dream, with one man playing the part. No wonder, perhaps, that Seaman dropped a brick.

England (4-4-2): Seaman; Neville (Dyer, h-t), Keown, Adams, Le Saux (Barry, 77min); Beckham (Parlour, 82), Southgate, Scholes, Barmby; Cole, Owen.

Germany (3-5-1-1): Kahn; Rehmer, Nowotny, Linke; Deisler, Ramelow, Hamann, Ballack, Bode (Ziege, 86); Scholl; Bierhoff.

Referee: S Braschi (Italy).

fields.headline: Litmanen the next danger
fields.standfirst:
Greece 1- 0 Finland
Lymperopoulos 59
fields.trailText: Finland warmed up for England's visit with a somewhat unfortunate defeat at the hands of Greece in the sodden Olympic stadium, but the message for Howard Wilkinson as he prepares for Wednesday is "beware Jari Litmanen".
fields.body:
Finland warmed up for England's visit with a somewhat unfortunate defeat at the hands of Greece in the sodden Olympic stadium, but the message for Howard Wilkinson as he prepares for Wednesday is "beware Jari Litmanen".

The 29-year-old Finnish striker, on the transfer list at Barcelona, played as a deep-lying forward and was at the heart of everything the visitors threw at Greece, the problem being that his less astute team-mates often failed to read his intentions quickly enough.

Thus Greece move into second place in Group Nine behind Germany and level with Finland on three points. The goal that did the trick, however, came just as they were beginning to show signs of frustration, Nikos Lymperopoulos spotting the goalkeeper Antti Niemi off his line and chipping in from the edge of the area.

The Greeks had dominated an entertaining first half, with Grigoris Georgatos firing in several testing crosses from the left flank and his Olympiakos club-mate Lambros Houtos hitting a post and twice having fine shots saved by Niemi.

Finland, who began their qualifying campaign with a 2-1 home win against Albania last month, almost snatched the lead five minutes before half-time when Litmanen played in Charlton's Jonatan Johansson, who was thwarted by two defenders. And Shefki Kuqi, who replaced Johansson, missed their best chance to equalise, his header from two yards sailing over the crossbar.

Greece : Nikopolidis; Amanatidis, Ouzounidis, Lymperopoulos, Georgiadis, Georgatos (Venetidis, 72min), Karagounis (Lakis, 76), Patsatzoglou, Zagorakis, Basinas, Houtos (Antzas, 81).

Finland : Niemi; Helin, Reini, Hyypia, Tihinen, Nurmela, Jarkko (Kottila, 81), Valakari, Johansson (Kuqi, 63), Litmanen, Kolkka (Forssell, h-t).

Referee : P Collina (Italy).

webTitle: 'I'm just not the man for this job'

fields.headline: 'I'm just not the man for this job'
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan broke the news to Sky's Claire Tomlinson. This is an edited transcript
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan broke the news to Sky's Claire Tomlinson. This is an edited transcript

CT: Kevin, you've been in a meeting for a long time with some high-ranking FA officials. What can you tell us?

KK: I've first of all told the players that it's my last game. I'm very disappointed with the result, not for myself but for the players, for all my staff and for the FA. I've probably had a longer run than I could have expected. After Euro 2000 a lot of coaches who did a lot better than me fell by the wayside.

I just don't feel I can find that little bit of extra that you need at this level to find a winning formula. I want to spend some time with my family. I feel I've given it my best shot.

I don't want to outstay my welcome. I think the fans today made me realise they feel it's time for me to go. That's where the power should be.

The FA have been great. I've had more support than any manager could have had. But I've not been quite good enough.

CT: Whose decision has it been? Has it come from you?

KK: 1,000%. Please don't think anyone has put a gun to my head. Far from it. I've always been a man who knows when the time's right. And I feel that's where I am now.

CT : The timing is interesting though, Kevin, four days before the next big qualifier. Have the FA tried to get you to stay for that game?

KK: Yes they did but I feel I would be doing it for the wrong reasons. I know it's not great timing, but there's never a good time. It's not what I wanted but I look forward now to a life outside of football, I think.

CT: Did you think this morning that if you lost you would offer your resignation?

KK: Yeah, it went through my mind. But I think I've had more than a fair chance. I've absolutely no complaints. I'm just not the man for this job. I'd only be cheating myself to carry on.

webTitle: Midwife crisis over hours and workload

fields.headline: Midwife crisis over hours and workload
fields.standfirst: Government hopes to improve numbers hit by vicious circle as pressure of extra work means more midwives are becoming dissatisfied and quitting
fields.trailText: A serious shortage of midwives is depriving women of one to one care and pushing up the rate of caesarian sections and other medical interventions.
fields.body:
A serious shortage of midwives is depriving women of one to one care and pushing up the rate of caesarian sections and other medical interventions.

Long hours, low morale and intense pressure in under-staffed NHS maternity units is causing more midwives to consider leaving. This has created a vicious circle, which promises from the government about increases in midwife numbers have as yet been unable to break.

"Midwives don't want to work within the system," said Frances Day-Stirk, director of midwifery affairs for the Royal College of Midwives. "They feel unable to give the standard of care they want to, and so they vote with their feet.

"We know that midwife care is cost-effective and that with one to one support women have far higher chances of a spontaneous birth and shorter labour," she said.

The college says that its research confirmed the vicious circle of midwives, unable to give women one to one care because of shortages, becoming dissatisfied and leaving in turn.

A study from the English national board for nursing, midwifery and health visiting shows that there is a direct correlation between midwife shortages and medical interventions in childbirth.

Their figures comparing 1996, 1998 and 1999, show an alarming drop in the number of deliveries by a midwife rather than an obstetrician, from 72.3% to 71. 25% two years ago and down to 68.8% last year. Over that period, caesarian sections rose from 15.8% of births in 1996 to 18.1% in 1998 and 18.9% last year.

In 27 of the 233 maternity units from which the board collected data, there are less than 1,000 deliveries a year. The outcomes from these smaller, midwife-led units are quite different from the rest, says the report. "Rates of midwives' deliveries and home birth rates are higher, while caesarian sections are lower."

The government has acknowledged that there are problems and promised an extra 20,000 nurses and midwives in the NHS national plan published in July. But there is a problem with retention.

A lot of midwives leave in their first year after completing training. Others go when they have children of their own and find the hours too long and inflexible. Out of 5,744 midwives working in the NHS in March this year, 550 had joined in the last year but 531 had left, resulting in a net gain of just 19, or 0.3%.

A long-running and damaging dispute over grading appears to have been resolved, with a commitment in the national plan to put them on at least grade F. Most midwives earn somewhere between £15,920, which is the bottom of grade E and £21,635 which is the top of grade F.

But hours are still a serious cause of discontent. Many midwives are now called in during the night not because one of their clients is in labour but because of staff shortages on the ward. The overnight on-call payment is just £5.95 an hour, and some are offered time off instead, which because of shortages they are unable to take.

The college says that its research confirmed the vicious circle of midwives, unable to give women one to one care because of shortages, becoming dissatisfied and leaving in turn. A study from the English national board for nursing, midwifery and health visiting shows that there is a direct correlation between midwife shortages and medical interventions in childbirth. Their figures comparing 1996, 1998 and 1999, show an alarming drop in the number of deliveries by a midwife rather than an obstetrician, from 72.3% to 71. 25% two years ago and down to 68.8% last year. Over that period, caesarian sections rose from 15.8% of births in 1996 to 18.1% in 1998 and 18.9% last year. In 27 of the 233 maternity units from which the board collected data, there are less than 1,000 deliveries a year. The outcomes from these smaller, midwife-led units are quite different from the rest, says the report. "Rates of midwives' deliveries and home birth rates are higher, while caesarian sections are lower." The government has acknowledged that there are problems and promised an extra 20,000 nurses and midwives in the NHS national plan published in July. But there is a problem with retention. A lot of midwives leave in their first year after completing training. Others go when they have children of their own and find the hours too long and inflexible. Out of 5,744 midwives working in the NHS in March this year, 550 had joined in the last year but 531 had left, resulting in a net gain of just 19, or 0.3%. A long-running and damaging dispute over grading appears to have been resolved, with a commitment in the national plan to put them on at least grade F. Most midwives earn somewhere between £15,920, which is the bottom of grade E and £21,635 which is the top of grade F. But hours are still a serious cause of discontent. Many midwives are now called in during the night not because one of their clients is in labour but because of staff shortages on the ward. The overnight on-call payment is just £5.95 an hour, and some are offered time off instead, which because of shortages they are unable to take.

fields.headline: Middle East press review
fields.standfirst: What the region's papers say about the latest outbreak of fighting between Israel and the Palestinians
fields.trailText: What the region's papers say about the latest outbreak of fighting between Israel and the Palestinians.
fields.body:
'The Orwellian attempt to paint Israel as an aggressor'
"As serious as events of the past week were, yesterday witnessed a further Arab escalation: Hizbullah attacked Israeli positions with missiles and kidnapped three soldiers, and a Palestinian mob ransacked Joseph's Tomb Both were acts of naked aggression and utter betrayals of solemn agreements. Both challenge the international community to come to Israel's defence and see through the Orwellian attempt to paint the most conciliatory Israeli government in history as an aggressor.

"Israel has done what it can and more to test the theory that maximum generosity will bring peace. Whether or not the US has deemed the theory to have failed, now is the time for America to fulfil its end of the bargain and unequivocally come to Israel's moral defence. Anything less will invite the attack to continue and intensify, and force Israel to take more drastic action in self-defence."
Jerusalem Post leader comment

'Jewish repentance will not bring peace'
"Even if we concede that [Israeli rightwinger Ariel] Sharon's act was ill-advised and politically motivated, both supporters and sceptics of the Middle East peace process are still left with a daunting question: If the reaction of Israel's peace partners to any assertion of the incontrovertible Jewish historical ties to Jerusalem and the Temple Mount are so extreme, what hope is there, then, for an end to the conflict?

"Conflicts about borders are susceptible to resolution. Disputes about history and legitimacy are not so easy. If the Arab-Israeli conflict is still about the latter, as recent events seem to indicate, then all of the Jewish repentance and willingness to make further concessions on Israel's rights and dignity will ultimately not bring peace."
Jerusalem Post columnist Jonathan S Tobin

'The ultimate test for Barak'
"This is the ultimate test of leadership for Barak He can win an immediate but short-lived popularity by resorting to the quick use of force, declaring the Oslo Accords dead, and forming a coalition of national unity. This is the easy way, but it is not the wisest

"This is not the time to form a government of hardliners, like Ariel Sharon, who created the mess of unneeded settlements in places not vital for our security and presses for the annulment of the peace process. This is the time for a government that includes only the forces that really want to advance the goal of peace, against all aspects of extremism."
Jerusalem Post columnist Daniel Bloch

'Permission to kill'
"Permission to kill has become 'self-evident' even when it comes to defending the thorn-in-the-side settlement of Netzarim. It is permissible to kill a child in the arms of his father and to afterward deny that killing 'because he had no reason to be there'. It is permissible to shoot missiles at demonstrators, because at stake is not just defence of the state or its citizens, but a 'principle': one does not surrender to violence. It is permissible to use violence to make others surrender. And as usual, in summing up the entire event, human life is important only when the human is not Arab.

"This war is being waged by the government of Prime Minister Ehud Barak, 'our' government, of 'the left'. And so, for the sake of peace of course, since after all everything is for the sake of peace, everything is permitted."
Ha'aretz columnist Yitzhak Laor

'The drums of war beat only in Israel'
"All over the Arab world, voices are calling for calm The only drums of war we heard still beating last night were those in Israel.

"If we measure the events of the past week, beginning with the visit of that master of bloodshed and terror, Ariel Sharon, to Al Haram Al Sharif, and culminating with Israeli threats to bomb the region into the dark ages at the behest of a 'national emergency government' that will have neither the foresight nor desire to salvage peace, we might be led to believe that Israel is deliberate in its effort to torpedo the peace process."
Jordan Times leader comment

'Palestinians are not considered people'
"As Serbs stormed and torched their parliament in an outburst of violence encouraged and cheered on by the Western powers, US President Clinton proclaimed: 'The United States stands with people everywhere who are fighting for their freedom.'

"It would, of course, be wonderful if this were true, but, as with every other principle which Americans purport to hold dear, Palestinians, who have also been fighting for their freedom in recent days (at far greater human cost), are a glaring exception. It seems that, in American eyes, Palestinians are not considered 'people.'
John Whitbeck in the Jordan Times

'The peace deal is now done'
"I think this peace deal is done; that "fruition" is relative and that even if the sides do not sign a final-status agreement before President Clinton leaves the White House, they have, essentially, already made their peace. Life is now in the details.

"The extent of de facto normalcy that has crept into the lives of Israelis and Palestinians since the start of Oslo is extraordinary. It has trickled down, almost against the will of the sides [and] to say that the alternative to a successful and complete culmination of the peace process is another intifada [uprising], a regression to the black days of closed schools and shops and daily casualties on the firing line, is not the case. There are too many factors mitigating against it."
Jerusalem Report columnist Hirsch Goodman

fields.headline: Holland prunes the Portuguese
fields.standfirst:
Portugal 1 - 1 Republic of Ireland
Sergio Conceicao 57, Holland 72
fields.trailText: In the precarious world of national team management Mick McCarthy's stock continues to soar while others lurch into free-fall. They may both be Yorkshire miners' sons but all similarities with Kevin Keegan ended on Saturday.
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor  at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
In the precarious world of national team management Mick McCarthy's stock continues to soar while others lurch into free-fall. They may both be Yorkshire miners' sons but all similarities with Kevin Keegan ended on Saturday.

It is only now, after a tough beginning and five years in the job, after clambering to heady, previously unexplored heights against two of Euro 2000's semi-finalists, that McCarthy no longer need fret about exposing his back for fear of having a dagger plunged between the shoulder blades. To emerge from the Estadio da Luz and Amsterdam Arena with draws has rejuvenated the Republic's faltering reputation as intrepid travellers and done wonders for the credibility of their durable former stopper.

McCarthy has been around long enough to know this result will mean nothing unless they beat Estonia on Wednesday and it remains a gnawingly awkward fact that his players have a talent for making life unnecessarily difficult for themselves. Yet two games into Group Two and the Irish have done enough so far to harbour genuine hopes of reaching Japan and Korea.

McCarthy has moulded a team incorporating two or three players of exceptional talent and, more crucially, others of lesser quality who are performing to their maximum. "People have criticised me but I'm not looking for their vindication," he said. "I know I'm doing a good job."

Certainly the Irish should feel positively invigorated after these getting-to-know-you stages with the two group favourites, even though they are languishing somewhat incongruously as the fifth-placed team in a group of six. Their next four games pit them against Estonia, Cyprus and Andorra twice and if they can avoid going belly up on those banana skins the initiative will be theirs approaching the final round of matches, with four of the last five games to be played at Lansdowne Road.

If the Portuguese made a fatal error it was indulging in their own showboating once Sergio Conceicao had fashioned a 56th-minute lead, tucking a wicked left-foot drive inside Alan Kelly's far post. Until then they had been the superior team, as one would expect on a ground where they had conceded only one goal in nigh on 10 years.

But they were to pay for their pomposity when Ipswich's Matt Holland, surely one of the Premiership's most under-rated players, collected a short pass from Roy Keane in the 73rd minute, steadied himself with a couple of touches and let fly from nearly 30 yards.

The Irish stretched every sinew, drew on every reserve and skipped off the pitch in a back-slapping scrum, leaving the Portugal coach Antonio Oliveira exclaiming: "What a unit."

Portugal (4-4-1-1): Quim; Beto, Couto, Jorge Costa, Dimas (Capucho, 88min); Sergio Conceicao (Pauleta, 76), Rui Costa, Vidigal, Figo; Joao Pinto; Sa Pinto (Simao, 76).

Republic of Ireland (4-4-2): Kelly; Carr, Breen, Dunne, Harte; McAteer (Duff, 68), Kinsella, Roy Keane, Kilbane; N Quinn (Holland, h-t), Robbie Keane (Finnan, 83).

Referee: A Ouzounov (Bulgaria).

fields.headline: Subvertise, don't advertise
fields.standfirst: Duncan Campbell  on the man who wants to de-swoosh America.
fields.trailText: Duncan Campbe on the man who wants to de-swoosh America.
fields.body:
It carries some of the most striking visual images of any magazine in the world, it was founded by an Estonian who has worked for the Australian defence department, it is based on the Pacific coast of Canada and perhaps no publication could claim to be more in tune with the current international campaign against corporatism and globalisation.

It is Adbusters, the "journal of the mental environment", and from its exquisitely executed covers to the call for cultural revolution at the end of the magazine it is now, in the wake of Prague and Seattle, attracting admirers and readers from all sides of the political arena. Next month it will be encouraging the world to take part in a Buy Nothing Day and this month it is running a "creative resistance contest" to encourage worldwide cultural rebellion. Its ideas come from the French Situationists and from Marshal McLuhan but its concepts and execution are very much twenty-first century.

The manifesto at the back of the bi-monthly explains who is behind the publication: "We are a loose global network of artists, writers, environmentalists, ecological econo mists, media-literacy teachers, reborn lefties, ecofeminists, downshifters, high-school shit-disturbers, campus rabble-rousers, incorrigibles, malcontents and green entrepreneurs . . . We believe that culture jamming will become to our era what civil rights was to the 60s, feminism to the 70s, and environmental activism to the 80s . . . Above all, it will change the way we interact with the mass media and the way in which meaning is produced in our society."

Adbusters was actually born more than 10 years ago, but it is only since the events of Seattle last year which led up to the demonstrations in Prague this year that it has suddenly started to break through to a much wider audience. Articles in its latest edition cover everything from the marketing of the American elections to a story about McDonald's in Lebanon, from a polemic on anarchism to news of what "culture jammers" have been up to in Japan.

Its founder and editor-in-chief is 58-year-old Kalle Lasn, who left Estonia as a two-year-old, and grew up in Australia where he worked for the defence department before moving first to Tokyo where he was in market research and then to Canada. There he became an award- winning documentary film-maker before founding Adbusters, which was driven by his increasing disillusionment with the corporatisation of the world and the failure of conventional left politics to combat it. His philosophy is contained in the book Culture Jam, the Uncooling of America, where the list of dedications includes "My mortal enemy, Philip Morris Inc which I vow to take down."

Lasn believes that the mass media now dispense a form of the "soma" that Aldous Huxley predicted in Brave New World: "The most powerful narcotic in the world is the promise of belonging. And belonging is best achieved by conforming to the prescriptions of America." In response, Lasn and his colleagues have set themselves the task of "unswooshing America" and "jamming its image factory until it comes to a sudden, shuddering halt". Adbusters is effectively the bulletin of that movement.

Lasn estimates that we receive around 3,000 marketing messages in an average day, from the logos on people's clothes to the billboards or posters we pass, to the commercials on our televisions and the ads in our daily papers or the signs in our super markets; some research puts the figure even higher. Adbusters' aim is to start to reverse the process.

"At the beginning, I did feel we were talking to the converted," says Lasn, "but all of a sudden there is a well-spring of interest." Initially, Adbusters was produced on newsprint and had only a small if loyal following, but it now sells 100,000 copies worldwide, mainly in the US, but also throughout Australia and New Zealand and with around 2,000 subscribers in the UK. Its small team of journalists, based in Vancouver, are mainly in their 20s and 30s.

Lasn attributes the recent attention to the whole post-Seattle effect and certainly many of the ideas which come into the magazine and its website have the subversive message of the loose movement that has emerged since then and been seen on the streets of Washington, Philadelpia, Los Angeles and Prague. He sees the growth of a global anxiety that the magazine taps into. "There is a messy feeling that things aren't quite right." Essentially he sees the magazine as a player in the epic battle between corporate culture and civic culture - "a people-driven planet earth or a corporate-driven planet inc".

And for all the playful nature of the publication, Lasn and his colleagues are quite serious. As he put it in Culture Jam: "Instead of treating vegetative, corporate-driven TV culture as something to be gently, ironically mocked, it's time to face the whole ugly spectre of our TV-addicted nation, the savage anomie of a society entranced and entrapped and living a lie. It's time to admit that chronic TV watching is North America's number-one mental health problem and that a society in which citizens spend a quarter of their waking lives (more than four hours a day) in front of their sets is in serious need of shock therapy."

If you watch people flipping through Adbusters in a bookstore or newsagents, you can often sense the slight puzzlement on their faces. Is this ad for Absolut Vodka for real? Is this two-page photo-spread of an elderly man asking "How can I die with dignity?" an invitation to a website about dying?

This is part of the magazine's intent, a desire to challenge the persuasion industry, to subvert the meaning in the message and to encourage people to become "culture jammers", taking on the corporations at their own game. "Corporations advertise and culture jammers subvertise", is one of their credos. Adbusters does take ads itself and will run "advocacy advertisements", such as either pro- or anti-abortion, but it reserves the right to vet every other kind of ad which means that most that do appear are mainly for books and CDs, rather than for, say, cars and alcohol.

Some of the visuals are subversions of well-known ads but although all the likely suspects - Nike, McDonald's, Coca-Cola and Walt Disney - have been lampooned, only one has sued: "Absolut Vodka came after us with a horde of lawyers, but we beat them back quite handsomely. They got scared and ran away with their tail between their legs. We have quite consciously provoked people like Nike and McDonald's - they haven't sued but they do subscribe." Lasn ran into problems, however, when he tried to advertise his Buy Nothing Day on television. All the major networks refused to run the commercials and CNN only agreed after being hounded by a reporter from the Wall Street Journal.

But Adbusters remains optimistic. If not culture jam today, then certainly culture jam tomorrow.

fields.headline: DFGW gears up for £12m Tacuma task
fields.trailText: 8am:Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters has created a new £12m pan-European campaign to launch Daewoo's new model, the Tacuma, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters has created a new £12m pan-European campaign to launch Daewoo's new model, the Tacuma.

The agency won the business at the beginning of the summer in a competitive pitch against other European agencies.

The 40 and 30-second commercials were shot as three separate films then spliced together to form one entire car on a split-screen. Various everyday family scenarios along with contrasting locations including a cloudy city, a rainy countryside and the beach aim to demonstrate the versatility of the Tacuma and how it was designed around all the family's needs.

fields.body:
Miles Saltiel is a director of WestLB Panmure, WestDeutsche Landesbank's investment banking arm. He is co-head of European technology research and responsible for the group's equity strategy and internet coverage.

As an undergraduate in Oxford, Mr Saltiel read politics, philosophy and economics before writing a Master's dissertation on Japanese business and government at Sussex university. He has worked in technology since 1979 when he joined GEC-Marconi.

Since 1986, he has worked in investment banking, joining the WestLB Group in 1996 to become head of equity research at West Merchant Bank. He took up his current role in 1998.

fields.headline: Live but not Kicking
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: BBC1's revamped Saturday morning children's show, Live and Kicking, opened with more of a whimper than a bang, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC1's revamped flagship Saturday morning children's show, Live and Kicking, opened with more of a whimper than a bang against ITV's SM:TV Live and CD:UK.

Live and Kicking returned with 1.3m/19.5% share between 9.15am and 12.10pm on Saturday; while on ITV from 9.25am SM:TV took 2.5m/39% and CD:UK averaged 2.5m/37% from 10.15am-12.30pm, according to unofficial overnights.

BBC1 received another ratings drubbing on Sunday night, with the inaugural People's Awards (5.5m/22%, 7-8.30pm) losing out to Kids Say the Funniest Things (9.1m/40%), Coronation Street (14m/56%) and Who Wants to be a Millionaire? (14.9m/56%).

From 9pm last night, the concluding part of ITV's Ray Winstone drama, Tough Love (8.3m/37%), beat BBC1 Steven Mackintosh drama Care (4.1m/19%), which tackled child abuse in local authority homes.

ITV's strong ratings throughout Sunday evening were reflected in a peak time (7-10.30pm) share of 40.3%; against a BBC1 figure of 23%. But on Saturday night the roles were reversed, with BBC1 averaging 35.1% in peak time and ITV managing only 29.6%.

BBC1's Saturday ratings victory was build around solid performances from Casualty (9.3m/40%, 8.10-9pm) and Forrest Gump. The repeated movie ran either side of the 10pm BBC News & Sport (7.9m/38%), averaging 7.7m/34% from 9pm, and 7.7m/43% after 10.15pm.

Earlier on Saturday highlights of England's dreary Wembley finale drew a suitably downbeat audience to ITV (4.6m/26%, 5.25-6.25pm), losing out to an Only Fools and Horses repeat (5.8m/32%) and Jim Davidson's Generation Game (6.9m/36%) on BBC1.

Channel 5 served up a double-header of live international soccer the same evening, with San Marino v Scotland (1.4m/6%) from 6.25pm and Portugal v Ireland (1.3m/6%) taking over between 8.50-11.05pm. After that, Late Night with Jerry Springer (0.5m/4%) made a disappointing debut on Channel 5, 11.05-11.45pm.

The following night the channel's late evening line-up performed more impressively, with movie Beverly Hills Ninja (2.3m/10%, 9-10.35pm) and documentary Murder Detectives (1.9m/15%, 10.35-11.40pm).

On Friday night, new BBC1 comedy drama Brotherly Love (5m/22%) opened poorly at 8.30pm.
