webTitle: Five more die as Israel's deadline approaches

fields.headline: Five more die as Israel's deadline approaches
fields.trailText: Five more die as Israel's deadline approaches.
fields.body:
Fighting in Israel and the West Bank today claimed five more lives as Israel's deadline to the Palestinians to end the violence or face "forceful action" drew closer by the hour.

Two Palestinians were killed today in Nazareth after police fired rubber bullets into a rioting crowd. Overnight one Palestinian was found shot dead, another was found beaten to death and an Israeli settler was found shot dead in a cave near Nablus.

The dead are the latest casualties of the conflict that erupted after Ariel Sharon, leader of the Likud party, staged a provocative visit to a Muslim shrine at the heart of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, has warned he will use "all means" at his disposal if Palestinian violence does not stop by Monday night, the end of the Jewish Yom Kippur holiday.

World leaders have stepped up their efforts to stem the crisis. The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, still held out the possibility of a leadership summit and the UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan, and the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, are due to arrive this evening to confer with Mr Barak and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.

Mr Arafat, returning from a meeting with the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, said he would limit his talks with Mr Annan to Palestinian demands for an international inquiry into the recent events. Eighty eight people, most of them Palestinians and Arab Israelis, have died since the fighting began 12 days ago.

The UN security council has called for an "objective inquiry", but stopped short of the Palestinian leader's demand for an international commission. Israel has rejected both calls.

Israeli officials were unavailable for comment, observing Yom Kippur, the day of atonement, until Monday evening. After that, Mr Barak is due to meet with Mr Annan and Mr Ivanov to assess Mr Arafat's compliance.

Israeli officials have threatened to go on to an offensive footing - perhaps even attacking Palestinian headquarters - if Mr Arafat did not announce a ceasefire. Palestinians dismissed the ultimatum as "insulting".

fields.headline: Gap,  Next, and  Top Man
fields.trailText: KOO-GONE
fields.body:
KOO-GONE

Five o'clock on Saturday afternoon, and England manager Kelvin Koogan had failed to appear for the round of post-match interviews. By ten past, he'd been joined in a dispirited dressing room by FA chief executive Adam Crozier and FA not-sure-what-he-actually-does David Davies. Many were confused, but the Fiver immediately knew what was going on: a piqued Koog had obviously brained David Beckham with a misdirected flying teacup, and the supportive Crozier and Davies were helping him out of a sticky spot by bundling the late midfielder's cold corpse into a kit basket and dumping it on the back of the German bus.

But if we're being brutally frank, we misread the situation. In actual fact, Koogan was handing in his resignation, a process which involved much soul searching, some heated debate and a bit of snivelling in the toilets. By half five, Koog had announced he was "a little short" at international level - as if his head ever troubled the dugout ceiling at Craven Cottage - and England were looking for a new manager. And before you could say "Bryan", "Robson" or "you must be bloody joking", the race was on.

Sadly for the FA, the race was to see who could rule themselves out of the running first. "I have only been here four months and I owe it to the players to see it out," said Leicester boss Peter Taylor, former manager of England Under-21s and massive mates with Howard Wilkinson. "Some of them have signed long contracts because of me and some have come here because of me. I love it here and I want to put and end to the speculation."

France's World Cup-winning coach Aime Jacquet wasn't showing much interest either: "At the French Federation, I lead and I am pursuing passionate work with the coaches. That is fully sufficient for me." Meanwhile, jug-eared Sunderland boss Peter Reid - the name on nobody's lips - was swiftly removed from the reckoning by his chairman. "Peter is dedicated to Sunderland and respects and values the autonomy of his position at the club," thundered Bob Murray, unfortunately making Reid sound like a despotic maniac.

One figure who hasn't yet been ruled out for sure is Uncle Tom Cobleigh, but he was unavailable for comment at the time of writing. Another is Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger. The Gunners are prepared to give the FA permission to speak to their manager, but only because cocky chairman Peter Hill-Wood is sure Wenger will turn down any offer the FA make: "He wouldn't say yes to the job. He would be crazy to take it. And Arsene Wenger is not crazy - he is far too sensible." You should have mentioned that Wenger is competent as well, Peter - that would have definitely ruled him out.

WHO NEXT? - THE CHOICE IS YOURS, SO TELL IT LIKE IT IS, THE WAY YOU SEE IT

Who do you want the next England boss to be? Given that bosses with proven motivational skills are now out of fashion, our vote goes to John Gregory, who can de-motivate with the best of them. Failing that, McCaff would be as good a choice as any.

But don't let the Fiver influence you. Email your suggestions to the.boss@theguardian.com along with a bit of ill-thought-through reasoning. Give your email the subject heading 'Don't get me wrong, lovely bloke, but thank eff for that' and we'll publish the best tomorrow.

FINN GOD WE TRUST

We all want things to work out nicely for Howard Wilkinson, don't we? Well, fair point, but this time you're going to have to - he's in charge for England's match against Finland on Wednesday afternoon. And as he's got a massive injury crisis on his hands, he doesn't need any grief from you.

Tony Adams and Graeme Le Saux were today ruled out of the match nobody will see because: a) it's on while everyone is still at work; and b) it's on some ropey digital channel or other. Adams injured his back - surprise! - in a Bisham Abbey training session this morning, while Le Saux failed a fitness test on his calf.

Adams and Le Saux join David Beckham and Steven Gerrard on the sidelines, and that's a fair bit of talent to be without. The Fiver refuses to be despondent, however. Andy Cole and Paul Scholes have, unlike Le Saux, recovered from knocks taken on Saturday, and let's not forget the recall of in-form striker Teddy Sheringham.

Not only that, Gary Neville's toe injury has cleared up, so he can play as well! OK, we've said too much.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We could not contemplate Bobby Robson's release, neither in the short nor long term. He is under contract to Newcastle United and that is the end of it" - Newcastle chairman Freddy Shepherd in amazing no-PR-disaster statement shock.

KOOGAN'S RUN: A FIVER HISTORY

We don't want to say we told you so, but we told you so. After England beat Poland 3-1 in Koog's opening match, the entire nation went wild... but only the Fiver, standing awkwardly in the corner, dared to offer a different analysis: "The Fiver has noticed a bandwagon rolling straight towards a wall marked 'disaster'. The Fiver would like to offer its own gift to the nation, with its Keep-a-Koog-at-Fulham campaign. So if you're in the minority and think that nothing in this world could be worse than Koogan as full-time England manager, email us now."

Many of you wrote in to support our campaign. But did anyone listen? Did they feck. However, the Fiver was magnanimous: "We would like to perform a graceful volte-face and wish the England coach the best of luck. Until, that is, failure to qualify for Euro 2000 ends with Koogan being unceremoniously sacked and denounced as the fraud that he is."

For months we kept quiet. When Koog sat slumped pathetically over a microphone after a home defeat against Scotland, and tried to raise our spirits ahead of Euro 2000 by saying "I know you'll laugh, but we have a chance to win it", we said nothing. Apart from "Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha. Ha, ha, ha, ha. Ha." And when England skittered uselessly out of Euro 2000, we offered only rational analysis: "If it wasn't for a slightly fortuitous win against Germany, a foaming, flapping Kelvin Koogan would probably have offered his resignation by now. And Bryan Robson would have probably been rolled in to replace him. Perhaps that's why the hardened tabloid hacks decided to give Koog a strangely easy ride earlier today."

But now it's over, and we can't keep quiet any longer. The Fiver - alongside you, dear reader - was right all along. Get in there! Where does this smug feeling get us, we hear you ask? Well, we'll tell you. Erm...

THE RUMOUR MILL

Danish goalkeeper Jesper Christiansen has arrived at Manchester United for a three-day trial with a view to a permanent £2.5m move.

Aston Villa are lining up a move for Steve Staunton, who has been given a free transfer by Liverpool.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Bayer Leverkusen coach Christoph Daum has agreed to supply urine, blood and hair samples for tests in order to prove he has never taken cocaine. The samples will be sent to an independent laboratory in Cologne and the results will be available in about four weeks.

Joe Royle has played down reports that George Weah has left Manchester City. "We have had a chat, but everything has calmed down," said Royle. "George was just a bit upset but we've gone through it together and he's fine."

He Was He Is Emmanuel Petit has claimed that top players could be forced to take drugs simply to maintain their match fitness because of football's overcrowded calendar. "I don't want drug taking to become commonplace in my sport," Petit told French daily Le Parisien. "Unfortunately, we are heading in that direction. I have not had a single day's rest for two months. No athlete can repeat a maximum effort every three days."

Uefa have suspended two Romanian officials for one year after it was revealed that they offered a referee "female company" prior to an Intertoto Cup match earlier this season.

Red Star Belgrade have been fined £15,000 for their supporters' unruly behaviour during the Euro-Vase defeat of Leicester in Vienna last month.

Aston Villa's England U-21 international striker Darius Vassell has signed a new four-year contract that ties him to Villa Park until the summer of 2004.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (11.30pm) Previewing next week's preview of the return of Big Cup.

Football Extra (12.30am) Reviewing last weekend's Nationwide football, which is a much simpler concept.

Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 3am) If McCaff's not here, the programme will be fronted by a vacuous buffoon with a false grin and exaggerated Yorkshire accent. We're referring to Dave Clark, of course, not William Hague.

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5pm, 6.30pm SS1, 11pm SS1) Featuring better players than the ones you were forced to watch on Saturday. Better stadiums too.

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm) Ivor Broadis, which sounds like a music-hall joke but in fact is a chap who used to play for Carlisle, Sunderland, Manchester City and Newcastle.

British Eurosport: World Cup Football (5pm, 9.40pm) As if we need to bother with this any more.

Radio 5 Live: The Football World of Clem and Fischer (8pm) We've not heard this, but we assume it's pretty bad. So if anyone can back up our unfounded criticism with some hard facts, we'd be very grateful.

fields.headline: Economy of bits and pieces
fields.trailText: Don't get me wrong, I loathe being on the bandwagon, and cherish the contrary opinion as much as any Englishman. So had I been asked "Is there anything new in the new economy?" nine months ago, when the New Economy was being tipped to banish the Old Economy from this earth, I would have taken the opposite view from the one I am about to put forward. But that was then. Today, with stock-market valuations crashing, and the New Economy seemingly in flight, it is more important to make the opposite case. Here it is. By Geoffrey Moore.
fields.body:
Don't get me wrong, I loathe being on the bandwagon, and cherish the contrary opinion as much as any Englishman. So had I been asked "Is there anything new in the new economy?" nine months ago, when the New Economy was being tipped to banish the Old Economy from this earth, I would have taken the opposite view from the one I am about to put forward. But that was then. Today, with stock-market valuations crashing, and the New Economy seemingly in flight, it is more important to make the opposite case. Here it is.

A new economy is emerging that will fundamentally change the nature and structure of global business. It is based on a series of innovations built one on top of the other over the past decade or so, and now reaching a tipping point - a point of inflection beyond which change accelerates irreversibly to a new order.

Over the past decade, information technology has been increasingly used to allow customers and suppliers to work together to create more timely delivery of more custom-tailored offerings. The business processes have not changed, but while IT was previously largely confined to enhancing processes within a single corporation, it is now also being used to enhance inter-company processes. This effort began with client server systems, but was impeded by a host of technical difficulties. However, widespread use of the internet as an inter-company platform has effectively eliminated the bulk of these problems. We have already seen this in the hi-tech sector, telecommunications and financial services - the bellwethers of the new economies.

The most important difference in these new economies is that they favour virtual integration over vertical integration. That is, they favour assembling a customer offering from best-of-breed components integrated across companies, as opposed to the same offering delivered as an end-to-end solution from one company. This preference is not universal, but in sectors of the economy where massive changes are under way, the cost of a single company keeping up with all the technologies to supply all the components has become prohibitive, in terms of cost and time to market. Moreover, because of the advances in inter-company IT systems, it is feasible to pull together multiple vendors into a single, coordinated supply chain that delivers a complex product on time and within specifications. Under those conditions, the added value of best-of-breed component elements overshadows the integration value of a single provider.

Wherever virtual integration can supplant vertical integration, it will win the accolades of the capital markets. Investors want their money to go into activities that increase the company's differentiation, its competitive advantage, its raison d' tre for charging a premium for its offerings. That's what creates great returns and raises share price. To the degree that these offerings are diluted with components that are not core to the company, investors see their money going into something that will not create privileged returns and thus not impact on share price. So the best-of-breed providers leveraging the new IT get higher market valuations, giving them a lower cost of capital, as well as turning their shares into an acquisition currency. To be sure, the high-flying internet shares have shown that this idea can be abused, but companies such as Dell, Cisco, Microsoft and Intel - all of which supply components, not end-to-end solutions - have shown that the best-of-breed position can be very powerful.

The rewards the capital markets have lavished on such companies in the hi-tech sector has given rise to an industry structure made up of networks of inter-operating companies. Ideally, each company in the network contributes that element of the end solution that is core to its mission and talents and leaves everything non-core to some other company, for whom that same element is core. In this way, every company is earning the maximum returns for its shareholders by focusing its scarce resources on the activities that generate the most competitive advantage for it.

Finally, this networked economy has made itself even more dependent on IT systems to coordinate with customers and suppliers to create more timely delivery of more tailored offerings - so we are back where we started, initiating another cycle through this loop, recruiting more companies, expanding into adjacent sectors, reinforcing existing advantages, and creating new ones.

This cycle is well under way in certain sectors of the US economy, with strong prospects for going global and for gaining expansion into other sectors. Rapid widespread adoption of the internet will accelerate these changes. This will undermine the traditional, vertically integrated Fortune 500 corporation, and give rise to more granular, networked economic entities. We are leaving behind a world dominated by Tyrannosaurus Rex for a new one ruled by velociraptors. The flesh-eaters will still create the havoc, but they will come in a new package.

webTitle: Tabloids for sale, £200m ono. Two careless owners

fields.headline: Tabloids for sale, £200m ono. Two careless owners
fields.standfirst: United News & Media seems hellbent on selling off the Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star. But who will pay a small fortune for titles that make no money? By  Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: United News & Media seems hellbent on selling off the Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star. But who will pay a small fortune for titles that make no money? By Roy Greenslad.
fields.body:
After the months of speculation, denials, economies with the truth, bluffs and boasts, surely we are nearing the end of United News & Media's grip on the Daily Express. No one can be fooled any longer. The for-sale sign is up at Ludgate House: the Daily and Sunday Express and the Daily Star are available.

Companies that want to keep a business do not enter into serious talks with people wishing to buy it. They do not open their books for them. They do not, having received a bid, then suggest a sum that would satisfy them.

Nor, if they really wish to grow the business, do they allow it to dangle in limbo, showing the minimum of interest in its problems and undermining staff morale. When the time comes to assess the Express stewardship of United's chief executive Clive Hollick, this tawdry end to his reign will overshadow his sincere attempts to make it work at the beginning. Indeed, if Hollick doesn't sell soon at a reasonable price to buyers willing to take on Fleet Street's biggest basket case, he may well merit the dubious title of the worst proprietor in modern press history (and that includes Robert Maxwell).

Express Newspapers is the only media group that is going down in price with every passing year. Now the reason has become crystal clear. The papers don't make any money. Without revenue from the printing outfits, such as West Ferry, the company would be insolvent.

Over the years, stretching back through Hollick's time into the regime of David Stevens, the once mighty Beaverbrook empire has been disembowelled. Assets have been ruthlessly stripped so that the paper once published from Fleet Street's finest building now finds itself a tenant in its Blackfriars editorial base.

Absurdly, if cunningly, the papers' online manifestations have been detached to form a separate United division, Xilerate, which is not part of the sale. What the Barclay brothers are therefore trying to buy is just part of the entity that should form a newspaper group. No wonder their latest offer is so low. Does anyone seriously believe that the purchase price of a company with a turnover of £250m is going to reach £200m?

So let's try to make some sense out of this mess. Frederick and David Barclay, through their Press Holdings group and its publisher, Andrew Neil, have been trying to buy Express Newspapers for about 18 months. Other possible buyers, such as Trinity-Mirror and Independent Newspapers, have turned their backs on the idea. Since the Express titles do not make a profit, the monopolies problem would probably vanish, but neither has shown any real interest.

Mohamed Al Fayed has been mentioned as a potential bidder but there is a big question mark over whether he has the money, or the will, to match his supposed ambition.

Though Hollick is known to be furious about the public revelation of the Barclays' bid, because it contradicts all the official denials that the papers are not for sale, the publicity might just flush out other hopeful buyers. For the moment, though, the only game in town is being played by the Barclays. They have bid at least £75m, but it isn't their final offer: they will pay what the company is worth. By chance, they have a first-class idea about its current value. Obligingly for the Barclays and embarrassingly for Hollick, United's own broker, Merrill Lynch, has published a report suggesting it lies in the range of £74m to £105m.

If that is so, then United's board, if it wishes to satisfy the company's shareholders, should be entertaining the Barclays to lunch. The subsidised canteen has long gone, but the dining rooms on the top floor still turn out reasonable meals at £25 a head.

While United's directors ponder, Neil's team has asked United's merchant bank, Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, to explain why they should pay more. "It isn't a vanity purchase," says one of the Barclays' executives. "We will pay what it is worth."

Merrill Lynch, by the way, are not totally disinterested analysts. They own MAM, which is one of United's biggest shareholders. Doubtless United's forceful chairman, Sir Ronald Hampel, might be pointing that out to Hollick this week in a sharp reminder that investors are getting impatient. Hampel might also question the wisdom of Hollick having just authorised £2m to be spent on the hiring of 27 new advertising staff for the Express group. Is that the wisest initiative at this moment?

Meanwhile, the editorial side limps on with the minimum of resources. One of the eye-catching figures to emerge from the fray is the fact that the combined editorial budget for the three titles is £53m. Of that, it's thought that £41m is devoted to the Daily and Sunday Express. It sounds a reasonable sum to me, but compare it to the £85m enjoyed by the Daily Mail alone and it looks hopelessly inadequate.

I noted the Daily Express's recent front-page assault on the government over pensions was headlined "Peanuts" and wondered whether it was a subtle message from editor Rosie Boycott to Hollick about the failure to increase her editorial spend. She is known to be deeply unhappy about the turn of events last week. "I'll be extremely sad if the paper goes to the Barclays," she said, "because they'll be against all we've been trying to do here." Since she took control in April 1998, Boycott has transformed the Express's former Tory political agenda, first aligning it with Tony Blair's New Labour and then, of late, championing the cause of those who feel neglected by the government, such as pensioners and NHS patients.

While Hollick, a lifelong Labour supporter, has undoubtedly been pleased with the paper's politics in general, he has not been a hands-on proprietor in terms of content. He certainly had nothing to do with the recent attacks on Blair's policies, even though he was upset at the decision by trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers to back the competition commission's veto on his company's giant TV merger with Carlton.

Indeed, according to many Express journalists, it is Hollick's lack of attention to the paper that causes dismay. Why does he want it, they ask? Does he care? This is a reasonable point. If the papers aren't making money, there is no business reason for keeping them. If he doesn't use them to back his party, then there is no political reason for having them. There is pride, of course, but that generally comes before a fall.

Anyway, if Hollick were to sell to the Barclays in the end, would it be such a bad move? I can understand Boycott's concern for her own future and that of her politically committed staff. Neil is unlikely to share her view that the paper could make a profit by appealing to a supposed niche audience of a left-leaning lower middle class somewhere between the Guardian and Mirror readerships.

On the other hand, he cannot hope to go head to head with the Daily Mail on its traditional right-wing territory. Any such challenge would be met by the formidable resources of Associated Newspapers.

Neil is certainly not going to reveal his hand at present. If you don't own the train set, it's a waste of time worrying over new signalling equipment. He may have an editor in mind, though I suspect he doesn't, and reports that his successful Sunday Business editor Jeff Randall is being lined up for the job are wide of the mark.

Politics aside though, why the concern about Neil? Sure, he had an unhappy time failing to save the European from the dustbin of history, but who really thought it would ever work? He has come in for criticism over his editorial strategy and marketing of the Scotsman, but he didn't invent price-cutting and it appears to be working for him thus far.

Sunday Business has proved a huge success, and - let it be noted - its sale has remained above 50,000 despite his having doubled its cover price. Neil's 11-year editorship of the Sunday Times was anything but a disaster. Many experienced journalists on the paper, including those who disparaged his politics, came to admire his journalistic drive, ideas and attention to detail.

Express Newspapers have had two poor owners in succession. The titles are on their last legs, lying unloved and unwanted on a trolley in an underfunded hospital. If they are to have any hope of survival, they require a massive injection of resources and adrenaline. Dr Neil's cure might be painful and, in fairness, the patient might still die. But surely it's better to perish on the operating table than due to neglect?

fields.headline: Carlton in £400m bid for horseracing rights
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: Carlton Communications has bid £400m for broadcasting rights to UK horseracing, writeDan Milmo.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications is betting on the popularity of the interactive gambling market after bidding £400m for the broadcasting rights to UK horseracing.

Carlton, the key player in the ITV network alongside Granada Media, refused to confirm press reports of a bid, but an ITV source said the offer made sense.

"Carlton could do a lot of things for UK racecourses, and I am not surprised they are talking to each other. In order to cover racing, you need a channel, a subscriber service and interactive TV capabilities, and Carlton has all of them. The possibilities for interactive TV are very exciting," said the source.

Carlton's bid for internet, TV and interactive rights for 10 years would see profits split 50-50 between the company and the UK's 59 racecourses.

Carlton already has a pedigree for sports coverage, producing most of ITV's sports content and covering Premiership soccer matches for BSkyB with its outside broadcasting unit..

webTitle: Royles to star in PowerChannel ads

fields.headline: Royles lined up for PowerChannel push
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Banks Hoggins O'Shea/FCB is understood to have lined up stars from The Royle Family for the £5m launch task for PowerChannel, Jade Garrett reports.
fields.body:
Banks Hoggins O'Shea/FCB is understood to have picked up the £5m launch task for PowerChannel, Granada Broadband's television internet service, and is lining up stars from BBC1 sitcom The Royle Family to feature in its debut campaign.

The advertising, due to break shortly, will focus on the free distribution of up to 200,000 "net-top boxes", which can be plugged into viewers' TVs to provide full internet access and email.

Granada, which took a £13.5m stake in PowerChannel earlier this year, will be the net service provider for the channel, which will also incorporate all other programme websites.

Sven Olsen, managing director at Banks Hoggins, admitted that the agency was in talks with PowerChannel but was unable to comment further.

Granada Broadband marketing director Peter Nowlan confirmed he has been working with the agency.

fields.headline: Brown reforms lone parent aid
fields.standfirst: Government offers extra money, childcare places and employment flexibility to get people back to work
fields.trailText: The chancellor of the exchequer, Gordon Brown, will today launch a partnership between Whitehall and business to provide jobs for lone parents as the government declares its intent to make help for the family central to next year's Budget and a key dividing line in the forthcoming election.
fields.body:
The chancellor of the exchequer, Gordon Brown, will today launch a partnership between Whitehall and business to provide jobs for lone parents as the government declares its intent to make help for the family central to next year's Budget and a key dividing line in the forthcoming election.

Scorning Conservative plans to scrap Labour's tax breaks for the working poor in favour of a married couple's allowance, Mr Brown will unveil plans for extra money, additional childcare places and more flexible jobs to raise the proportion of lone parents in work to American levels.

"We want to see a sea change in the opportunities available to lone parents," he will say in Bristol at the launch of the Treasury's pre-budget report consultation period, which will lead to extra assistance for poorer families in next spring's Budget. "We want to give lone parents real choices, enabling them to move from welfare to work and out of poverty."

Five of Britain's leading firms - Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, Sainsbury, Direct Line and Granada - have agreed to be the trailblazers for the scheme designed to tempt lone parents back into the labour market with family-friendly working practices.

Government figures show that the number of lone parents on benefit fell from 1,015,000 to 910,000 in the three years from May 1997 to May 2000, raising the proportion in work from 43% to 50%. However, Mr Brown is concerned that this is still a much lower figure than in the US, where it is heading for 70%, and France, where it is 82%. The chancellor believes that getting lone parents back to work is the best way of tackling child poverty, where Britain's record is still one of the worst in the developed world.

As part of this drive, Mr Brown will today provide details of pilot schemes which allow lone parents to choose between education or training, working for less than 16 hours a week without losing all their benefits, or working longer hours and taking advantage of the working families tax credit, the earnings top-up for low income households. Mr Brown will confirm that the working families tax credit is to be made more generous and announce an advertising drive to encourage low-income workers to apply for it.

The government's labour market policies for the working poor will be praised today by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. The OECD says the working families tax credit and the new deal, programmes which the Conservatives have pledged to scrap, have been instrumental in attracting lone parents back into the market.

"Tens of thousands of lone parents in Britain find work worthwhile for the first time because of the working families tax credit," the OECD's director for employment, John Martin, will tell a conference in London on social exclusion.

The Conservative party's pledge to replace the tax credit with the old family credit benefit will cost 1m families nearly £25 a week, according to the chancellor. "Scrapping the working families tax credit and the new deal for lone parents would deny lone parents the choice of going out to work and would leave millions of children and their parents in poverty," Mr Brown will say today.

Mr Brown's aides made it clear yesterday that new measures for lone parents were high on the agenda for next month's pre-budget statement.

With the opposition making the traditional two parent family the centre-piece of its approach, the government is determined to show that its welfare reforms have delivered benefits to both one parent and two parent families.

As part of the government's campaign, the employment minister Margaret Hodge will today announce 1m extra childcare places will be available by 2004 as a result of a threefold increase in funds to over £200m.

Five of Britain's leading firms - Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, Sainsbury, Direct Line and Granada - have agreed to be the trailblazers for the scheme designed to tempt lone parents back into the labour market with family-friendly working practices. Government figures show that the number of lone parents on benefit fell from 1,015,000 to 910,000 in the three years from May 1997 to May 2000, raising the proportion in work from 43% to 50%. However, Mr Brown is concerned that this is still a much lower figure than in the US, where it is heading for 70%, and France, where it is 82%. The chancellor believes that getting lone parents back to work is the best way of tackling child poverty, where Britain's record is still one of the worst in the developed world. As part of this drive, Mr Brown will today provide details of pilot schemes which allow lone parents to choose between education or training, working for less than 16 hours a week without losing all their benefits, or working longer hours and taking advantage of the working families tax credit, the earnings top-up for low income households. Mr Brown will confirm that the working families tax credit is to be made more generous and announce an advertising drive to encourage low-income workers to apply for it. The government's labour market policies for the working poor will be praised today by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. The OECD says the working families tax credit and the new deal, programmes which the Conservatives have pledged to scrap, have been instrumental in attracting lone parents back into the market. "Tens of thousands of lone parents in Britain find work worthwhile for the first time because of the working families tax credit," the OECD's director for employment, John Martin, will tell a conference in London on social exclusion. The Conservative party's pledge to replace the tax credit with the old family credit benefit will cost 1m families nearly £25 a week, according to the chancellor. "Scrapping the working families tax credit and the new deal for lone parents would deny lone parents the choice of going out to work and would leave millions of children and their parents in poverty," Mr Brown will say today. Mr Brown's aides made it clear yesterday that new measures for lone parents were high on the agenda for next month's pre-budget statement. With the opposition making the traditional two parent family the centre-piece of its approach, the government is determined to show that its welfare reforms have delivered benefits to both one parent and two parent families. As part of the government's campaign, the employment minister Margaret Hodge will today announce 1m extra childcare places will be available by 2004 as a result of a threefold increase in funds to over £200m.

webTitle: Straw asked to scrap voucher plan

fields.headline: Straw asked to scrap voucher plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A Labour thinktank will this week call for the voucher system for asylum seekers to be scrapped and a human rights commission to be set up in a report to be launched by the home secretary, Jack Straw.
fields.body:
A Labour thinktank will this week call for the voucher system for asylum seekers to be scrapped and a human rights commission to be set up in a report to be launched by the home secretary, Jack Straw.

The commission on the future of multi-ethnic Britain, which included Labour peer, Lord Bhikhu Parekh, and Trevor Phillips, chairman of the Greater London assembly, is to call upon the government to declare Britain a multi-cultural society.

The commission, set up by the Runnymede Trust, says that Mr Straw's policies of dispersing asylum seekers and forcing them to live on below-the-breadline vouchers have created "statelessness and racial and ethnic divisions". It calls for them to be given cash support and for their rights to appeal against deportations to be restored.

Mr Straw is unlikely to concede these changes but the Home Office yesterday insisted that other proposals are under official consideration.

The Home Office minister, Mike O'Brien, said: "Many of the recommendations cover areas where action is in hand. Where there are new suggestions we will look at these."

Lord Parekh, the commission chairman, said one of the first steps should be a declaration that Britain is a multi-cultural society, as has happened in the US, Australia and Canada. "It is a way of saying to ethnic minorities and the world that we not only tolerate but cherish our diversity." He said it would not just be a formal statement but would mean that annual ceremonies such as Remembrance Day would begin to reflect the contribution of Britain's diverse communities.

The two-year study also calls for an independent investigation of complaints against the police, of all deaths in custody and for publicity campaigns to ensure the public know their rights if stopped and searched.

A major proposal is to set up a human rights commission and an equalities commission, which would involve the merger of the commission for racial equality, the equal opportunities commission and the disability rights commission. A single equality act would update the 1976 legislation on race and sex discrimination.

The report is also expected to recommend government-set targets for reducing the number of pupils from particular minority ethnic communities who are excluded from school.

It urges that national working parties be set up to evaluate the race equality impact of Ofsted inspections at schools and local authorities. Schools should also be given guidance on how subjects could be given an international and multicultural dimension.

 A trust set up by the late Labour MP Bernie Grant to promote racial justice and social development is to be launched at the Commons today.

webTitle: Online Classics' plans fail to impress City

fields.headline: Online Classics' plans get the thumbs down
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Online Classics has received the thumbs down from the stock market after announcing an acquisition and £8m share placing. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online Classics, the ballet-to-opera internet content provider, has received the thumbs down from the stock market after announcing an acquisition and £8m share placing.

The company's shares fell 15% to 71.5p, from 83.5p, following preliminary results revealing a pre-tax loss of £0.98m on turnover of £80,000. The AIM-listed company said the losses stemmed from flotation and website development costs.

Online Classics plans to buy production company Iambic Productions for £5m, although the purchase hinges on the success of the share placing of 13m shares at 60p per share.

Richard Price, chairman of Online Classics, said: "Online Classics' core strategic aim is to be a leading website for audio-visual performing arts content. The board believes that the future of arts broadcasting will be centred on the internet, as television and the internet converge.

"The proposed acquisition of Iambic Productions will bring a high-profile producer of performance arts programmes in-house, and the placing will help fund the expansion of the company into maturity."

Online Classics has so far secured performance rights deals with opera stars such as the three tenors, Jessye Norman and Montserrat Caballe. And it is planning a major marketing push to coincide with the spread of broadband internet access.

fields.headline: Stormin' Norman
fields.standfirst: In a new two-part documentary, Norman Mailer reviews his life, his work and America of the 20th century. He's fiery and unashamedly opinionated - and makes compelling viewing, says  Mark Lawson
fields.trailText: In a new two-part documentary, Norman Mailer reviews his life, his work and America of the 20th century. He's fiery and unashamedly opinionated - and makes compelling viewing, says Mark Lawson
fields.body:
In American television, the sections of a film in which the reporter addresses the camera directly are known as "stand-ups." (In Britain, PTC for piece-to-camera is preferred.) In a two-part documentary transmitting this week, the reporter's contributions are all sit-downs - slouched on a variety of chairs in houses and on porches - but this can be forgiven because the journalist in question is in his seventies and has undergone knee surgery.

And his pieces to camera are wiser and livelier than any stand-ups.

Storyville, shown on Wednesday and Thursday is Norman Mailer's report on his life, his novels and his nation. The programmes - made by Richard Copans and Stan Neumann - are built around lengthy interviews with the writer. You can guess how long the conversational process was by the rate at which Mailer changes locations and, above all, shirts. You sometimes feel that a subliminal leisurewear commercial is being screened. The author's opinions and reminiscences are split by archive film from American history and Mailer's own frequent appearances before the cameras.

Oh, My America belongs to the somewhat intermittent television genre of the authored documentary. Most associated with James Cameron and then John Pilger, these opinionated films have tended to trouble executives in Britain because of institutional and legal requirements for balance in reporting. Under Thatcherism, this tension about self-expression reached a peak at the BBC and it was Channel 4 - with Gore Vidal and then his intellectual heir Christopher Hitchens - which most explored the form. Even so, it's still noticeable that - with occasional expections such as Fergal Keane's Forgotten Britain - the sound-off projects tend to concentrate on foreign subjects, where the terror of bias is less.

But the success of authored documentaries inevitably depends on who the author is. And Norman Mailer was born for this format. The geographical size and political significance of America give its writers the weight of sages. It's very difficult for British novelists to be oracular: JG Ballard perhaps comes closest but his perspective is semi-American.

Contemporary US letters has produced two great poet-pundits - Mailer and Gore Vidal - who, though differing wildly in such matters as the quantity of wives (6-0 to Norman), are two sides of the same dollar. Both have run for political office. Both, while writing shelves of novels, have flourished in the form of the essay.

Their long mutual hostility may be explained by the realisation that they are fighting for the same prize: the ultimate summing-up of 20th century America. Seeing these Mailer films - after Vidal's various documentaries on the presidency - it's tempting to fantasise about a head-to-head television debate between the writers in the presidential campaign fashion: "Mr Mailer, your two minutes on the moon landing is up. Mr Vidal, you have one minute for rebuttal." Norman vs Gore would provide in eloquence, intelligence and radical ideas everything that Gore v Bush has lacked with the added thrilling possibility that rebuttal might lead to head-buttal.

These two programmes are a glorious warm-up by Mailer for such a bout. The authored documentary most depends on provocative opinions and freshly-made phrases and here the writer provides both. Ronald Reagan "truly loved America - which was possibly the only sincere thing about him." The nation would have been a better place if Bobby Kennedy had been elected President. Richard Nixon must be regarded as a "political genius" because he was "a man with an unpleasant personality who got the highest electoral vote of any president ever". The problem with much political writing is that "you can never do good writing simply because you dislike something". You wind him up and he winds us up.

But too many opinionated films can feel like displaced radio because the pictures lack the kick of the words. Here the programme-makers benefit from the size of Mailer's visual archive which includes Pennebaker's famous Town Bloody Hall, in which the writer debates with Germaine Greer and others. There's also a squirming appearance on American breakfast television after the New York Times has called Ancient Evenings a "disaster". But Copans and Neumann have also found more surprising illustration including a CIA recruitment video and footage of the Cold War Museum in Arizona.

What keeps us here, though, is the Mailer voice: informed and authoritative but also teasing and cheeky. There's only one cheap moment - when the film cuts from Mailer's reference to his penis to footage of an Apollo rocket soaring towards orbit -and the only regret is that Mailer's political retrospective pulls out before Clinton. But the author is a canny negotiator - who has needed to find vast quantities of alimony and child support in recent times - and may well see Clinton as a separate series. If so, it's one that Copans and Neumann should rush to make.

 Storyville - Oh My America,Wednesday & Thursday, 11.20pm, BBC2

webTitle: Nickelodeon UK assesses impact of BBC's plans

fields.headline: Nickelodeon UK studies impact of BBC's plans
fields.trailText: 10am: Nickelodeon UK has commissioned a survey to assess the economic impact of the BBC's planned children's services on its own output, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Nickelodeon UK has commissioned a survey to assess the economic impact of the BBC's planned children's services on its own output.

The company plans to use the results as an economic "ready reckoner" to respond to the government's consultation with the industry, after the BBC by the end of this year formally puts forward its proposals for the channel to secretary of state for culture, media and sport, Chris Smith.

The model is designed to allow for the input of different factors and variations, and could be used as a blueprint for other commercial television services to assess the impact of parallel BBC services in their market.

Nickelodeon claims a negative byproduct of BBC ventures into areas served by commercial TV companies will be that what it dubs "quality" cable and satellite services - offering mixed genre schedules, live output and increasing levels of local production - will suffer.

Nickelodeon has been vocal in attacking the BBC on its planned children's digital services, confirmed by director general Greg Dyke at the Edinburgh television festival. The company accuses of the BBC of breaching government guidelines and using public funds for the proposed BBC3 pre-school service without consultation.

Nickelodeon general manager Paul Lindley has written to Mr Smith, claiming the BBC is already commissioning material for the planned services via its children's TV department.

fields.headline: There's something about Mary
fields.standfirst: She shared his labour but not his glory, and when Dick Francis's wife Mary died last week, a particular type of woman went with her.  Elspeth Barker mourns the loss
fields.trailText: She shared his labour but not his glory, and when Dick Francis's wife Mary died last week, a particular type of woman went with her.  Elspeth Barker mourns the loss
fields.body:
The past is littered with them, the noble, only occasionally embittered wives and mistresses, sisters and daughters, too, who dedicated their lives to the service of their men, those brilliant creators who seldom thanked them or even acknowledged their value. Milton's wife, Yeats's sisters. And woe betide the pram in the hall, Cyril Connolly's iconic enemy of promise. Any mothering that went on was to be directed at the fragile psyche of the artistic male.

And what if the women, too, had creative aspirations? Consider Lily Briscoe in Virginia Woolf's To The Lighthouse, struggling to paint, yet preoccupied by her own inadequacy, her insignificance, keeping house for her father, Mr Tamsley whispering in her ear: "Women can't paint, women can't write."

Why did they do it, the wailing chorus of martyrs, the sacrificers of self; were they the victims of bullies or were they simply masochists? Or did they use their apparent servitude as an excuse for declining to engage with the responsibility of their own lives' potential? When, in fact, does supportiveness become subjugation?

These facile questions arrive from patronising attitudes as unkind and crass as the caricatured relationships they pretend to expose. They ignore the existence of love and belittle the detailed richness of women's lives.

Dick Francis's wife Mary died last week. His biographer, Graham Lord, has claimed that her contribution to her husband's work "was greatly underestimated. She did far more than anybody ever imagined." Francis himself had acknowledged this and would happily have shared his covers with her, but she declined, preferring always to stay out of the limelight. The fact of his recognition was enough for her; her research and editing were pleasures in themselves.

Is this strange? I think not. Not everyone is desperate to engage in the trashy cult of celebrity that dominates the media. Not everyone is animated primarily by selfishness, especially people of their generation who have retained the values of their past: generosity and courage, loving kindness and a certain modesty. The happiness that can derive from family life and friendship, dogs, gardens, owes nothing to opulence or style.

There is a curious view that monetary reward confers acceptability on acts of service to others. Thus nurses are rightly admired for their dedication and care, and because they are paid, albeit wretchedly, they are not seen as servile. Yet women who perform similar duties unpaid, at home, out of selfless devotion, are often viewed with thinly disguised contempt. They should be doing something with their lives.

In this day and age, we do have choices and if we choose to create conditions in which someone else may write or paint, there is no reason for this to be seen as martyrdom. You can have a very good time doing just what you like, while the creator is locked up in his garret. As for the stifling of your own creativity, allowing for the fact that it exists at all, it will emerge in its own weird way. Some make dolls' house furniture, others make courgette fritters. Just remember, though, that unless you're paid, it won't count and you will still be a sacrificial lamb and in some obscure way you will also be betraying the cause of women.

Being myself deeply uncreative, I was untroubled by these concerns while my children were small. I greatly enjoyed their society and have found all subsequent paid occupations a paltry substitute. My husband was a poet and I felt happy and honoured when he discussed new work with me. As for writing myself in those days, I had other things to do, some inevitably arduous, others more sybaritic.

What mattered then and still matters is simply affection and appreciation. The poet William Dunbar pointed this out 500 years ago: "Service and love above all other thinge." Service, not servitude.

webTitle: Seagram merger on track, says Vivendi

fields.headline: Seagram merger on track, says Vivendi
fields.trailText: Vivendi has insisted its merger with Seagram is on track, despite reports of a management fall-out with its sister company, Canal Plus. Dan Milmo reports.
fields.body:
Vivendi has insisted its merger with Seagram is on track, despite reports of a management fall-out between the French media group and its sister company, Canal Plus.

Sources at Vivendi rubbished rumours that Vivendi chairman Jean-Marie Messier came close to firing Canal Plus counterpart Pierre Lescure last week. The pair were said to be at loggerheads over plans to integrate Canal Plus, a pay-TV channel, with proposed merger partner Seagram, the owner of Universal Studios.

"Messier and Lescure recently held two meetings over integration plans and have been working together to prepare analysts' meetings for next week," said the source. The source added that the company did not know where the rumours were coming from, but suspected that it may be someone unhappy with being left out in the cold by the integration plans.

The Seagram merger is being examined by EU regulators, who are set to reach a decision on the £23bn deal before October 13. The new company would be called Vivendi Universal, as Seagram owns Universal Studios and Universal Music.

A Vivendi spokesperson refused to comment on the reports of a management fall-out, but said the company was confident its merger would receive the green light from the EU.

webTitle: Eidos shares plummet as takeover talks fail

fields.headline: Eidos shares plummet as takeover talks fail
fields.standfirst: Eidos undermined by loss of senior staffer
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: Eidos has dealt a further blow to its share price by abandoning takeover talks, says Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Eidos, the gaming company which launched the Tomb Raider franchise, has dealt a further blow to its share price by abandoning takeover talks.

The company's shares fell 10%, or 30p, to 264.5p after it said talks with a potential bidder, understood to be Infogrames of France, had been terminated. The news follows last week's resignation of finance director Jeremy Lewis.

"The board gave the approach serious consideration, but concluded that the terms discussed did not represent fair value for shareholders," said Eidos.

Eidos said it is still experiencing tough market conditions, complicated by a delay in delivering Sony's PlayStation 2 boxes. The company is hoping for signs of an upturn after this month's release of the Who Wants to be a Millionaire? game.

webTitle: Virgin.com hits back over lay-off claims

fields.headline: Virgin.com hits back over lay-off claims
fields.trailText: 2.45pm:Virgin.com has hit back at a report on US website thestandard.com that it planned to lay off almost 50% of its workforce. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Virgin.com has hit back at a report on US website thestandard.com that it planned to lay off almost 50% of its workforce.

Will Whitehorn, head of corporate affairs at Virgin Group, said that while 14 out of the 35 staff at Virgin.com had been offered voluntary redundancy, it was "process-driven" and dependent on the Virgin Net demerger from NTL going through in the next few weeks.

He said: "We have to offer voluntary redundancies at this stage as we're integrating the two businesses. The two [Virgin Net and Virgin.com] will sit alongside each other and it's more than likely that there'll be some redeployment rather than redundancies."

webTitle: Emap pop chief deflects criticism of cross-media sales policy

fields.headline: Emap pop chief deflects criticism of cross-media sales policy
fields.standfirst: Emap poaches former BBC music chief
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Emap's new head of pop, Trevor Dann, has flown in the face of his company critics, claiming: 'Cross-media is just about helping magazines to survive, it's as simple as that.' By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Emap's newly appointed head of pop, Trevor Dann, has hit out at critics of the company's cross-media sales policy, claiming: "Cross-media is just about helping magazines to survive, it's as simple as that."

But he warned of the danger that magazines could be "diluted" by poor masthead and online versions, as a result of over-zealous attempts to make the brand available across all platforms.

Mr Dann, who joins Emap on November 1, will take a strategic role across all the company's pop brands, spanning magazines (Smash Hits), radio and TV shows like the Box.

Emap last week announced that Mr Dann, along with Kiss FM's Mark Story and former Kerrang! editor Dave Henderson, are joining the company to develop cross-media strategies for its music brands.

"For a brand to survive, it will have to be available on different platforms," Mr Dann told MediaGuardian. "My daughter is seven and she reads Smash Hits, and she also wants to read the website and watch it on TV, and she can't - yet.

"There's a new generation out there which will simply not forgive you if you're not available in different media, all the time."

But Mr Dann said magazine publishers faced a tough time migrating a successful editorial formula into a winning proposition on TV, radio and online platforms.

In particular, he said, there is a danger that publishers could face a revolt from magazine journalists who feel their skills are being undervalued if they are not involved in turning magazines into broadcast models.

He added that a successful masthead programme reflected the editorial tone of the magazine without "slavishly copying the format", pointing out that "just because Top of the Pops magazine is aimed at the under-16s doesn't mean the programme isn't watched by the over-40s".

Mr Dann and others working on cross-media brands could face a backlash. Two weeks ago it was revealed that Emap broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney has downgraded the company's shares. One of the reasons given was advertisers' jitters about the company's policy of selling across media brands.

fields.headline: BBH unveils Excite campaign
fields.trailText: 10.15am: BBH is launching a national press and poster campaign for Excite, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Bartle Bogle Hegarty is launching a multimillion pound national press and poster campaign for Excite.

The campaign urges consumers to "get excited" and aims to build Excite UK's brand awareness among existing and new internet users. Press ads kick off on October 11, with posters breaking on October 26 and runnning until the end of the year.

The advertising has been developed for the UK consumer market and aims to communicate how the UK portal can bring excitement to consumers' lives whatever their interests.

The campaign introduces four different characters, namely the "superfly guy", the "female footballer and child", the "Japanese rocker" and the "scuba diver". It is backed by trade advertising, already running in specialised marketing and new-media publications.

Lorraine Thomson, senior marketing director of Excite Europe, said: "Excite is already one of the leading online European brands. We want to demonstrate that it is relevant for everyone, no matter what their needs are, how individual, what age, how basic their internet skills. Everyone can get excited on our site."

According to MMXI Europe, Excite.co.uk attracted 1.2 million users in August 2000, a 23% increase on January of this year. Excite UK claims its average number of daily visitors has reached 179,000, 226% higher than AskJeeves and 156% higher than AOL.co.uk.

Excite UK is a joint venture between British Telecommunications plc and Excite@Home. It offers free web-based email, online shopping and access to 15 different channels covering shopping, travel, music and sport.

fields.headline: England's injury crisis deepens
fields.trailText: England's injury crisis deepened today when Tony Adams and Grame Le Saux were ruled out of Wednesday's World Cup qualifier with Finland.
fields.body:
England's injury crisis deepened today when Tony Adams and Grame Le Saux were ruled out of Wednesday's World Cup qualifier with Finland.

Adams was unable to make the flight to Helsinki after injuring his back in a training session this morning. Le Saux, who was struggling after receiving a kick on his calf during Saturday's 1-0 defeat by Germany, also failed a fitness test today.

And England will also be without Paul Ince, who was given permission to pull out of the squad so he could return home to be with his wife, who is expected to give birth this week.

Stand-in coach Howard Wilkinson had already lost the services of Steven Gerrard and David Beckham.

But there was some better news for England. Andy Cole and Paul Scholes were able to train after picking up knocks on Saturday and they came through unscathed. And Gary Neville, who injured his toe against Germany, should also be fit to play on Wednesday.

As expected Teddy Sheringham, who has been in inspired form this season, has joined up with the squad and he took part in today's training session.

webTitle: BBC Worldwide recruits two new press officers

fields.headline: BBC Worldwide recruits two new press officers
fields.trailText: 11am: BBC Worldwide has expanded its internet and interactive team by appointing two new press officers, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
BBC Worldwide has expanded its internet and interactive team by appointing two new press officers.

Melanie Curtis joins as press officer, BBC Multimedia, from IMG Artists where she covered press and PR for 200 classical musicians and dance groups. Her appointment follows that of Andrew Widger, who was recently appointed press officer, internet and interactive, from the Press Association, where he was communications manager.

The two report directly to Matt Turmaine, head of press and PR, internet and interactive.

Janie Ironside Wood, director of communications at BBC Worldwide, said: "BBC Worldwide's Internet & Interactive business has developed significantly over the last 12 months. We therefore need to focus press and PR effort on the strategy and day-to-day working of the unit as a whole and the individual I&I businesses."

fields.headline: LineOne avoids watchdog's wrath
fields.trailText: 3pm: ISP watchdog the Internet Services Providers Association has shied away from giving LineOne a slap on its wrist over its unmetered access problems. Amy Vickersreports.
fields.body:
ISP watchdog the Internet Services Providers Association has shied away from giving LineOne a slap on its wrist over its unmetered access problems.

A formal investigation into the ISP followed a number of complaints relating to its unmetered internet access service, which it dumped in July unceremoniously.

At the time, the ISPA gave LineOne seven days to reply to allegations that it had failed to "act decently, fairly and reasonably at all times". ISPA members then met with LineOne to try to establish whether its code of practice had been breached.

The association said in a statement: "It is the view of the ISPA council that LineOne has not breached the ISPA code of practice. On the basis of evidence provided by LineOne, the ISPA council believes that LineOne used reasonable endeavours to comply with its obligations to its customers, thereby acting 'decently, fairly and reasonably' as the code requires."

Most of the complaints centred on the fact that unmetered LineOne users were forced to shell out £20 for diallers in order to switch telecom provider, then soon after the service was dumped without warning.

While the ISPA said originally that it wanted LineOne to refund the cost of the diallers, it is now saying that because users continued to use the unmetered service during the two-month notice period they had effectively saved "many times more the cost of the equipment that was initially paid for".

Industry reaction has been lukewarm, with the ISPA having been called timid for not making an example of LineOne for the whole unmetered internet access fiasco.

However, the ISPA statement said it was working with its members and the Advertising Standards Authority to ensure that in future confusion about the true meaning of 24-hour unmetered access is avoided.

webTitle: BBC wins back right to screen Royal Horticultural Society events

fields.headline: BBC wins back right to Royal Horticultural Society events
fields.trailText: 11.15am: The BBC has won back the right to screen Royal Horticultural Society events such as the Chelsea Flower Show. By Jessica Hodgson reports.
fields.body:
The BBC has won back the right to screen Royal Horticultural Society events such as the Chelsea Flower Show.

The corporation has snatched the rights back from Channel 4, which won them in 1998.

RHS's director general, Andrew Colquhoun, said the deciding factors for the RHS were the BBC's "proven track-record in developing the highest-rating gardening programme and its commitment to serving this huge and growing audience".

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: 1) Keegan: the verdict
fields.body:
1) Keegan: the verdict

Kevin Keegan = useless, tactically inept innocent who should never have been appointed England manager in the first place. That's what most of you, in your usual eloquent way, are arguing this morning.

"Kevin Keegan should have quit after the shambles of Euro 2000," reckons Karen Handley. "His inability to build a team with good defensive qualities was exposed then as it was on Saturday." After calling England's players "mediocre" and "gutless" she then returns her fire to Keegan. "Well done Kevin, you have destroyed our post-Olympic pride in a single afternoon."

And we've had hundreds of emails echoing her views. "It was painfully obvious to anyone after the Euro 2000 fiasco that Keegan should have been asked to step down," claims Campbell Watkins. "He is a nice chap, a good cheerleader, but out of his depth at the international level.

"He was also unwilling to stand down the old guard. Adams and Seaman continued, and had Shearer not retired himself, he would have been playing as well. Mercifully, Ince was left on the bench. Keown was right -- tactical ineptitude."

Not everyone saw it that way, however, with Mark Bassett launching a vigorous George Carman-like defence of Keegan. "Most of the negative reaction is probably down to the footy hacks that had to sit down Saturday evening and write a new set of headlines," he claims. "That Keegan had the self-awareness and the courage to admit his shortcomings himself is much to his credit. That he has done it four days before a game is neither here nor there."

But for many of you the real culprit is the Football Association. Perhaps Dave Noonan sums up your views best. "We appeared to be on the up after Euro 96, with a coach who knew his way around a tactical blackboard and players who would perform for him," he says. "What did the FA in their own retarded fashion do to reward those efforts? They left him out to dry."

"Since then we have been left reeling; with a disabled-despising, brainless god-botherer with the man-management skills of a chair leg to a hapless gung-ho, tactically bereft kamikaze - who quits to save his own neck and leaves his country wanting."

2) So who should replace him?

Howard Wilkinson? Alex Ferguson? Aime Jacquet? Or Joe Kinnear? One advocate of the later is Elliot Cohen, who writes: "The FA should look for a manager who has had success at a club with limited resources -- not necessarily one who has won championships. The England manager cannot buy in the best players like a Ferguson or Wenger can, but must make the best of his limited resources. Come in Martin O'Neill, or even better Joe Kinnear, England needs you."

Unsurprisingly there's no groundswell of support for Joe Kinnear. Well not yet, anyway. Instead many of you support another cheeky cockney, Terry Venables. "Venables should be brought back to the job and 99 per cent will be happy!" is Paul French's view. But not everyone agrees with him.

"Doubtless a lot of people will argue for the return of Venables, but frankly I would suggest taking a look at Peter Taylor," says Simeon Orram. And he has support from Michael Baynes, who claims that: "The FA should now make a clean sweep and sack Wilkinson and appoint as manager his bete noir, the hugely talented and tactically clever Peter Taylor."

But Tony Traub doesn't believe the fortunes of the England team will be improved by bringing in a new man. "Surely the blunt truth is that whoever comes in will end up with the same ordinary players and will be in for a hard time?"

3) Where now for English football?

The Richard Williams article on the future of the English game stirred many of you into writing this morning. "This is the first time I've actually read a wholehearted appraisal of the scope of the problems inherent in our national team, that doesn't merely concentrate on the mechanics of the players/management, but examines the influence of our moronic, xenophobic culture upon what is an all-round unpleasant scenario. Excellent article!" says James Gardiner.

However not everyone completely agrees with Richard's analysis. Matthew Fleming takes issue with the booing of the German national anthem. "While I agree that whistling other countries' national anthems is not a good thing, I resent the fact that we roll this into the English football problem, since it happens during almost every international football match in the world," he says.

"To debate linked social history problems is barely Mr Williams's job, and definitely not mine. Please stop wheeling out the same irrelevant arguments every time England's football is shown to be too naive. This has nothing to do with supporters, nor stadia, and everything to do with the fact that players in Germany, France and Italy and Holland are from an early age funded better in better-organised clubs and leagues, and coached by qualified coaches."

And Matthew Fleming is not the only one who believes poor infrastructure lies behind the dismal showing of the national team. "The English game has, for too long, placed work rate and aggression above skill and vision with the result that domestic matches resemble contests between psychopathic headless chickens," says Mike Hewlett. "The continentals have been laughing at this style of play for decades but the English have yet to recognise the joke. Hence, the Wembley fiasco was caused by the technically deficient being led by the tactically inept, with the result we all feared.

"The game must be restructured to place the emphasis back on basic techniques," he suggests. "This will also require coaches to be qualified, not simply be popular ex-players. In the meantime, at least we will be spared the embarrassment of watching drunken English 'supporters' vandalising host cities after their team has been humiliated once again."

4) A Scotsman writes

Are English fans over-optimistic? That's what Peter Bond thinks. And before you ask, he's from Scotland. "English football, the fans, the media, the commentators, and England MUST get a reality check," he writes. "England have beaten only two world class teams in competitive matches since they won the World Cup in 1966 -- Holland in Euro 1996 and France in Spain 1982. Find me another world class team they have beaten in that period (i.e. a team capable at the time of winning the tournament) and I'll eat my words.

"That record in international football is not grounds for the unrealistic expectation and hype that surrounds the English game. All major European and South American nations have a better record in competitive international football than England," he adds, failing to mention exactly how many world-class teams Scotland have beaten in the same period.

fields.headline: Readers' wives, my arse
fields.trailText:
Readers' wives online
While checking to see which of its flagship magazines Northern & Shell has registered the domain names of, Monkey was amused to find that a certain webmeister, the one and only Richard Evans, is the proud registrar of readerswives.com. Intrigued, Monkey checked out the website only to find it defaults to Object1, the digital agency where Richard works. For a brief second, Monkey thought Richard may have devoted an entire site to his missus, the delectable Tarnya Norse from Mediasurface. Phew, what a relief.

Only slimline warriors need apply

"Firstly, the generosity of Channel 5 in offering Rainbow a box of T-shirts goes without saying - we were delighted to receive them, and we had loads of entrants to the competition in which they were the prize. On opening the eagerly awaited box of goodies, however, we could tell straight away that there was no way, with the best will in the world, anyone other than a small teenager or large Teddy bear was going to be able to get into them.

Monkey is unsure about being compared to a large teddy bear, but may well have to take up Rainbow's kind offer in the spirit of investigation.



Sticky gimmicks
Monkey was amused to discover an overflowing pot of honey in the post today. The honey pot subsequently attacked all surrounding computers and made everything in the office sticky. Eugh. The penny finally dropped when Monkey found the attached (and at this point very sticky) note, saying that eBay was stickier than QXL. Point taken. But did it really have to destroy my workspace to tell me that?

Clash of the dot.com giants
Plunging dot.com stock prices are nothing new, but the long-term ramifications are starting to impact heavily on those big boys we call Amazon and eBay. Rumours have started to surface about a mooted merger between the two e-commerce giants, which have both been rocked by the recent downturn in dot.com fortunes. A tie-up would make sense, particularly for Amazon, which is struggling to convince investors of its long-term earnings. Perhaps it should take a leaf from eBay's gimmick book and start sending out plants and pots of bottled Amazon river water to prove to investors that Amazon can make things grow. Just a (naff) suggestion.

Proud to portly
Channel 5 kindly sent 50 of its finest Xena, Warrior Princess T-shirts to the gay and lesbian website Rainbownetwork.com for a competition giveaway, on account of the pigtailed one being terribly popular with the target audience. Channel 5 was staggered, then, when Rainbow very apologetically sent them all back. It seems the T-shirts are of the cropped belly button-baring variety and, after a bit of market research in the office, Rainbow discovered they were too petite for its users. Seems a shame to let them go to waste, so Monkey is happy to try to squeeze into one to show support.

Bad taste sensation
GMTV managing director Christopher Stoddart is so concerned about reports of tasteless office banter that he has issued an email to all staff reminding them of the company's equal opportunities policy. In a carefully worded memo, he also reminded staff of the company's grievance procedure and told them that they mustn't feel frightened of whistle-blowing on their bosses. "From time to time we will be drawing your attention to important company policies which we all need to follow. Our equal opportunities policy is particularly important because its scope is both on-screen and off-screen," he wrote. "Should any employee have a complaint under this policy [or for any other reason] he should feel free to raise the matter." He continued: "If it concerns their line manager, then they may wish to consult personnel." Who on earth has prompted this and what on earth did he or she say? Answers on the back of a cornflakes box, please.

Readers of the Scotsman who also take Sunday Business may be suffering from a sense of déja vu. A few weeks ago top Sunday Biz hack Richard Northedge wrote a coruscating profile of some suit or other doing something fantastically important in the City. Two weeks later a frighteningly similar article (exactly the same except for two small amendments) appeared in the Scotsman's revamped business section, albeit under a different byline. Perhaps Northedge should sue for plagiarism. But then the ed-in-chief of the pink Sunday is one Andrew Neil, who is also in charge of the Scotsman. Other Sunday Business hacks should expect further doppelganger copy to start appearing north of the border under increasingly ludicrous invented bylines.

The man who coined the immortal phrase "They think it1s all over..." really did think Wembley was going to be all over without him. Now Sport First has hired the game's most memorable voice to write about the last match. What a joy, says Kenneth. Well, it is now!

fields.headline: Runners, riders and dark horses
fields.trailText:
Terry Venables Odds: 2-1 fav
Motivational skills: As good as Kevin Keegan's.
Tactical awareness: Probably the best among English coaches.
Temperament: Likes to think of himself as a cool dude.
Verdict: Favourite on the form but unlikely even to get to the starting post.
fields.body:
Terry Venables Odds: 2-1 fav
Motivational skills: As good as Kevin Keegan's.
Tactical awareness: Probably the best among English coaches.
Temperament: Likes to think of himself as a cool dude.
Verdict: Favourite on the form but unlikely even to get to the starting post.

Peter Taylor Odds: 7-1
Motivational skills: Top class (except in the case of Stan Collymore).
Tactical awareness: Encouraging signs but unproven at top level.
Temperament: Excellent, except for a tendency to lapse into Norman Wisdom impersonations.
Verdict: Despite a great England Under-21 record, probably seen as too inexperienced to compete against the world's best.

Bryan Robson Odds: 11-1
Motivational skills: Questionable, given some Middlesbrough performances.
Tactical awareness: Could do better
Temperament: Excellent, except after a night out with Peter Reid.
Verdict: Would be popular choice. But may not get the trip.

Bobby Robson Odds: 16-1
Motivational skills: Just look at the transformation in Newcastle.
Tactical awareness: Sometimes got it wrong with England but had the sense to listen to players.
Temperament: Avuncular. Verdict: Proven class, but almost old enough to join the FA committee.

Aimé Jacquet Odds: 6-1
Motivational skills: Convinced underachievers France they could win the World Cup.
Tactical awareness: First class.
Temperament: Sound, if stubborn.
Verdict: Already course and distance winner in the World Cup.

Arsene Wenger Odds: 12-1
Motivational skills: Second to none.
Tactical awareness: Gets it right nine times out of ten.
Temperament: Unflappably Gallic.
Verdict: Runs well in blinkers. Likely to refuse at this level.

Howard Wilkinson Odds: 8-1
Motivational skills: None, unless you are a believer in gobbledegook.
Tactical awareness: Great if you like the ball hoofed higher than a sponsor's blimp.
Temperament: Drone, drone, drone (think William Hague).
Verdict: Would be totally outclassed in this company.

Marcello Lippi Odds: 16-1
Motivational skills: Considered excellent until Internazionale lost their opening Serie A game.
Tactical awareness: Highly regarded around the world.
Temperament: Too honest for his own good (see K Keegan).
Verdict: Top-class pedigree. Must go close in this field
