fields.headline: Yom Kippur: the sound of silence
fields.standfirst: The streets of Jerusalem are always silent on Yom Kippur, but this year the air is thick with foreboding, writes Derek Brown, the Guardian's former Middle East correspondent
fields.trailText: The streets of Jerusalem are always silent on Yom Kippur, but this year the air is thick with foreboding, writes Derek Brown, the Guardian's former Middle East correspondent.
fields.body:
The first thing you notice is the quietness. The city is utterly hushed. There is not a sound from the roads, from the neighbours, from the phone. Yom Kippur, in Jerusalem, is an awesome experience. It's the day when life stops dead in its tracks and you have to be brave, foolish, or incredibly insensitive to break the rule of silence.

The day of atonement is not just for observant Jews. It is a dusk-to-dusk duty for all who live in the Israeli part of Jerusalem - and woe betide those who ignore it.

Before my first Yom Kippur, I was coached in the protocol. Don't ring up Israeli friends or contacts. If you turn on a radio or the TV, keep the sound low. Don't eat anything in public. If you have to go anywhere, walk.

Frankly, I thought the warnings a bit overdone. Surely, I thought, this vibrant, raucous city couldn't come to a complete halt. Wrong. It could, and it did.

I walked out of my house on the Bethlehem Road, normally a bedlam of traffic, and wondered at the utter quiet. There were people abroad, but all were on foot.

Some of the men, sober suited for the holy day, had stones in their hands. For a gentile - and possibly also for unobservant Jews - Yom Kippur has a threatening quality. If you drive, you will be attacked for your sacrilege.

Judaism, like all religions, is officially a tolerant and inclusive creed, with many strands and traditions. But on Yom Kippur, in Jerusalem at any rate, it demands collective obedience.

That is the point of it, after all. The Yom Kippur prayer stresses "we". It is a communal prayer, in which believers beg forgiveness not for their own sins, but for the sins of all.

Rabbi Morris Kertzer of New York, in his invaluable guide What is a Jew?, sums it up crisply: "There are individual sins, of course, but there is also an acceptance of collective responsibility for the shortcomings of mankind. On Yom Kippur we share each other's burden of guilt."

Jews have prayed and fasted on Yom Kippur for more than five millennia. Today is the tenth day of Tishri, in the year 5761. It is also the twelfth day of the latest crisis in the holy land, in which more than 80 lives have been lost. Tonight, as the fast ends, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, will make a momentous decision.

He has warned that unless the Palestinians - there are 3m of them under Israeli suzerainty - come to heel and cease their riotous protests, he will launch violent retaliatory action. Military sources have dropped heavy hints of an assault on Yasser Arafat's flyblown headquarters in the Gaza Strip.

In modern Israel, Yom Kippur is a time of doubt, as well as contemplation. On this day in 1973 the nation was caught horribly on the hop, when Egyptian and Syrian troops launched a war of reprisal for their humiliation in the six day war of 1967.

It didn't work. The Israeli army, the most formidable in the region, overcame its initial shock and recovered its 1967 conquests. But it took heavy losses, not least its reputation for invincibility.

Today, once more, the army is on high alert, awaiting the orders of a prime minister who was once its chief of staff. In Jerusalem today, the silence will be heavy with foreboding.

He has warned that unless the Palestinians - there are 3m of them under Israeli suzerainty - come to heel and cease their riotous protests, he will launch violent retaliatory action. Military sources have dropped heavy hints of an assault on Yasser Arafat's flyblown headquarters in the Gaza Strip. In modern Israel, Yom Kippur is a time of doubt, as well as contemplation. On this day in 1973 the nation was caught horribly on the hop, when Egyptian and Syrian troops launched a war of reprisal for their humiliation in the six day war of 1967. It didn't work. The Israeli army, the most formidable in the region, overcame its initial shock and recovered its 1967 conquests. But it took heavy losses, not least its reputation for invincibility. Today, once more, the army is on high alert, awaiting the orders of a prime minister who was once its chief of staff. In Jerusalem today, the silence will be heavy with foreboding. fields.headline: 'This is war'
fields.standfirst: The bitter battle between BBC1 and ITV may have started over the news, but the move to 10pm puts entire schedules head to head. With current affairs banished from BBC 1 primetime and both dashing for more soaps and gameshows, will viewers still be able to tell them apart? By  Maggie Brown
fields.trailText: The bitter battle between BBC1 and ITV may have started over the news, but the move to 10pm puts entire schedules head to head. With current affairs banished from BBC 1 primetime and both dashing for more soaps and gameshows, will viewers still be able to tell them apart? By Maggie Brown.
fields.body:
Caroline Aherne was besieged with frantic calls last Wednesday. The Radio Times desperately needed to photograph her as Denise Royle with new baby David as they scrambled to pull together a new front cover in a matter of hours.

The BBC's decision to rush forward the switch of its news to 10pm on October 16 and stuff the first week's schedule with their (too few) hit shows such as the Royle Family sent massive shock waves in every direction.

"This is war," announced a grim Clive Jones, chief executive of Carlton Television, as ITV responded by ruthlessly targeting the new 10pm News. "I find their arrogance breathtaking."

"It's like dinosaurs taking lumps out of each other," said Channel 4's chief scheduler, Rosemary Newell, as every network plotted revenge. Over at Sky, jokes about the "clay footed" BBC were replaced with respect, as Sky One gleefully fell on the task of targeting 10pm.

Ominously, last Tuesday's stunning announcement created a rare moment as politicians, desperate to ensure a choice of prime news outlets, united across party divides in fury: Chris Smith, Peter Ainsworth (Conservative shadow media spokesman) and Norman Baker (Liberal Democrats) uniformly condemned the move and questioned how this action could possibly constitute public-service broadcasting.

"I am hearing enormous political anger," said a top broadcasting regulator from the Tory party conference.

More to the point, Tony Blair's weekend red box reportedly contained the draft communications white paper to streamline regulation. Nemesis is at hand. The BBC governors will lose their special "judge and jury" status, demoted to Channel 4-style directors, answerable to an external regulator.

As the BBC's critics pointed out gloatingly, the introduction of statute (in the shape of a new communica tions act) can trump even the corporation's Royal Charter. But at a government seminar over the summer chairman Sir Christopher Bland had already virtually conceded the ground.

"My view is that the BBC knew the battle to keep the governors was already lost and decided to get on with more important things, like holding its audience," says a former BBC adviser.

Yet Chris Smith is not just another licence fee payer. The BBC requires his permission to see through its next phase of digital expansion: to launch two new children's services, revamp Choice and Knowledge as BBC3 and BBC4, and run five new digital radio stations. It is also consulting over ambitious plans for a digital educational network which will take it right into commercial territory.

Michael Jackson, chief executive of Channel 4, speaks for the entire commercial sector: "We need an independent regulator, that gen uinely harmonises things like the provision of news. This is a dog's dinner." The BBC should be tied, as Channel 4 is, to a clear statement of promises, he says.

Clive Jones adds: "When ITV wanted to move its news, it had an extensive period of consultation, a trial period, then a painful formula to reinstate news. The BBC had none of this. It is acting on a belief that it will be proved right, though we know it is really all about ratings."

Even events in the wider world conspired to question the BBC's move. The fall of Slobodan Milosevic as the people of Serbia marched last Thursday was perfectly suited for the BBC's Nine O'Clock News. Under the new arrangements homes without rolling news - the majority - would have had no real update till 10 pm.

Dyke's bold ploy took root on Friday morning, September 22, after the independent television commission (ITC) struck its deal with ITV for a return of News at Ten three or four nights a week. Before jetting off to the Olympics he asked Tony Hall and Mark Thompson, respectively director of BBC news and television, to see which was the first week when the news could be shifted from 9pm.

He came back to the answer: the week of October 16. Hall says he was encouraged by David Liddiment's refusal to revive the name News at Ten. But the truth is that every half-hearted move in ITV's half-hearted plans gave Dyke the fig leaf he needed. "The trouble with the ITC deal was that by day two it started to be unpicked, allowing BBC1 to justify its superior provision," observes Jackson.

All that remained was for Dyke to gain permission from an emergency meeting of governors last Monday. Sir Christopher Bland, an odd chameleon figure who adjusts his behaviour according to the style of his director-general, went around the table, putting the spotlight on each governor individually - yes or no. There was never really any doubt. The governors recruited Dyke for his gung-ho quality and on this matter, it was back him - or else.

Michael Jackson, a former BBC director of television, observes there is a Dyke factor at work here, revelling in sailing close to the wind and being everything John Birt was not. The sheer speed of the BBC's action prevented political opposition growing. "Good for them," says Jackson. "Greg really does put two fingers up to the government and Chris Smith in particular. There's a real sense that because of the [generous] nature of the licence fee settlement [which is index-linked until 2006] the BBC can do as it wants, without reference to politicians. Whatever one thinks of that, we're seeing at the moment a dysfunctional relationship between the two."

ITV's council meeting - where big decisions are thrashed out - also took place last Tuesday as the move was confirmed. The network's power brokers decided not to rush forward News at Ten plans to trump the BBC - though ITN would have loved to be asked, and Granada was initially keen.

Simply holding firm is not really an option for the network, however. The run up to Christmas is ITV's most critical revenue period. The network's owners know that the move is designed to take audiences away from them between 9pm and 10pm as the BBC puts out its best programmes, and ramps up investment.

"We will throw everything we can against the BBC between 9pm and 11pm, to hold onto viewers and cut the appeal of News at Ten," vows Jones. "Every drama, every entertainment show, every event we can lay our hands on. Peak Practice, Fat Friends, movies on Friday nights, the lot.

"This is a very clear betrayal of the BBC's public service values. What they are doing is not in the interests of viewers. Nor do they have carte blanche to target the commercial sector." It is likely ITV's resurrection of News at Ten will not now happen: relaunch at the end of January is fading by the day, though the ITC still thinks the deal stands.

Patricia Hodgson's stitched together deal - with the attractions of news on the main channels at 6pm, 6.30pm, 7pm, 9 pm and 10 pm (four nights), plus Channel 5 bulletins - seems a pipedream. Her power, given such a shot in the arm by her apparent victory just three weeks ago, is dented.

Jones says: "We have no real desire to go head to head with them, [but] we are not going to take any precipitate action." ITV will reopen talks with the ITC at some point after the BBC moves. The argument will be that two programmes at 10pm will halve news audiences.

ITV executives' gameplan is to embarrass the BBC over the long term, perhaps even into moving back to 9pm. They are studying Bland's comments on Channel 4 News last Tuesday when he speculated that this could happen if audiences plummet.

They also know that the BBC (as it privately admits) is under huge pressure because it does not have a sufficient stockpile of top-rating programmes to support its ambitions after the first big blaze up to Christmas. Already, dramas like Take a Girl Like You, originally destined for Sunday night, are to be parachuted into the 9pm weekday slot. Also, many recent drama series such as Badger, Border Cafe, Dirty Work and Fish have flopped.

It is also clear from the first week's schedules that there is a lot of stretching going on: the few live programmes - Watchdog and Crimewatch - are being told to run for an extra five to 10 minutes, to bring 50-minute dramas and other pieces up to the hour, says Mark Thompson.

He concedes that a fourth episode of EastEnders is now a "possibility" (for which, read "certainty").

With all the treats and big name feature films being lined up for the first week of the new schedule, viewers may well initially think it's Christmas. Certainly, BBC1's first week looks like Christmas (or an American network): it has no serious documentaries, current affairs or arts in weekday primetime.

Panorama has been dumped on Sundays at 10.15 pm, a slot to suit its 2-3m audience, when, as Jackson observes, BBC1 current affairs needs to be reinvented. "God slot" strands like Everyman - the show that Panorama replaces - will be shoe-horned in somewhere in the week, after the news.

Tony Hall, BBC director of News, says the important thing is that Panorama remains on BBC1 (the governors did put their foot down over a shift to BBC2) and that there were precious few other slots. The series is still seeking an editor. Meanwhile, ITV, with its commitment to running Tonight with Trevor McDonald at 10pm, looks like the channel with a commitment to current affairs.

The move also has huge repercussions for BBC2, and its relationship with BBC1, way beyond losing choice programmes such as Have I Got News For You?. The Friday night comedy zone is being turned into the History zone. Instead, BBC1 will have two comedy zones, on Mondays and Fridays between 9pm and 10pm.

And there are other clear winners and losers. Channel 4 promises to target 10pm (where it already schedules ER and Ally McBeal) with even greater vigour. Newell says, "nothing is out of the question. We will be making changes, but not from the first week." Most dramatically, it might even move Channel 4 News to 8pm.

Advertisers clearly face a "serious problem". Zenith Media's Adam Smith warns that ITV's audiences will shrink. "That is most unusual for commercial audiences, as the public service network grows. They will have to spend more to get the same level of exposure."

Yet, Dyke's claim that the BBC is moving the news to boost news audiences is met with universal disbelief in adland. Hall says it's really a case of holding and stemming further decline, now running at around 4% a year (after a period of 8%), rather than actually increasing viewers.

The figures tell the story. In the year to June 2000, BBC1 gained an average of 5.7m adult viewers between 8pm and 11pm, while ITV had 7m. With a clear run of entertainment this could even out eventually. However, at 10pm, the total TV audience is around 20m, 2m less people than at 9pm. At best a quarter, some 5m, might remain with BBC1 news, compared to the average of 5.3m so far this year for the Nine O'Clock News.

Thompson says: "If the organisation cannot move swiftly, it will not survive". If BBC news audiences do not thrive, it's hard to see Dyke surviving.

webTitle: Comment: Roy Hattersley on the Tories' weirdness

fields.headline: Weird world of life in the shadows
fields.standfirst: Only two or three opposition frontbenchers are at all normal
fields.trailText: High-minded people who think that politics should be about policies not personalities - and therefore regretted that Tony Blair chose to describe William Hague as weird - were reinforced in their fastidious beliefs last week when it became clear that the insult was gratuitously selective. There was absolutely no justification for the prime minister picking on the Tory leader in particular. The opposition frontbench is weird in general.
fields.body:
High-minded people who think that politics should be about policies not personalities - and therefore regretted that Tony Blair chose to describe William Hague as weird - were reinforced in their fastidious beliefs last week when it became clear that the insult was gratuitously selective. There was absolutely no justification for the prime minister picking on the Tory leader in particular. The opposition frontbench is weird in general.

Admittedly, two or three of them are normal. Andrew Mackay is typical of the golfing bores who lean on the corners of the nation's club-house bars and talk about their BMWs and the way in which the country is going to the dogs under the socialists. All over the country incompetents, promoted far beyond their ability, identify with Theresa May. And Dr Liam Fox has all the brash self-confidence of a doctor who never doubts his own diagnosis. But most of the rest behave as if they were sewn together in a Transylvanian laboratory.

Worst of all is Michael Portillo, whose behaviour last week at the Conservative party conference exhibited all the symptoms of monomania. His address to the party faithful was more suitable for delivery from a psychiatrist's couch than a political platform. And the television interviews which followed pursued the introverted theme. Compassion compels me to rejoice that Mr Portillo has found his true self and that defeat at the last election enabled him to reject his bad old rightwing ways. But listening to him perform his apologia was like eavesdropping on a meeting of Reactionaries Anonymous. Normal people do not indulge in such indecent emotional exposure.

One sure sign of dementia is the sudden switch of mood - elation to depression, love to hate, tranquillity to hysteria. With Michael Portillo the change is just as chillingly unpredictable, although where psychology begins and ideology ends is not clear. The callous old conviction that the victims of the market system are a necessary sacrifice to competitive efficiency has been replaced with a compassionate belief in the inclusive society that cares for its casualties. The last-ditch defender of the poll tax now advocates an annual increase in public expenditure. Total rejection of past life and previous behaviour is usually the sign of a nervous breakdown.

That was not the only symptom of what medical science will come to call the Portillo syndrome. On television he defended his philosophic oscillations with a manic calm and the repetition of meaningless phrases. He replied to almost every suggestion of intellectual inconsistency with what he clearly believed to be a mystic revelation. "The world has changed." Indeed it has. The Tories have lost the election and his heroine, Margaret Thatcher, is just a bad memory. But would a stable man have reacted to those events by claiming the equivalent of a frontal lobotomy?

And would he take constant refuge in fantasy? Portillo's Pauline conversion was preceded not by a thunderbolt or flash of lightning but by the whirr of television cameras. Mr Portillo must be one of the few men who have been born again on screen. Simulating the work of a hospital porter gave him "the chance to connect with Britain today". Is it possible that the cabinet minister, member of parliament, Conservative party researcher and cub tycoon had no idea what life was really like until he signed the contract with the BBC? Lord Reith must be smiling in his studio in the sky to discover that the corporation still has an educative effect on susceptible minds.

Mr Portillo's conference speech, which was shamelessly about himself rather than his party's policy, can only be excused if we accept it as a form of auto-therapy - an attempt to expel the demons within and achieve a Conservative catharsis. Yet it has been described as a bravura performance - mostly by journalists who are not quite sure what bravura means. The Shorter Oxford Dictionary, being very long indeed, can be taken as an authority on the subject. It offers three definitions. The first is "a display of daring or defiance". Since Mr Portillo was attempting to reconcile himself with the decent people he had offended over the years, his speech was hardly that. The second possibility is "brilliance of execution". Admittedly he learned his speech by heart. But that is a sort of brilliance which appeals only to parrots.

The third definition seems nearer the mark. For it reminds us that brilliance is flashy moved upmarket: "An attempt at brilliant performance...intentional passage of display and elaborate execution." There is something wrong with political commentary when an attempt at appearing spontaneous by learning a speech by rote is regarded as an oratorical achievement. A senior politician who takes refuge in such contrivances can only be described as weird - a characteristic of the shadow cabinet which can be demonstrated without even mentioning Ann Widdecombe.

 comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Ebookers expands by swallowing parent company
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Ebookers.com plans to buy its parent company, Flightbookers, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The travel website, ebookers.com, has out-grown Flightbookers, the parent company it was spun out of in 1999, and now plans to buy it in a $15m (£10.2m) deal.

The deal cements ebookers' position as the largest internet travel agency in Europe and follows months of aggressive acquisitive behaviour in which it bought its way into different European markets.

Flightbookers, which last year had sales of about $70m (£47.5m), is owned by ebookers' chairman and chief executive officer, Dinesh Dhamija.

The acquisition will be subject to shareholder approval, although it has been mooted since ebookers' IPO-ed last November. Shares in ebookers, which are listed on the Nasdaq and the Neuer Markt, are currently around the $5.43 (£3.4) mark, a significant drop from the high of $43 (£29.20) earlier this year. Ebookers raised $45m (£30.5m) through a private placement in July this year to see the business through to the first quarter of 2002.

The purchase of Flightbookers will enable ebookers to secure direct access to Flightbookers' 220,000 customers as well as reducing costs.

According to recent statistics from Nielsen/NetRatings, ebookers.com was the UK's most visited travel website in August with 249,000 unique users. fields.headline: Boo.com set to return
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Boo.com is to make a comeback at the end of this month, Claire Cozens writes.
fields.body:
Boo.com, the online fashion retailer that hit the headlines earlier this year when it became one of the first major dotcoms to call in the receivers, is to make a comeback at the end of this month with the new strapline, "Boo.com - because style never dies".

The retailer is being relaunched on October 30 by its new owner, US company Fashionmall.com, which bought the site from the receivers in June. Fashionmall hopes to capitalise on the notoriety of the Boo.com brand name to make its European debut.

Kate Buggeln, president of Boo.com, said: "In recent months we've had on and offline conversations with past and future Boo.com visitors. It is clear that the Boo.com community thrives on the exchange of dialogue about individual style and opinion. On the new Boo.com this will allow for the evolution of trends and ideas in the world of fashion and lifestyle. We're creating a virtual party where the famous, infamous and anonymous can interact with impunity."

Fashionmall will also bring back Miss Boo, the virtual shopping assistant who provides comments on Boo.com products as users call them up.

The company hopes to generate revenue from advertising and licensing as well as product sales. Advertisers will be able to sponsor specific pages and the company is also planning to develop its own merchandise with designers and manufacturers.

webTitle: For the benefit of Mr Such

fields.headline: For the benefit of Mr Such
fields.standfirst: Every Monday wisden.com asks a cricketing figure about his plans for the close season. This week we talk to the Essex and England offspinner Peter Such
fields.trailText: Peter Such, 36, played for Nottinghamshire and Leicestershire before joining Essex in 1990. He has won 11 England caps, the last against New Zealand at Old Trafford in 1999. At the beginning of the 2000 season, Such was kept out of the Essex side by fellow offspinner Tim Mason, but regained his place and took 36 first-class wickets at 29.30. Mason finished with 14 victims at over 50
fields.body:
Peter Such, 36, played for Nottinghamshire and Leicestershire before joining Essex in 1990. He has won 11 England caps, the last against New Zealand at Old Trafford in 1999. At the beginning of the 2000 season, Such was kept out of the Essex side by fellow offspinner Tim Mason, but regained his place and took 36 first-class wickets at 29.30. Mason finished with 14 victims at over 50

"The thing I'll be concentrating on is working on the old benefit for next year. It is my first benefit and I've been getting things sorted out already. I'm concentrating on the brochure at the moment. You speak to friends among the journalists and players and get them to write articles for you. I have to chase them up but I don't think I seem too much of a nag because I'm a friend. The articles are starting to come in now that the season is over and everyone has got a bit more time.

"I'm trying to work out a few out-of-season events but the main work will be during the season. I've got a benefit committee working on it at the moment. We're waiting for the ECB to release the fixture list for next year and then we can organise things for the summer.

"You generally follow the tried-and-trusted strategies that have worked for beneficiaries in the past. Old beneficiaries pass down lists of people who have attended previous functions and events. The main thing is to make it fun and to try and give people value. I've spoken to several members of previous beneficiary committees and will try and avoid the pitfalls.

"This year, due to the fact that I'll be working on my benefit and won't be doing any other sort of job, Essex will pay my salary over a 12-month period rather than seven which helps financially.

"I'm having a bit of time off at the moment but will start training again after Christmas. I don't see that much of the rest of the team as I'm in Colchester and most of the guys live in Chelmsford. I might see some for a round of golf though or at a function. I tend to socialise with my own circle of friends round our way during the winter.

"I don't really have any set goals for next season because those sort of targets can be altered by circumstances beyond your control. I just hope to bowl well and to get satisfaction from that. I was happy with the way I bowled last year when I was in the side, but I wasn't happy with the circumstances which led to me not playing for the first half of the season.

"Last winter I did three Pitmans training courses partly funded by the PCA, which I would recommend to all cricketers. Before I went, I knew how to switch a computer on but that was it. I couldn't type or anything. Now I am confident with the basics, and spend quite a bit of time using email."

Peter Such was talking to Tanya Aldred. If you want to help him with his benefit please write to: Peter Such Benefit, 12 Windmill Close, Boxted, Colchester, Essex CO4 5SA. To read last week's My Winter, in which Warwickshire's Mark Wagh tells us about going to Venice and stockbroking, click here

webTitle: Salas on his way to Inter

fields.headline: Salas on his way to Inter
fields.trailText: Marcelo Salas looks set to leave Lazio to join Internazionale in a deal worth around £22m. Inter's 24-year-old Croatian midfielder Dario Simic will move to Rome as part of the deal.
fields.body:
Marcelo Salas looks set to leave the Italian champions Lazio to join Internazionale in a player and cash deal worth around £22m. Inter's 24-year-old Croatian midfielder Dario Simic will move to Rome as part of the deal.

"The deal for Salas will be completed next week," said Lazio's owner Sergio Cragnotti. "There are still some details to be sorted out, but I believe it's only a formality."

The Chilean striker has been out of favour with Lazio since the close-season signings of the Argentine pair Claudio Lopez and Hernan Crespo for a combined fee of £53m.

Inter also announced that Italy's Under-21 coach Marco Tardelli has made a verbal agreement to replace Marcello Lippi as coach. The former Juventus and Inter player, capped 81 times, emerged as favourite after Inter's approach for the Argentine Daniel Passarella was rejected.

Rivaldo, the world and European player of the year, has threatened to walk out on his club Barcelona and return home. Responding to accusations in the Spanish press that he used an ankle injury as an excuse to take a holiday in Brazil, Rivaldo said: "If the fans and directors are not happy with me I will go back to Brazil because it is certain my family do want me.

"I would leave all the money and go. It is going to be very difficult for me if they aren't happy with my work. I have always tried to be honest and sincere, but it is difficult to work with so many lies being told about me."

Rivaldo, also criticised for in the wake of his club's poor run, recently signed a new contract that reportedly earns him $6m (£4.25m) a year tax-free. "All of this is because of the contract I signed with Barcelona," he added.

Paraguay's goalkeeper Jose Luis Chilavert was at it again at the weekend, scoring from a free-kick as his team beat Colombia 2-0 in a World Cup qualifier in Bogota. Chilavert, who had threatened to sue the Colombian football federation for using a photograph of him on match tickets, curled the ball around the wall in the 90th minute. Bayern Munich's Roque Santa Cruz had opened the scoring after four minutes.

Ron Atkinson yesterday poured cold water on a Sunday newspaper claim that Manchester United had offered Oxford United, then managed by Jim Smith, £6,000 to play a League Cup decider at Old Trafford.

"I remember the case in point very well. There's no problem," said Atkinson, then the United manager, of the 1983 incident. "We drew a match and it was discussed with Jim, 'Would you want to come back here and play the game at Old Trafford where you are going to get three times the crowd you are going to get at Oxford? Obviously both clubs are going to benefit.' The money I don't recall ever being mooted."

Chelsea are reported to be close to signing the 32-year-old Yugoslavian international Slavisa Jokanovic from Deportivo La Coruna. The Spanish press reported that the midfielder would be in London this week to conclude a deal.

fields.headline: EM.TV shares slump
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Shares in the German media firm, EM.TV & Merchandising, dropped by more than 20% this morning, Jason Deans writes.
fields.body:
Shares in the German media firm, EM.TV & Merchandising, which bought Jim Henson earlier this year, dropped by more than 20% this morning. This follows a revision of the outfit's trading figures for the first half of 2000.

The changes to EM.TV's first half results, which were originally released in late August, were in part a result of the company not being able to include Henson's DM31.6m (£9.6m) sales and DM6.3m (£1.9m) earnings before interest and tax. The Henson figures will now be included in EM.TV's trading results for the second half of 2000.

In addition, sales for the Formula One company, SLEC - in which EM.TV acquired a 50% stake in May - for the first four months of 2000 have also been taken out of the firm's first half results.

fields.headline: Sportsworld Media doubles profits
fields.standfirst: Booming Sportsworld plans further acquisitions
fields.trailText: 12pm: Sportsworld Media, the sports TV production and sponsorship group, has doubled its profits on the back of an acquisition spree, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Sportsworld Media, the sports TV production and sponsorship group, has doubled its profits on the back of an acquisition spree.

The group said preliminary pre-tax profits for the year were £2.7m, against £1.3m last year, on turnover of £20.7m, up from £5.5m.

Sportsworld bought Australia Media Holdings for £22.4m in December, giving it a foothold in the Asia Pacific market, followed by the £54m purchase of Sports & Outdoor Media International in March. SOMI sells advertising rights in stadiums in Australia and the UK.

Asia Pacific remains the UK-based group's strongest market, contributing over 50% of revenue, with Europe next on 35%. Sportsworld's priority over the coming year is boosting its presence in north America, which provides only 10% of turnover.

Geoff Brown, Sportsworld's chief executive, said: "The current year has started strongly, as the group establishes itself as a major international sports media business. Recent customer and market feedback indicates a positive environment on all fronts, and the momentum in the market shows no sign of slowing down."

fields.headline: Booming Sportsworld plans further acquisitions
fields.standfirst:
Sportsworld has announced preliminary pre-tax profits for the year of £2.7m, against £1.3m last year. Dan Milmo asks chief executive Geoff Brown what the secret is.

Sportsworld Media doubles profits
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Sportsworld Media is enjoying the never-ending boom in sports broadcasting. Dan Milmo speaks to chief executive Geoff Brown.
fields.body:
Sportsworld Media is enjoying the never-ending boom in sports broadcasting. It has interests in sports TV production, sponsorship and events marketing and this year boosted its size through a series of acquisitions.

Chief executive Geoff Brown spoke to MediaGuardian on the day Sportsworld announced preliminary pre-tax profits for the year of £2.7m, against £1.3m last year. Turnover soared by £15m to £20.7m, on the back of some canny acquisitions in the Asia Pacific.

MediaGuardian's Dan Milmo: "What were the key factors behind today's results?"

Mr Brown: "It's down to a combination of strong organic growth and acquisitions. Our purchases have bedded down more quickly than we expected. Australia Media Holdings and Sports & Outdoor Media International have performed well. We have integrated them quickly and they have settled into the group."

DM: "Given that the acquisitions have done so well for the company so far, do you plan more next year?"

GB: "It's an extremely fragmented market, and a big one. There are a lot of acquisitions that have come to us, and we are reviewing them now. We have identified the right criteria for a good purchase. We expect to be making more acquisitions during the course of the year, as we are so good at knitting in these companies and bedding them down."

DM: "With turnover up nearly 75%, are you not setting yourself impossible targets for next year's results?"

GB: "We clearly don't want to overstate ourselves, but analysts have projected our earnings for the next year, and we are very comfortable with them."

DM: "How well-placed are you in the sports broadcast market?"

GB: "There is a very significant shift in the marketing and spending of advertisers, which are moving into sports events sponsorship. Thirty-second TV commercials are a thing of the past. And the sea-change is just beginning. Fosters and Toyota are just some of the companies we are in discussions with. We provide the solution to their sponsorship needs."

DM: "What about TV production?"

GB: "Our business is now strong in terrestrial, cable and satellite, and we have programming that will satisfy any viewer in any environment. We really do describe ourselves as a unique global company."

webTitle: In brief: Blair snitch gives thumbs down to sequel

fields.headline: Blair snitch gives thumbs down to sequel
fields.trailText: Plus: Moulin Rouge opening delayed, Meg opts for Deep Throat career switch and Rupert Everett fave to play Prince of Wales as tree-hugging rasta
fields.body:
 Ain't It Cool News boasts what seems to be the first review of Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2. Although the sneak previewer concedes: "It was a print literally fresh out of the lab, with final colour timing not complete, nor credits on the end-reel yet," he felt this was no excuse for what he slated as a crushingly bad movie. "The script is so incompetent that every plot element and hint are glaring and we spotted them coming a mile off," he goes on to say. And the million-dollar question: "Was the film scary? No. Because you need to care about the characters and what might happen to them. Since these aren't believable characters, the film plops down dead like a damp squib about 20 minutes in and proceeds to stay there for the rest of the 90 minutes, oozing into a rather messy puddle and starting to smell increasingly bad."

 Baz Luhrmann's new film Moulin Rouge, starring Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor, is still in trouble despite the last-minute addition of diminutive pop princess Kylie Minogue. The tale of a young poet and a sultry courtesan in Paris in 1899 was slated for a Christmas release, but producers now say the movie won't be ready till March 2001. Producer Martin Brown said: "We wanted to make Christmas and the studio wanted to make Christmas, but it's a very complicated project and we don't want to rush it. It's an open issue at the moment. We will deliver the film when we've got it right."

 In one of the most radical changes of images we've seen in a long time, Meg Ryan is set to play porn star Linda Lovelace in a movie about the Deep Throat star's tangled love life. The tousle-haired actress has carved a niche for herself playing the nice girl in roles such as Sleepless in Seattle, You've Got Mail and French Kiss. But since her split from husband Dennis Quaid and her dangerous liaison with Gladiator star Russell Crowe, maybe it's time for the wholesome star to get explore a different side of her personality. Producer Brian Grazer said: "I want to really trash up a really wholesome girl."

 Rupert Everett is favourite to play Prince Charles as a Rastafarian tree-hugger in a big screen version of hit novel The Queen and I. The satire on Britain's Royal family, written by Adrian Mole author Sue Townsend in 1993, was on the verge of being filmed in 1997, but was abandoned following the untimely death of Diana, Princess of Wales. A studio spokesman said this week: "We now feel that enough time has passed for the project to proceed. fields.headline: You Bet Your Life - week eight, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Gambling expert Patrick Murray offers his analysis of week eight
fields.trailText:
Current standings (from initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £120.98;
Sean Ingle £101.77
Football Unlimited Punters Collective = £73.15;
Paul MacInnes = £70
fields.body:
Current standings (from initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £120.98;
Sean Ingle £101.77
Football Unlimited Punters Collective = £73.15;
Paul MacInnes = £70

Scott Murray
England v Germany: Correct score 0-0 £5 @ 5/1

Mr Murray, after all I've taught you, you go and make a fundamental error like this. If you think there are going to be no goals you must back no goalscorer; it's the same price and you get own goals for free.

Apart from that I can't argue with the thinking behind the bet. "Two low-quality sides both petrified of defeat" just about sums it up and it could so easily have been 0-0. So bad luck Scott, but please back no goalscorer next time.

Paul MacInnes
England v Germany: Half-Time/Full-Time - England/Draw £5 @ 14/1

If you're picking 14/1 shots you don't need many winners over the season to make a profit and there are certainly worse 14/1 shots than this. This is not a bet that would have occurred to me but that in a way is its charm; its very obscurity makes it so much more likely to be value.

The vast majority of bets on the half-time/full-time market are placed on one team to be winning both at half-time and at full-time and as such this is where the bookies put most of their profit margin. It is in the less popular selections that the value is to be found. I have written before about the wisdom of backing draw/favourite in a match where there is a long odds-on shot, but without a bit of research I couldn't really say whether favourite/draw in a fairly even game has any mileage in it.

As I write this I can hear the words of Mr Ingle ringing in my ears accusing me of spending my "whole life checking probability tables". I'm not here to tell you how to watch football, I'm here to help you use the knowledge you have gained from watching football to make a bit of money. Mr MacInnes, at least, seems to be listening and if he perseveres with his search for value a profitable season is still well within his reach.

Sean Ingle
Millwall to beat Luton @ 6/5; Walsall to beat Colchester @ 11/10; Finland to beat Greece @ 4/1; Rep of Ireland to draw with Portugal @ 5/2: 4 x £1 trebles and 1x50p accumulator

He's only gone and done it again. Week after week I stress the wrong-headedness of multiples and week after week Mr I seems not only to choose a multiple but to choose a winning multiple. He's making a fool out of me. But I've checked the probability tables and it seems that this run of luck cannot go on indefinitely and unless he wises up and sees the error of his ways the poorhouse beckons.

But why change a winning formula? Mr I has the bookies on the run, everything he touches turns to gold. With the £12 he won this week he's actually into profit, for heaven's sake. Clearly he must be doing something right. If only I could work out what it is.

He seems a fair judge of a football game, which will certainly help to minimise the losses in the long run, but if he would only harness this power the world could be his lobster. But I know I'm wasting my breath, I've said it a thousand times and still he persists. And still he wins. Cue much gnashing of teeth.

The Football Unlimited punters collective: Hugh MacEvilly, working in supply chain for Johnson and Johnson
Finland to beat Greece: £5 @ 4/1

At last a punter after my own heart. None of these over-ambitious multiples for Mr MacEvilly, just a straightforward, oppose a bad favourite, support an underrated outsider, bet.

I'm not entirely convinced by the wager itself - the Finns have some good players but they also have several pretty poor ones (so 3-0 to Finland on Wednesday then) plus home advantage can count for a lot in international football - but nevertheless I applaud the spirit in which it was struck.

The great god 'value' was paid due reverence and the 1-0 Greek victory does not mean that 4/1 was a bad price. If the game were played five times Finland might well sneak at least one win. The important thing in punting is to have the patience to keep plugging away at the 4/1 shots and such like knowing that if you keep taking the value in the long run it will pay off.

But conversely, dear punter, if you persistently take under the odds then in the long run you will lose. Just ponder on that as you prepare to have your next bet. Happy punting.

webTitle: Billy Elliot tops UK, while comic De Niro pleases US

fields.headline: Billy Elliot tops UK, while comic De Niro pleases US
fields.trailText: Billy Elliot beat Nutty Professor II to the top spot, while Robert De Niro's turn as a tetchy dad in betrothal farce Meet the Parents claimed the laurels in the US over the weekend
fields.body:
After last week's £1.5m opening, Billy Elliot has moved to the top of the UK box office, ahead of Eddie Murphy's Nutty Professor II: The Klumps. The picture is a triumph for Working Title and its low-budget unit WT2, Tiger Aspect Pictures, BBC Films, Universal and its new speciality arm Universal Focus, France's StudioCanal, and the UK's maligned lottery funding system.

There haven't been so many firsts and breakthroughs bound up in a single British picture since Four Weddings lit the way out of the British film industry's early 90s gloom, virtually inventing Working Title, Polygram Filmed Entertainment, FilmFour, producer Duncan Kenworthy, screenwriter Richard Curtis and actor Hugh Grant in the process.

Meanwhile, X-Men has passed the $100m mark overseas - the special effects-laden blockbuster has now hauled in $104m worldwide.

Over in the US, funny guy Robert De Niro helped to give the box-office one of its best weekends for many weeks. De Niro is currently starring in the betrothal comedy Meet the Parents, a farce about a jittery prospective son-in-law (Ben Stiller) and his girlfriend's hard-nosed, overprotective father (De Niro). Meet the Parents debuted as the weekend's top film, taking $29.1m, according to studio estimates last night.

At almost $30m, this represents a record weekend for a US October opening, beating the $17.2m taken in by Antz two years ago. This was also a personal best for both De Niro and Stiller. Denzel Washington's football-coaching flick Remember the Titans, last weekend's top film, held solidly at second place. The Sylvester Stallone remake of Get Carter, opened in the third spot.

webTitle: IPC lines up new men's magazine

fields.headline: IPC lines up new men's magazine
fields.trailText: 12pm: IPC is understood to be working on the launch of a new men's lifestyle and music magazine, codenamed Project Oak, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
IPC is understood to be working on the launch of a new men's lifestyle and music magazine, codenamed Project Oak.

The magazine, which is understood to have reached dummy stage, will come under the remit of IPC Music & Sport's new managing director, Mike Soutar, who was recently brought in to spearhead new developments.

Neither IPC Media nor Mr Soutar would comment on developments. A spokeswoman for the publisher would only say that at any one time the company had several projects under development.

But one source told MediaGuardian that IPC had been commissioning design dummies for the project, based on "well-dressed men on retro album covers".

Mr Soutar, a former FHM editor who recently launch-edited Maxim US, was brought in with former Maxim UK publisher Eric Fuller to "aggressively develop" IPC's men's titles, including Loaded, Loaded Fashion and Later.

Loaded, once hailed as a publishing phenomenon, saw its sales fall by more than 30,000 in the last ABCs, and is still without an editor.

webTitle: EU lifts economic sanctions against Serbia

fields.headline: EU lifts economic sanctions against Serbia
fields.trailText: The European Union is to lift economic sanctions against Yugoslavia, EU foreign ministers decided today.
fields.body:
The European Union is to lift economic sanctions against Yugoslavia, EU foreign ministers decided today.

The decision was made at an EU meeting in Luxembourg following the appointment of Yugoslavia's new president, Vojislav Kostunica,

It comes in the wake of a call by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, for the EU to grant a "swift, generous and welcoming; response to the dramatic change of leadership in Belgrade".

It spells the end to the EU's oil embargo and a ban on commercial flights to and from Serbia. But two other sanctions will remain in place, at least in the short term. Assets held abroad by people linked to the Milosevic regime will remain frozen. These individuals will also remain unable to obtain EU visas.

The arms embargo against Yugoslavia will also stay in place, since it is a United Nations measure and can only be rescinded by the UN security council.

The meeting in Luxembourg signalled the first steps in trying the former Yugoslavian president Slobodan Milosevic, an indicted war criminal. His extradition would require the cooperation of the new leadership in Belgrade. Before today's meeting, the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, said that bringing Mr Milosevic to the Yugoslav war crimes tribunal in the Hague was "not a top priority". The EU ministers heard a report from Bernard Kouchner, the chief UN administrator for Kosovo, who said the appointment of a new Yugoslav president does not imply an end to the rivalry between Serbs and ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

"Kosovo remains a society in crisis," Mr Kouchner said. Ethnic Albanians, who comprise the overwhelming majority of Kosovo's population, did not fight against Mr Milosevic, "but against Serb repression," Mr Kouchner told the ministers.

webTitle: Railtrack faces further fines after rise in delays

fields.headline: Railtrack faces further fines after rise in delays
fields.trailText: Railtrack may face a multi-million pound fine after revealing today that it is not meeting its own targets to cut train delays.
fields.body:
Railtrack may face a multi-million pound fine after revealing today that it is not meeting its own targets to cut train delays.

The figures, which were supposed to put the company on the way to a 7.8% reduction in late and cancelled services over the 12 months until April 2001, actually show that delays increased by 10% for the period from April to September.

Railtrack has already been fined £10m by Rail Regulator Tom Winsor for failing to meet its delay-reduction target for 1999-2000 and by the end of this month Mr Winsor will announce whether he intends to impose any further financial penalties on the company.

The fine could be as much as £35 million unless Railtrack can improve its record in the second half of this financial year. The company today blamed the wrong kind of weather - in the form of heavy rain - for the increase. Track circuit failures were the largest cause of delays, with Railtrack attributing this to the wettest April since records began, the wettest May in 17 years and the wettest September in 19 years. Fatalities on the line and people trespassing increased by 30%, hold-ups caused by security alerts by 120% and delays caused by "bridge bashes" rose by 16%. But Railtrack also saw a 30% reduction in the number of trains passing signals at danger - blamed for last year's Paddington rail crash. And delays because of broken rails were down by 32%.

Railtrack chief executive Gerald Corbett said: "The first half of the financial year saw record levels of investment, with an increase to 36% to £1.2 billion. This is more than Railtrack invested in the whole of 1996-97.

"We apologise for the inconvenience delays cause to travellers. However, our investment programme is vital to the long term health of the railway, and passengers will ultimately benefit from the work."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's "tactically inept" transfer talk falls a bit short, sad to say
fields.trailText: Unsurprisingly, the vacant England job is top of the agenda for most of the papers. The Sun claims Arsenal are prepared to give the FA permission to speak to Arsene Wenger, but Gunners chairman Peter Hill-Wood is sure his French coach will turn down any offer. "He wouldn't say yes to the job. He would be crazy to take it. And Arsene Wenger is not crazy - he is far too sensible." Alright, alright, we get your point.
fields.body:
Unsurprisingly, the vacant England job is top of the agenda for most of the papers. The Sun claims Arsenal are prepared to give the FA permission to speak to Arsene Wenger, but Gunners chairman Peter Hill-Wood is sure his French coach will turn down any offer. "He wouldn't say yes to the job. He would be crazy to take it. And Arsene Wenger is not crazy - he is far too sensible." Alright, alright, we get your point.

Bobby Robson would take the job if he was offered it, though. "If I received a call from someone at Lancaster Gate in the next few days, I would answer it," the 67-year-old former England manager says.

Robson's phone is unlikely to ring, though, according to the Daily Mail. Aime Jacquet, the man who led France to the 1998 World Cup, is the result of an FA search which mysteriously began "a month ago". Jacquet was by all accounts prepared to move to London for the Chelsea job, and this has given the FA encouragement.

The paper of choice for middle Englanders with nothing better to do than moan about how expensive it is to take their 4x4 down the local shops also claims that Rangers boss Dick Advocaat could be a "surprise" choice.

Other names mentioned in various journals include Alex Ferguson, Leicester boss Peter Taylor, Premiership success stories John Gregory and Bryan Robson, Celtic manager Martin O'Neill, Uncle Tom Cobleigh and - surprise! - Terry Venables.

But enough. Rumours will now turn its attention to domestic matters.

Spanish sports daily Marca reports that Deportivo La Coruna midfielder Slavisa Jokanovic will complete a move to Chelsea today. "The club wants to sell me and I agree with the conditions they are offering," the 32-year-old Yugoslavian announced.

Barcelona midfielder Jari Litmanen fancies a move to the Premiership. "I have heard that certain clubs are interested," announced the lifelong Liverpool supporter. How much the injury-prone Finn would enjoy the hurly-burly of the English game is another question - read Simon Kuper's article on the former Ajax player.

Leeds will not pay £60,000 a week to employ Steve McManaman, according to chairman Peter Ridsdale, who has branded a weekend report "a complete kite-flyer". Ridsdale also denied plans to sell Michael Bridges to Newcastle. "He's only been on the bench for two matches, everyone says it's important that we build up a strong squad and as far as I am concerned Michael is a highly valuable member of that squad so he is going nowhere," he told Teamtalk.

John Gregory wants to take Liverpool defender Steve Staunton back to Aston Villa. Teamtalk also suggests Sheffield Wednesday striker Gilles de Bilde could be turning up at Doug Ellis Towers on loan.

Manchester United have taken 22-year-old Danish goalkeeping prospect Jesper Christiansen on trial.

fields.headline: Ananova abandons ad pitch
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Ananova has called off the advertising pitch for its online news and information service, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Ananova has called off the advertising pitch for its online news and information service.

The brand is now not expected to receive any separate advertising support following its buyout by telecommunications giant Orange.

Several agencies pitched for the account but no appointment will be made. Sources say it is unlikely that there will be any separate launch of the site. If advertising or marketing does becomes necessary this will fall to Lowe Lintas & Partners, the incumbent agency on the Orange account.

Ananova provides packages of news, sports, event listings and other information for websites and interactive services.

fields.headline: Who's in charge here?
fields.standfirst: The Peugeot 607 is perfect for all you corporate hotshots, says  Giles Smith . But it does like to make its own executive decisions
fields.trailText: The Peugeot 607 is perfect for all you corporate hotshots, says Giles Smith. But it does like to make its own executive decisions
fields.body:
The new Peugeot 607 is a big lump of French luxury. Smooth, silent, unnecessarily long and stuffed to the roof with toys, it wants to be up there rubbing suited shoulders with the big boys - the top flight Audis and BMWs. It wants you to love it like a tax perk.

In my favourite publicity photo of the car, the 607 is parked adjacent to an airfield and off in the background, beside a glamorously pointy black helicopter, the driver - in blue shirtsleeves, briefcase to hand - is offering a firm handshake of gratitude to the liveried pilot. That's the kind of person you are if you drive a 607: perpetually out on pricey business, in and out of the heliport, keys to the executive washroom on your fob.

So you leave the pilot and walk crisply towards your mercilessly polished saloon, which has really ugly headlights, but never mind. You thumb the boot-opener on your remote control, at which point it unlocks with a satisfying "punk" and the lid rises silently and ever so slowly into the air. (The general idea of labour-saving technology is to get jobs done faster. But, as everyone knows, the really cool and properly satisfying thing is to see something happen automatically but slowly. This is as true of hidden film-screens, doorways into secret passages and CD-trays as it is of car boots.)

Then you stow your case and close the lid - though it doesn't shut first time, unfortunately, because you have to learn to give it quite a good whack, which is also the case, you've noticed, with the doors when you get out. Memo to self: have a word with Dave in the Fleet Division about this? Anyway, you're inside now, in the leathery splendour of your ergonomically-precise seat. (The car has already remembered and run a check on your favoured settings. It recognised you from your remote control.) And you're ready to begin lightly poaching your executive backside with the under-seat heater.

You've checked the on-board phone for messages and programmed the satellite navigator. Incidentally, if you don't mind seeing films on a five-inch screen, you can avail yourself of the socket in the glove compartment and watch videos or DVDs. How technology creeps on. Only National Express used to offer an on-board movie service.

With the engine whispering under you, there's just time to catch your own eye in the glare-defeating rear-view mirror before signalling. Now you come to mention it, the indicator stalk feels a bit plastic-like and stiff. In fact, don't the instruments in general on this car feel - dare one say it? - a little junior manager?

And finally, you're on the road and it feels good. Not fantastically powerful, like you, but good anyway. As a top-level executive in an enormous car, your need to get things done is almost as pressing as your need to get things done for you. Peugeot understand this. The 607 wants to relieve you of driving's most onerous chores. Switching on the lights, for instance. Headlights come on automatically when the car decides there isn't enough natural light about. The hazard lights will come on automatically when you brake sharply, leaving you free to concentrate on the slightly more urgent matter of doing the braking. (A smart idea, that. There have been a number of occasions I can recall during sudden traffic build-ups on motorways when, fumbling along the dashboard for the hazard button in order to let people behind know that I am slowing down pronto, I have almost forgotten to slow down pronto.)

What's more, the windscreen wipers work automatically, as do the headlamp washers. The air conditioning automatically adjusts itself and so does the volume of the hi-fi, according to the noise of the engine. When you lock the car the wing mirrors automatically fold away. It can probably be set up to go off automatically and shop for a present for your PA.

The car is even keen to take onto its broad and manly shoulders some of the burden of reversing. There's a radar at the back that sounds to let you know when you're risking your paintwork. In a moment of executive fat-headedness, I chose to ignore the radar's judgment during a basic reverse parking manoeuvre. This was not especially clever - though, in fairness to myself, I should point out that the radar had earned some scepticism from me by beeping urgently whenever I reversed off my drive. The slope of the drive, combined with the camber of the road, meant the sensors, which are strung along the bumper, were locking on to the surface of the road and informing me that there was tarmac in the way.

Also, what would Michael Schumacher be likely to trust: potentially fallible technology or his fastidiously disciplined naked eye? During this later parking manoeuvre, which took place on level ground, the radar's beeping rapidly quickened to a continuous tone. I would not like to be forced to review video footage of my complacently smiling expression as, in the midst of this shrilling alarm, I turned to my mildly anxious passenger and said, "Ridiculous device! I've got yards." Emerging from the car, I saw that I had parked with the bumper actually resting on top of the vehicle directly behind. Still, no damage. Well, not to the 607, anyway.

As a top-level executive, you'll want to know about the deal. Unfortunately, the 607 won't be unveiled until the London Motor Show next Monday and the price, Peugeot tells me, remains a secret until then. If it comes in at under £10,000, snap one up, would be my advice. Realistically, though, you're probably going to need at least three times as much as that. Still, who cares as long as the company's paying?

The lowdown

Peugeot 607

Price: To be announced
Top speed: 132mph
Acceleration: 0-62 in 11.5 secs
Consumption: 29.7 mpg (combined)
At the wheel: The new MD
On the hi-fi: Classic FM
En route for: The M1

fields.headline: Foster defends Nazi film-maker biopic
fields.trailText: Oscar-winning director Arnold Schwartzman and Jodie Foster are at odds over Foster's plans to produce and star in a controversial project - a movie about Nazi film-maker Leni Riefenstahl
fields.body:
Oscar-winning director Arnold Schwartzman and Jodie Foster are at odds over Foster's plans to produce and star in a controversial project - a movie about Nazi film-maker Leni Riefenstahl.

Schwartzman, who won an Academy Award for his 1981 documentary Genocide about the plight of the Jews in Hitler's Europe, said last week: "A lot of people in Hollywood are horrified at this... There will be many objections. Leni Riefenstahl was probably the best propaganda tool that Hitler had and a lot of terrible things that happened were as a consequence of what she did."

Foster told the Ottawa Citizen earlier this year: "I think it will be the most challenging film of my life, but it's something I've wanted to do for a long time. There is no other woman in the 20th century who has been so adored and so vilified simultaneously."

Riefenstahl, who is now 98, is best known for her 1934 film Triumph of the Will, which opens with a shot of Hitler descending from the skies in his plane in 1934, and was one of the most famously powerful pieces of propaganda ever filmed. It was banned for years after the war for fear that it still had the potency to spark a Nazi revival.

Riefenstahl's film Olympia, about the 1936 Olympic games and a hymn to physical perfection, won the Mussolini prize, then the top award at the Venice Film Festival. She covered the Nazi invasion of Poland as a photo-journalist and is alleged to have used Gypsy concentration camp victims as extras in what was to be her last film Tiefland, which was only finally finished in 1954.

At the end of the war Riefenstahl was jailed first by the Americans and then the French and spent four years behind bars, before being eventually cleared of collaboration by a West German de-Nazification court.

She became a photo-journalist in Africa, made a famous photographic study of the Nuba tribes in Sudan and came to America to receive an award at the Telluride Film Festival in Colorado, where she was roundly booed by Holocaust survivors.

Her memoirs, published seven years ago, claimed that she had been naive and ignorant rather than a Nazi supporter, but a 1993 documentary, directed by Ray Mueller and entitled The Wonderful, Horrible Life of Leni Riefenstahl, cast doubt on those claims.

Foster however insists that too much is being made of Riefenstahl's links with Hitler, and that people are missing out on the fact she was a remarkable woman.

"She is one of the great stories of the 20th century, an extraordinary woman, sharp as a tack and as beautiful as she ever was, with a tremendous body," said Foster, in the German woman's defence.

Riefenstahl is currently collaborating on a version of her story wih a German company.

 See Sunday's profile of Jodie Foster.

fields.headline: Sympathy for the Devil
fields.trailText: A group of devil worshippers is urging its members to catch Liz Hurley's star turn in new film Bedazzled
fields.body:
A group of devil worshippers is urging its members to catch Liz Hurley's star turn in new film Bedazzled. She plays the devil, who tempts the hapless Brendan Fraser with each of the seven deadly sins.

Church of Satan chiefs reckon that Liz is the ideal choice to play Lucifer, as she will boost Satan's image by "looking so good" in a variety of sexy outfits, and she will show the "numerous benefits" they feel can be enjoyed if one becomes a satanist.

Church of Satan spokesman Peter Gilmore said, "We have very high hopes for this movie. We believe Elizabeth will help to accurately portray Satan as someone who brings pleasure not pain. We couldn't ask for anyone better than her."

Steve Jenkins, spokesman for the Church of England, dismissed their comments as a cheap publicity stunt for the film itself, and having not seen the movie, preferred not to comment any further.

Meanwhile Hurley herself has refrained from commenting on her religious leanings, but will admit that she has committed all seven of the deadly sins, and that lust is her favourite, because it did wonders for her complexion.

She says, "Lust does wonders for you and is good for the skin. All humans crave a bit of tension in the air - and lust brightens up the day.

"The only thing that got me through chemistry class in school was fancying a boy who sat in front of me. How I longed to brush past him on the way to the Bunsen burner.

Hurley confesses she also enjoys the sin of sloth: "It can be heavenly. On vacation, I always welcome physical sloth."

fields.headline: Campaign Media Business round-up
fields.trailText: October 9: Granada Enterprises is to share the ITV sales director role between the TSMS sales director, Andy Farwell, and the Granada account director, Mark Butterfield.
fields.body:
Granada Enterprises is to share the ITV sales director role between the TSMS sales director, Andy Farwell, and the Granada account director, Mark Butterfield. TSMS's group broadcast director has been appointed as operations director at the merged company.

TSMS and Granada media sales staff are being told they have to reapply for their jobs. Around 100 people are to lose their jobs.

MediaVest has clung on to Scottish Courage's prestigious £45m media account.

Western Media has won the £15m brief to launch Priceline in Europe, with a UK site planned to go live on October 16.

Virgin Radio has hired Channel 5's Mark Swift as sales director.

Manning Gottlieb Media has promoted Matt James to managing director.

Centaur is rebranding Leisure Week into Leisure and Hospitality Business from October 19.

Carlton Television has lost another member of senior staff, its regional sales director, Chris Phillips, who is going to recruitment website Jobsin.co.uk.

fields.headline: Richard Farnsworth
fields.standfirst: Oldest-ever nominee for a best actor Oscar after a lifetime as a Hollywood stuntman
fields.trailText: Gerontophiles, and those who simply like a good ornery character, were delighted when Richard Farnsworth, who has died aged 80, became the oldest best actor Oscar nominee ever for his lead role in David Lynch's The Straight Story (1999). Farnsworth, a former stuntman, had waited over 60 years for just such a part: "It feels a lot better because I'm getting up there in age and might not have a chance again."
fields.body:
Gerontophiles, and those who simply like a good ornery character, were delighted when Richard Farnsworth, who has died aged 80, became the oldest best actor Oscar nominee ever for his lead role in David Lynch's The Straight Story (1999). Farnsworth, a former stuntman, had waited over 60 years for just such a part: "It feels a lot better because I'm getting up there in age and might not have a chance again."

The Straight Story told the true and picaresque tale of Alvin Straight, a septuagenarian widower who sets out from Iowa, driving a lawn mower, on a 380-mile trip to Wisconsin to see his estranged brother, who has suffered a stroke. The film extolled slowness and age, ideas which were almost seditious in a country which worships youth, speed and the automobile.

Farnsworth, with his weathered face, scraggy beard, and his blue eyes alert if watery, perfectly portrayed the dignity, individuality and stubbornness of the man. He was Lynch's first choice for the role, but he was scheduled to have hip replacement surgery, and was using a cane when the casting call came. When he heard that the character used two canes, he delayed the surgery and took the part. He was diagnosed several years ago with cancer, which had left him partially paralysed, and he struggled with the pain while working on the film.

"He was very ill in that movie, but, phenomenally, he made it through. He didn't want the world to know he was sick," said Jewely Van Valin, who had shared his life for the last 11 years. She was in the next room of their New Mexico ranch when she heard the gun shot with which he killed himself.

Farnsworth, a third-generation Californian, spent almost 30 years working as a movie stuntman. He left school at 15 during the Depression, and worked as a stable boy at a polo barn, where many actors played in their leisure time. In 1937, two men from MGM came looking for horses, and for someone who could ride them, for The Marx Brothers' movie, A Day At The Races. Farnsworth followed this with work as a Mongolian horseman in The Adventures Of Marco Polo (1938), and stunted for years for leading Western stars, including Joel McCrea, Gary Cooper and Henry Fonda.

Farnsworth was also a good swordsman, which earned him the job of playing Kirk Douglas's double in Spartacus (1960), even though he remarked that, with his skinny legs, he looked more like "a crane in a short skirt". He then started to get bit parts, mainly in Westerns, as stage coach drivers or cowboys, but his real breakthrough came in Alan Pakula's Comes A Horseman (1978), in which he played Jane Fonda's old ranch hand Dodger, a part for which he was Oscar-nominated as best supporting actor. The character, representing the Old West, is thrown from his horse because of the sound of blasting for oil. He is brought back home, but climbs back on his horse, preferring to die outside under the stars.

Farnsworth also played a Wyoming rancher in Tom Horn (1980) with Steve McQueen, but his first leading role was in The Grey Fox (1982), the story of Bill Miner, stagecoach robber, who emerges from 33 years in prison into the 20th century. According to Roger Ebert: "Farnsworth is one of those unstudied, graceful, absolutely natural actors who has spent a lifetime acting exactly as he feels. I think he is incapable of a false or a dishonest moment. He makes Miner so proud, so vulnerable, such a noble rascal, that the whole movie becomes a little more complex."

Farnsworth represented both the Old West and the Old Hollywood. Of The Straight Story, he said: "There wasn't one four-letter word in this movie. I'll tell you I'm really disappointed in what people seem to want nowadays - action, sex, violence, four-letter words. I've turned down quite a bit of work because there's too many four-letter words." His more folksy roles (including TV series such as Bonanza and The Big Valley) didn't allow him to be much more than a loveable old coot, until Lynch made his offer.

Farnsworth, whose wife of 38 years died in 1985, is survived by their daughter Missy, and son Diamond - who is also a top stuntman.

 Richard Farnsworth, actor, born September 1 1920; died October 6 2000.

fields.headline: When the revolution came
fields.standfirst: With reporters denied visas and TV stations unable to get pictures, Thursday's revolution in Yugoslavia posed huge problems for news organisations.  Merope Mills  finds out how they coped.
fields.trailText: With reporters denied visas and TV stations unable to get pictures, Thursday's revolution in Yugoslavia posed huge problems for news organisations. Merope Mills finds out how they coped.
fields.body:
Ed Pilkington Foreign editor, the Guardian

We have Gillian Sandford as our regular stringer there. She came out of Belgrade earlier in the year and it took her about three months to get a visa. All our main correspondents were refused a visa. It's been horrendously difficult, but on Thursday Jonathan Steele got in. We've done quite a lot of updating on the wires as [reports] come in because if you're right in the middle of it, it's actually quite difficult to know everything that's going on. In some senses, we know more here than they do.

Maggie O'Kane The Guardian

The truth is that, eventually, almost all journalists who cover the Balkans don't get visas anymore. You're the odd one out if you do get one. Most of the journalists who were in there came on tourist visas because there really wasn't any other way. That makes it much harder to report because you have to be careful where you stay. You can't stay in the hotels because you could be very easily found and so you have to rely on people's goodwill - and they have to be people who are aware of what the situation was when you came in.

Stephen Robinson Foreign editor, the Telegraph

Mark Dowdney Foreign editor, the Mirror

We've always been very outspoken in our criticisms of Milosevic and, of course, they monitor the papers and they pay us back by refusing to let our staff in. We couldn't get a visa this time, but we sent Anton Antonowicz and Mike Moore to Montenegro and they went two or three days ago in the hope that we could get in through there. It's a big, big story and we're giving it a lot of attention. I think the Sun blundered by not putting it on their front page on Friday.

ITN, BBC and Sky missed everything. It was strange because if you lived in Serbia you were able to watch what was happening live via CNN because we were broadcasting via their state television, but in the UK, only if you were tuned into CNN could you see what was going on

During the Kosovo crisis our viewership in eastern Europe really seemed to take off and in reporting Belgrade on Thursday night it really showed because our phone-in programmes were flooded with people calling and faxing and emailing from Serbia and Kosovo and all around there. We were also very fortunate to get a call from a British lad who was with the demonstrators and a very good local producer who did a running commentary on everything that was hap pening. But as far as I can see, the only people who had live pictures were CNN. All credit to them.

Nigel Dacre Editor, ITV news at ITN

It's a very difficult country to get into. Hopefully that will change now. We're very experienced at being in Belgrade, though on Thursday we were relying on agency pictures and pictures from Belgrade TV. This is a massive story for us. We are putting a lot of resources into it. We've sent three teams and a satellite dish. So, for us, the coverage is working well.

Dominic Crossley-Holland Deputy editor, ITN 24-hour news

On Thursday night we chucked out the set 15-minute wheel of bulletins and went for live, extended coverage of Belgrade. The difference between us and other channels was if you tuned in to us you didn't often see boring studio shots with a presenter interviewing an expert. The BBC came off air about two or three hours before ITN with its open-ended Belgrade coverage, and by later in the evening it was running hours of William Hague.

Mark Ogle Press officer, BBC news

We started with the Belgrade correspondent Jackie Rowland there and John Simpson in Montenegro. On Thursday, John wasn't being allowed in, but in his own inimitable style he got in a car with a fixer and legged it across the border and got to Belgrade just in time to do live reports as things were unfolding. John has tended to concentrate on TV while Jackie has been doing all the radio bulletins. But I believe he and Jackie were the only terrestrial TV broadcasters who managed to get there on Thursday. I certainly think the BBC did very well. John was reporting live on the phone and reporting while he was being tear-gassed in the crowd.

We couldn't get any visas so we didn't have anyone in up until Friday. Obvi ously we've been trying for the past couple of weeks, but they weren't issuing them. We had a fixer on the ground in Belgrade who arranged phone interviews for us, including the only broadcast interview with Kostunica. We've been monitoring and using Serb TV, CNN pictures and agency pictures. But by Thursday we just weren't able to get our journalists in.
