webTitle: Henry VIII 'all written by the bard'

fields.headline: Henry VIII 'all written by the bard'
fields.trailText: A team of software engineers claim to have solved one of the enduring mysteries of English literary history: who exactly wrote William Shakespeare's last play Henry VIII?
fields.body:
A team of software engineers claim to have solved one of the enduring mysteries of English literary history: who exactly wrote William Shakespeare's last play Henry VIII?

For many years it has been assumed that the play, first performed in 1611, was a collaboration between the bard and John Fletcher, the rising star of the King's Men players for whom Shakespeare was reaching the end of his career.

The Oxford Dictionary of Quotations even goes as far as crediting the play to both men.

Following the research by SER Systems, however, academic opinion may need to be revised. Using a piece of software designed to help companies better to manage their documentation, the researchers have declared that it is likely Shakespeare wrote the play alone.

Plays by Shakespeare, including Macbeth, Richard III and The Merchant of Venice, were fed into the software, an intelligent search engine that uses neural algorithms to mimic the workings of the human brain.

These were then compared with works by Shakespeare's contemporaries, including Fletcher, Christopher Marlowe, Ben Jonson, Thomas Dekker and John Webster, with the software concluding that it was 88% likely that Shakespeare was the play's sole scribe.

The software, called SERbrainware, compares words and syntax, and "learns" to make connections between them.

But while SER said the technology could be applied to other disputed Shakespearean texts, including The Two Noble Kinsmen, others where less sure of the value of automated textual analysis.

Stanley Wells, chairman of the Shakespeare Society and general editor of the Oxford edition of Shakespeare, was sceptical. "I would find it very hard to believe Shakespeare worked alone on this play. This theory of collaboration has been around for well over 150 years. There is material evidence of Fletcher's hand. Fletcher was known for using 'em' instead of 'them' and this is one of the things generally taken to be evidence of his having a role in the writing of Henry VIII.

"It is hard to judge without knowing the exact criteria on which the machine calculated, but it would seem to be entirely dependent on what you asked it to do. The computer is only a tool, it cannot work without people. Computers can't think."

Sir Frank Kermode, author of Shakespeare's English and former professor of English at Cambridge University, was equally dubious. "These sorts of comparisons have been done repeatedly for over 100 years, and the basic understanding is that Shakespeare and Fletcher worked together on the play. It was quite normal to collaborate back then, quite plausible that Fletcher worked with the old hand who was fading out."

He added: "I heard Ralph Richardson's son reading from the play last week, and he said afterwards it was such rubbish that it couldn't possibly be by Shakespeare."

 The doubters' arguments against Shakespeare Stephen Moss

The more that is written about Shakespeare, the less we seem to know. The Bard is second only to Jesus as a subject for writers, yet thus far we have failed to establish whether he was Catholic or Protestant, gay or straight, and precisely what he looked like.

The tradition of doubting whether Shakespeare wrote Shakespeare dates back at least 200 years, but it was first given concrete form in 1857, in Delia Bacon's The Philosophy Of The Plays Of Shakespeare Unfolded.

Bacon argued that Shakespeare was far too ignorant and low-born to have been able to write about court life, Europe and classical literature, and ascribed the work to Francis Bacon (no relation).

Her doubts were sufficient to convince Henry James, who wrote: "I am haunted by the conviction that the divine William is the biggest and most successful fraud ever practised on a patient world."

The Baconians, who portrayed Shakespeare as an obscure impresario who staged the master's work, had the field to themselves until 1918, when J Thomas Looney, on the most circumstantial evidence, suggested Edward de Vere, the 17th Earl of Oxford, as the true author. Sigmund Freud was an influential convert to the cause.

Many other possible authors have been mooted, including Christopher Marlowe (Marlovians argue that their hero faked his death in a Deptford tavern in 1593 and then took up ghost writing), John Fletcher (who did collaborate with Shakespeare on his later plays), the earls of Derby, Rutland and Southampton, Walter Raleigh, Elizabeth I and Anne Hathaway.

fields.headline: High Tories
fields.standfirst:
Widdecombe comes down with a bump
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: As if determined to demonstrate that anything Labour does, they can do better, the Conservatives have managed to stage both a fine old feud and a vintage fiasco. The two may have been connected.
fields.body:
As if determined to demonstrate that anything Labour does, they can do better, the Conservatives have managed to stage both a fine old feud and a vintage fiasco. The two may have been connected. Who exactly was the "senior party aide" who whispered into the Mail on Sunday's ears that it might be worth asking shadow cabinet members if they had ever smoked dope when younger? Could it be that this person belonged to the Portillo/inclusivist wing of the party, now locked in battle with the fundamentalist forces of the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe? If so, the mischief-maker struck gold. Seven members of William Hague's shadow cabinet (or six and a half, if you accept Oliver Letwin's defence that he did so by accident) pleaded guilty as charged, thus knocking a sizeable hole in Ms Widdecombe's case for on-the-spot fines for anyone caught in possession of cannabis - and also in her reputation.

Ms Widdecombe has two defences to offer. Of course she did not set out to target people like Messrs Maude, Willetts, Norman and Ainsworth, and Lord Strathclyde, who dabbled at university, or Bernard Jenkin, who abstained at university but succumbed while working for Ford. She is after bad people who deal in drugs in big cities. And of course she cleared her initiative both with Mr Hague and Mr Portillo. But the way she put it across is her responsibility. And the message which stuck at Bournemouth was that the threat was inclusive: that anyone, tomorrow's Tory frontbenchers by no means excluded, who messed with this stuff in future stood to pay a penalty. And that could catch a vast swathe of potential Conservative voters.

That ought to serve as a necessary lesson, both for her and even more for her adulators in the party, where surveys suggest she outscores Mr Portillo as a possible Conservative leader. Ann Widdecombe is a natural, a character, a card, a woman utterly unreinventable by spin doctors or image consultants. That is why many people like and admire her. But she is also a headstrong bigot. With a doomed opposition these things may pass by unregarded. With a party aspiring to government, people begin to notice. The roll-your-own deflation of her previous reputation which this incident looks to have engineered is both overdue and deserved. And that is not, by the way, to be read as an endorsement of Michael Portillo.

fields.headline: A destructive deadline
fields.standfirst:
Israel's ultimatum is self-defeating
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: This is a time for restraint, not for more, murderous mayhem. This is a time for leadership, not for submission to the blinding anger of the streets. Restraint and leadership were lacking in the immediate aftermath of Ariel Sharon's offensive visit to Haram al-Sharif. Palestinian civilians reacted with violent rage, the Israeli army with excessive force.
fields.body:
This is a time for restraint, not for more, murderous mayhem. This is a time for leadership, not for submission to the blinding anger of the streets. Restraint and leadership were lacking in the immediate aftermath of Ariel Sharon's offensive visit to Haram al-Sharif. Palestinian civilians reacted with violent rage, the Israeli army with excessive force. Their political leaders, Yasser Arafat and Ehud Barak, failing to take firm charge, opted instead to blame each other, the one rejecting a US-mediated ceasefire, the other ruling out an international inquiry into his government's actions.

Restraint and leadership are lacking now as Mr Barak threatens to wage war in the West Bank in defence of Jewish settlements and in Lebanon. The weekend clashes with Hizbullah, the renewed air raids and border bombardments, are an appalling backward step. Israel's Lebanon withdrawal last May, Mr Barak's only tangible achievement, is now in jeopardy. In turn, Mr Arafat, part ambivalent, part impotent in the face of his people's fury, undermines by his weakness the peace process to which he has pledged Palestine's future.

Exploiting the moment, hostile outsiders like Iraq and Iran tilt at US regional "hegemony" and call for a "holy war". For their own ends, they urge the Palestinians to throw their bodies upon Israel's bayonets in a vicarious conflict they themselves are too smart to fight. Throughout the Arab world, in Israel itself, and among Israel's Arab citizens, the mood hardens. It is, after all, so much easier to vent hatred and prejudice, to throw stones and fire bullets, than to seek compromise and conciliation. But this is what happens when leadership fails and restraint is cast aside.

Mr Barak claims that Israel's army has shown remarkable self-control in recent days. But his attempt to portray his country as victim will be rendered all the less credible should he take the offensive. He clearly wants to jolt the Palestinians into a cessation of violence. But his ultimatum, expiring tonight, is plainly self-defeating. Israel's prime minister should be in absolutely no doubt that a solemn declaration by him that the peace process is dead will sound the death knell of his own legitimacy. Mr Barak was elected last year on a peace platform. He has faced immense internal political difficulties. He was unlucky, in that the death of Syria's Hafez al-Assad paralysed negotiations with Damascus. To his credit, he went further than any Israeli leader before him in trying to cut a deal with Mr Arafat at Camp David last July. True to his word, he has fought for the "peace of the brave". But for him to abandon that struggle now would be to admit the bankruptcy of his whole policy.

If the peace process really is allowed to collapse, Mr Arafat, too, may have good cause to consider his position. Enjoying an iconic status, he has been the face of the Palestinian struggle for so long that it is difficult to imagine him gone. But what, in the event of a descent into an even greater chaos and yet more futile bloodshed in the West Bank and beyond, will he have left to offer? Many may feel, if that point is reached, that it is time for the standard to change hands.

For these reasons, as well as the intense interest of Bill Clinton in avoiding a Middle East implosion on the eve of the US election, the desperate attempts under way last night to head off an irreparable breach, possibly through an emergency summit tomorrow, may bear fruit. It is earnestly to be hoped that they do. If not, the events of the past 10 days will look like minor disturbances by comparison with what may swiftly follow.

Restraint and leadership were lacking in the immediate aftermath of Ariel Sharon's offensive visit to Haram al-Sharif. Palestinian civilians reacted with violent rage, the Israeli army with excessive force. Their political leaders, Yasser Arafat and Ehud Barak, failing to take firm charge, opted instead to blame each other, the one rejecting a US-mediated ceasefire, the other ruling out an international inquiry into his government's actions. Restraint and leadership are lacking now as Mr Barak threatens to wage war in the West Bank in defence of Jewish settlements and in Lebanon. The weekend clashes with Hizbullah, the renewed air raids and border bombardments, are an appalling backward step. Israel's Lebanon withdrawal last May, Mr Barak's only tangible achievement, is now in jeopardy. In turn, Mr Arafat, part ambivalent, part impotent in the face of his people's fury, undermines by his weakness the peace process to which he has pledged Palestine's future. Exploiting the moment, hostile outsiders like Iraq and Iran tilt at US regional "hegemony" and call for a "holy war". For their own ends, they urge the Palestinians to throw their bodies upon Israel's bayonets in a vicarious conflict they themselves are too smart to fight. Throughout the Arab world, in Israel itself, and among Israel's Arab citizens, the mood hardens. It is, after all, so much easier to vent hatred and prejudice, to throw stones and fire bullets, than to seek compromise and conciliation. But this is what happens when leadership fails and restraint is cast aside. Mr Barak claims that Israel's army has shown remarkable self-control in recent days. But his attempt to portray his country as victim will be rendered all the less credible should he take the offensive. He clearly wants to jolt the Palestinians into a cessation of violence. But his ultimatum, expiring tonight, is plainly self-defeating. Israel's prime minister should be in absolutely no doubt that a solemn declaration by him that the peace process is dead will sound the death knell of his own legitimacy. Mr Barak was elected last year on a peace platform. He has faced immense internal political difficulties. He was unlucky, in that the death of Syria's Hafez al-Assad paralysed negotiations with Damascus. To his credit, he went further than any Israeli leader before him in trying to cut a deal with Mr Arafat at Camp David last July. True to his word, he has fought for the "peace of the brave". But for him to abandon that struggle now would be to admit the bankruptcy of his whole policy. If the peace process really is allowed to collapse, Mr Arafat, too, may have good cause to consider his position. Enjoying an iconic status, he has been the face of the Palestinian struggle for so long that it is difficult to imagine him gone. But what, in the event of a descent into an even greater chaos and yet more futile bloodshed in the West Bank and beyond, will he have left to offer? Many may feel, if that point is reached, that it is time for the standard to change hands. For these reasons, as well as the intense interest of Bill Clinton in avoiding a Middle East implosion on the eve of the US election, the desperate attempts under way last night to head off an irreparable breach, possibly through an emergency summit tomorrow, may bear fruit. It is earnestly to be hoped that they do. If not, the events of the past 10 days will look like minor disturbances by comparison with what may swiftly follow.

fields.headline: Polish president heads to victory
fields.trailText: Aleksander Kwasniewski, president of Poland, was on the verge of securing a second five-year term in office as voting ended last night in the country's third popular presidential election since the fall of communism.
fields.body:
Aleksander Kwasniewski, president of Poland, was on the verge of securing a second five-year term in office as voting ended last night in the country's third popular presidential election since the fall of communism.

Mr Kwasniewski, a former communist minister of sport who has reinvented himself as a social democrat, was expected to come far ahead of the 11 other rightwing and centrist candidates. The big question was whether he would gain the necessary 50% to win outright, or if he would have to face his nearest rival in a runoff later this month.

Preliminary results are due today with official results out tomorrow.

The final opinion polls published before an electioneering ban was imposed on Friday night, showed that Mr Kwasniewski had gained between 52% and 55% of the vote. The first exit polls last night seemed to bear this out, showing him at 56%.

Pre-election opinion surveys showed president's closest rival, Andrzej Olechowski - a businessman and independent centrist candidate - as likely to get between 13% and 15% support. Last night's exit polls showed him at 18%.

Trailing far the incumbent was the legendary Solidarity leader and Nobel Peace Prize winner, Lech Walesa, who lost the presidential post to Mr Kwasniewski in a close se cond-round runoff five years ago.

Mr Walesa ran as an independent, having been isolated by the ruling Solidarity bloc some years ago, but is set to scrape no more than 1%-2%.

Mr Olechowskihas admitted to collaborating with the communist secret police, but even so is fairly popular among Poland's educated youth. Leading rightwinger Marian Krzaklewski, who formed the ruling Solidarity bloc and is widely supported by the church, was tipped to come in a poor third, with between 7% and 12%.

But the prospect of a landslide victory for Mr Kwasniewski lost its air of inevitability due to the efforts of Mr Krzaklewski who has run a campaign to discredithim.

His campaign film showed video footage from 1997 in which Mr Kwasniewski's security adviser parodied the Pope by kissing the ground after a helicopter flight. The film also showed Mr Kwasniewski apparently drunk at a memorial service in the Ukraine for the victims of Stalinist execution squads in the second world war. As a result Mr Kwasniewski's support dropped about 10 points and he has been declared persona non grata in various Polish towns and cities.

Although the presidential post is largely ceremonial it carries much moral authority and the power to veto parliamentary bills. Despite his communist past, and self-declared atheism in a predominantly Roman Catholic land, Mr Kwasniewski is viewed favourably by many Poles as a necessary moderniser who has eased the painful transition to a market economy.

He has received praise for orienting the country towards the west and is admired for the business-like way he steered Poland towards its membership of Nato last year, as well as for his enthusiasm for future EU membership.

Poland, with a population of 40m, is by far the biggest EU hopeful. But it is seen as problem in Brussels, mainly due to its 10m-strong farming community which is demanding that the EU commit itself to big financial subsidies.

The British prime minister, Tony Blair, drew praise from Polish politicians last week, after choosing Warsaw as the place to deliver a speech on the EU in which he called for 2004 to be declared as the firm entry date. Brussels has been reluctant to commit itself.

Mr Kwasniewski's political performance is being closely watched by analysts as it could signal the future domination of Poland by former communists. The Democratic Left Alliance, a party of ex-communists once led by Mr Kwasniewski, is expected to win next year's general election and form a government, either alone or in coalition.

Twenty-nine million Poles were eligible to vote yesterday, including hundreds of thousands of emigrants, mainly living in the American midwest.

webTitle: Superiors absolved priest of sex abuse

fields.headline: Superiors absolved priest of sex abuse
fields.trailText: The Roman Catholic church in France has been plunged into a bitter debate over the secrecy of the confessional after the the conviction last week of a paedophile priest who had been telling his superiors about his sexual relations with young boys for more than 25 years.
fields.body:
The Roman Catholic church in France has been plunged into a bitter debate over the secrecy of the confessional after the the conviction last week of a paedophile priest who had been telling his superiors about his sexual relations with young boys for more than 25 years.

A court in Caen, Normandy, sentenced Father René Bissey, 56, to a record 18 years in prison on Friday for the repeated rape of one boy and the sexual abuse of 10 others between 1989 and 1996.

The case sparked outrage in France when it emerged that Monsignor Pierre Pican, the Bishop of Bayeux, had done nothing to stop Father Bissey's activities after churchmen were alerted by a parent in late 1996. The case finally came to court when one of the main victims, now 26, filed a formal complaint with police.

In an unprecedented case against the church, the bishop himself now faces charges of failing to report sexual crimes.

Testifying in Father Bissey's case, he insisted that the secrecy of the confessional was paramount. Msgr Pican said the process of confession should have allowed the paedophile priest to "arrive at the truth about himself" and take the appropriate action.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Three Colours: White | The Birdcage | The Outrage
fields.body:
Three Colours: White

(Krzysztof Kieslowski, 1993)

6pm, FilmFour

The second in Kieslowski's majestic Colours trilogy is an ironically black comedy on the theme of equality, with Zbigniew Zamochowski as a Polish hairdresser doing fine in Paris, except that he's impotent with his wife, cool Julie Delpy (right). Soon he's ruined and busking on the Metro, and later, back in Warsaw, an act of revenge on his wife only makes him sadder. One minute bouffant, the next cropped down; life was hard for Kieslowski.

The Birdcage

(Mike Nichols, 1996)

10pm, FilmFour

Hollywood remake of the hugely successful 1978 French gay farce, La Cage Aux Folles, and if you overlook the stereotyping, enjoyable enough. Robin Williams is surprisingly restrained as club owner Armand, but Nathan Lane as his lover, the artiste Albert, makes up for that with a performance of breathless hysteria. Still, they're doing fine, until Armand's son comes to dinner with fiancée and prospective in-laws, Dianne Wiest and Republican senator Gene Hackman. Can they maintain a fiction of straight masculinity? Well, not really, and it's fun watching the web of deceit unravel, the discomfort felt more by reactionary Hackman than the fluttery couple.

The Outrage

(Martin Ritt, 1964)

11pm, TCM

Overwrought western version of Kurosawa's great Rashomon, that depicts a nasty crime from four viewpoints. Paul Newman plays the Mexican bandit who kidnaps fine Southern gent Laurence Harvey and his wife Claire Bloom, then kills him and rapes her. Edward G Robinson is all ears as the conman who hears the truth emerging from conflicting accounts.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Two young men have been detained in connection with the murder of a woman and a homeless man in the eastern town of Freiberg, the latest in a series of brutal attacks on the homeless in Germany this year.
fields.body:
German murder suspects held

Two young men have been detained in connection with the murder of a woman and a homeless man in the eastern town of Freiberg, the latest in a series of brutal attacks on the homeless in Germany this year.

According to police, the two, aged 17 and 18, have confessed to stabbing to death a woman of 56 last Thursday before turning their fury on a 63-year-old homeless man who saw them go home with the woman. Prosecutors said there was no evidence linking the two to far-right extremists
AP, Freiberg

Pontiff closes 2000 holy year

The Pope brought a statue of the Virgin of Fatima to St Peter's Square yesterday, scene of a 1981 attempt to kill him: the pontiff believes the virgin saved him.

Eighty cardinals and more than 1,500 bishops joined the golden-robed Pope in a solemn service marking the close of the Roman Catholic church's 2000 holy year. He visited the Fatima shrine after his recovery from the attack by a Turkish gunman attack, placing a bullet from his body in the icon's crown.
AP, Rome

Mobutu's son supports rebels

Congolese rebels fighting to oust President Laurent Kabila have won some rather unwelcome backing - from the son of the country's late dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko.

Nzanga Mobutu arrived in the Rwandan capital, Kigali, on Saturday and, in a "clear message to Kabila", said he planned to visit rebel-held towns in eastern Congo next week, according to a rebel spokesman. The rebels, however, have been reluctant to associate themselves with the family of the hated Mobutu.
AP, Kigali

Spain protests at water plan

Tens of thousands of people from Spain's northern Aragon region marched yesterday to protest against a plan to channel water from the Ebro river to other parts of the country hit by drought.

Concerns about the diversion's environmental impact and that it could drive small farmers off their lands has sparked the protests, but local officials say the region has a duty to share its water with less privileged regions.
Reuters, Madrid

webTitle: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous
fields.body:
Miriam Margolyes in The Awakening (Mike Newell, 1980)

Who?
Matronly British character actress. Margolyes normally ends up playing a nurse or a nanny, but she's also often seen as a haughty spinster in period dramas and her dulcet tones guarantee a lot of voice-over work - she voiced the original Cadbury's Caramel bunny. She had bit parts in Morons From Outer Space (1985), Little Shop Of Horrors (1986) and played Queen Victoria in Blackadder's Christmas Carol (1988). In the 90s she appeared in Martin Scorsese's The Age Of Innocence (1993) and in Baz Luhrmann's Romeo + Juliet (1996). The voice got a good airing too, as Fly the sheepdog in Babe (1995) and Babe: Pig In The City (1998), the Matchmaker in Disney's Mulan (1998), and the Glowworm in James And The Giant Peach (1996). But her finest hour was in last year's End Of Days where she got to beat up Arnold Schwarzenegger.

The role:
Doctor Kadira, who delivers the baby of an archaeologist (Charlton Heston) and his wife in an Egyptian hospital.

Best line:
When the mother first sees her baby, she weeps. Doctor Kadira tells her "All new mothers cry, Mrs Corbeck". Or is that just all new mothers whose babies are posessed by an ancient Egyptian spirit?

Cringe factor:
Low - merely a dodgy Egyptian accent.

Other wannabes:
Ian McDiarmid, who plays Doctor Richter, is the evil Emperor Palpatine in Return Of The Jedi and the Star Wars prequels.

Critical judgement:
Leonard Maltin, quite correctly, states "Archaeologist Heston enters the tomb of Egyptian Queen Kara, whose spirit enters the body of his newborn daughter. Need we continue?"

Also not starring in:
A 1979 episode of Tales Of The Unexpected. She also appeared in the gritty women's prison drama Scrubbers (1983).

The Awakening, Sci-Fi, Saturday October 14, 8pm.

fields.headline: Fat chance
fields.trailText: There are a lot of frustrated movie-makers in television drama, whose ambitions are merely intensified whenever a piece created for the small-screen - such as Stephen Daldry's ballet smash Billy Elliot - comes out as an Oscar possibility
fields.body:
There are a lot of frustrated movie-makers in television drama, whose ambitions are merely intensified whenever a piece created for the small-screen - such as Stephen Daldry's ballet smash Billy Elliot - comes out as an Oscar possibility. Given the existence of so many would-be Scorseses, it's important to prize a form of drama unique to television: the six-part serial.

There was a fashion in the 90s for describing these extended pieces as "novels for TV". The problem with this tag is that it was simply a different kind of inferiority complex - though kow-towing to printed fiction rather than to movies - but it usefully suggests the scale of characterisation and plotting which is possible.

Kay Mellor - with Band Of Gold and Playing The Field - is one of the best television novelists of the post-Potter generation and Fat Friends (Thursday, 9pm, ITV) is another of her stories of Northern women in which raunchiness is off-set by thoughtfulness.

Here the theme is body-image. Betty (Alison Steadman) is married to Douglas (Barrie Rutter), a chip-shop owner who didn't mind his wife being fat (or said he didn't). But Betty's own self-loathing leads to her to lose five-and-a-half stone at Weight Watchers and become Yorkshire Superslimmer 2000 and a candidate in the regional finals.

Like Victoria Wood (who once wrote a television play about weight-watchers), Mellor understands the funniness of club jargon. Here the dialogue plays with both the lingo of dieting - units, targets, reward points - and the idiom of fish-shops: top boxes, tatie-sacks, scraps.

One-liners are also reliably supplied: "His idea of a balanced diet is changing the toppings on his pizza." Fittingly but irritatingly in a piece about weight-watchers, the first episode is almost ruined by its sweet-tooth - a saccharine sequence in which "If You Go Away" is played - but there is enough to bring you back for further chapters.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Old Westmorland
fields.trailText: Old Westmorland
fields.body:
Traversing a sort of shelf on the soaring flank of Mallerstang Edge, hundreds of feet above the highest railway in England, is a remarkable track marked on the maps as, simply, The High Way.

This rough track, in places a limestone "pavement", crossing becks and waterfalls and snaking round pot-holes, is the route the formidable Lady Anne Clifford, one of the most powerful women in the country and the owner of at least six castles, used to travel in her carriage in the 17th century. Frequently, inspecting her properties, she had to go from Skipton Castle to Pendragon Castle. These must have been exciting journeys but uncomfortable. The other day, between the showers, we walked a couple of miles along The High Way to catch the flavour of her journeys.

About a mile north of the county boundary where the High Way dips down to the winding River Eden and the long length of Mallerstang stretches out to the distant hills, we came upon a curious structure. This was a modern "sculpture", not offensive like the monstrous windmills on Lambrigg Fell but never the less a strange erection. It consists of two slabs of dressed limestone, about nine feet high, so arranged that the space between them might be thought to resemble the winding Eden far below. I understand there are 10 of these "sculptures" by different artists, marking the length of the river - a concept that may well appeal to many people, although I prefer my hills without adornment.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Afternoon Play - A to Z | It's My Story - Trial By GM
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone should erect a statue of the woman celebrated in Lucy Catherine's Afternoon Play - A to Z (2.15pm, Radio 4). It's doubtful if one person in a million has heard of Phyllis Pearsall though her paperbacks get the riveted attention others would kill for. After tramping for 18 hours a day around 1930s London she compiled the capital's first A to Z street guide, locating 23,000 thoroughfares from Abberton Walk to Zoffany Street. When no publishing house would take it, she started her own.

fields.headline: Ewen Henderson
fields.standfirst: A sculptor in clay - 'fluxed earth' - from which he created monumental and original works
fields.trailText: Ewen Henderson, who has died aged 66, had an international reputation as a sculptor who took clay into a new expressiveness. He is represented in the Victoria & Albert Museum, but much of his work has gone abroad to the Museum of Modern Art in Tokyo, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the Australian National Gallery, Canberra.
fields.body:
Ewen Henderson, who has died aged 66, had an international reputation as a sculptor who took clay into a new expressiveness. He is represented in the Victoria & Albert Museum, but much of his work has gone abroad to the Museum of Modern Art in Tokyo, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the Australian National Gallery, Canberra.

For Henderson, "fluxed earth", as he called clay, was capable of being stretched and teased into complex new forms. His construction methods produced objects with a multiplicity of colour and textures, edges and interior spaces. His mastery of form was based on his insights as a painter, and he always stressed drawing as the key to his three-dimensional achievements. His intense, visceral vision was born out of his love of the natural world; he believed in making art that asked new questions. Henderson had a restless, outspoken personality.

He came late to art. He was born in Staffordshire, to a Scottish medical family (his father was a GP in a grim mental hospital). Ewen and his brother boarded at a grammar school, and he did his National Service in the RAF, in north Germany. After, he went to work for a Yorkshire chemical company before moving to Cardiff to run a branch specialising in timber preservation, and later said of this time: "I was guilty of making unrottable revolting houses in Newport which should have been allowed to rot very quickly."

Meanwhile an interest in classical and contemporary music was developing. He also began to read, explore museums, attend evening classes at Cardiff's art school and the annual summer art school in Barry. There he met artists Terry Frost, Kenneth Martin, and Harry Thubron, a painter who had a formative impact. These initial painting experiences were a revelation and, at 29, Henderson enrolled for the foundation course at Goldsmith's College, there first encountering clay: "I was seduced by the alchemy of change where you take a material ... and it is transmogrified into something else." In 1965, he went to Camberwell College of Art to study ceramics under Hans Coper, Lucie Rie and Colin Pearson.

Although Henderson made work on the wheel, he quickly felt limited by it and constructed his pots freely, since he felt there was an inherent dynamic in hand-building, which had more expressive potential, reflecting his romantic absorption of natural things and their extraordinary asymmetry. Henderson found such qualities in the art he admired, from the early Mediterranean, the Far East and pre-Colombian America. He was also drawn to 20th-century culture, to painters such as Braque, Lanyon and Diebenkorn. His wide interests in music and literature enriched his intellect and anarchic wit.

Over 30 years, alongside a distinguished teaching career at Camberwell, Henderson developed a complex landscape of forms, some of which populated the sculpture garden he and his wife, Kay, created in Camden Town. He worked on a variety of vessels, building them up in layers, using clay bodies into which bone china or porcelain might be laminated. The addition of stains and oxides - on tall pots as well as small tea bowls - created rich colour; when used to excess, these pigments became rough and blistered. The result was almost volcanic, redolent of the firing process and Earth's own geology. By building in texture and palette simultaneously, body and colour became one. Only American ceramic sculptor Peter Voulkos worked with energy as highly charged as Henderson's.

By the late 80s, Henderson's concerns were more sculptural, and he largely abandoned the vessel in favour of intricate open structures - often monumental - investigating his interest in intersecting volumes, spaces, edges and contours: a three-dimensional development of Cubism. These projects were paralleled by radical abstract gouaches and watercolours. His interest in early contributions to the landscape resulted in a series of monoliths based on British megalithic sites. Sculptures from this made an ambitious installation at the Economist Plaza in London in 1994 and the genesis of a touring exhibition in 1995. That year he also curated Pandora's Box at the Crafts Council, an anthology of ceramics and painting which shaped his aesthetic; in 2000 a show of his paintings opened in Portsmouth and will reach the London Institute gallery in 2001.

Despite Henderson's considerable stature - recognised by the London Institute's honorary fellowship in June - the British artistic establishment largely ignored his contribution. As his friend Sir John Drummond recently said "a typically British difficulty in categorising his work gave him less recognition than is his due".

Good humoured and impatient with the world, Ewen faced a quickly accelerating cancer with fortitude. His friends will miss his engaging personality; the art world may wake up to the loss of one of its most unorthodox and innovative sculptors. He was, as fellow ceramist Angus Suttie described him, "a national treasure".

He is survived by Kay, and his daughter, Charlotte.

fields.headline: The great shark hunt
fields.trailText: Great White Down Under | Care
fields.body:
'Of all the Earth's predators known and feared, none is more shrouded in mystery than the great white shark," said the narrator of Great White Down Under (Discovery Channel, Sun), in tones unilaterally reserved for Scary Subjects. At Narrator School, there must be a whole syllabus devoted to the tones for aspiring voiceover artistes when discussing spiders, forest fires, the possibility of robots taking over the world and "the merciless killing machines of the deep". (The deep, you'll notice, not "the sea" or "the oceans". At Narrator School, nuance is everything.)

Discovery's Shark Weekend did the usual associated with documentaries on scary subjects, and was perversely jolly for it. It scared the bejeesus out of us with footage of sharks attacking cameramen in underwater cages, and photographs of attack victims with serrated semi-circular chunks taken out of their legs. It had technicolour coral paradises invaded by shoals of viciously grinning sharks who proceeded to wolf down unsuspecting stripy fish. It even showed biologists like Barry, Hamish and - my personal favourite - Dr Rocky Strong, using modern technology to track and learn more about "these enigmatic beasts".

Yet in its aim to explain, what Discovery's shark extravaganza did more than anything else was affirm the notion that, despite scientists' efforts, we still know very little about the animal. And that ignorance was the most scary thing of all. Hence sharks got the most menace-ladened tones imaginable, more than pyromaniacal robot spiders.

But at least you know where you are with a shark. With their inkwell eyes and slaughtersome teeth, they're quite obviously not to be messed with. Humans, on the other fin, don't carry such obvious manifestations of their dangerous qualities.

"I don't bite," grinned Mr Chambers, the avuncular children's home warden in Care (BBC2, Sun). No, he did much worse than that, as his unsuspecting charge, Davey, would find out. Along with countless others at the home where he was incarcerated, Davey was used and abused by men entrusted with his welfare. In its exploration of the aftermath of child abuse, as well as its perpetration, Care was a bleak, harrowing, unmissable piece of TV, exceptionally acted and wonderfully directed. A Cathy Come Home for the millennium.

At its heart was a stunning performance from Steven Mackintosh as the grown-up Davey struggling to come to terms with his ordeal. Mackintosh moved from little boy lost, eyes almost sewn shut with tears, to raging bull, smashing and bashing those closest to him, a directionless, devastating fury fuelled by guilt, fear, self-doubt and self-loathing.

With bewildered support from Maria Pride as Pauline and Jaye Griffiths as Elaine, a campaigning journalist, Mackintosh's Davey remained trapped in a world where there are no merry Christmases, no happy birthdays, no safe places or caring authorities. From his own private hell to humiliation in the law courts, all dark wood and intimidation, the all-too- terrible reality of what actually went on in children's homes all over the country was brought into sharp relief. Corrupt silence and paisley-patterned pyjamas hid - and are still hiding - bleeding arseholes and torn souls.

And, in a sign of a most mature drama (and executive producers who know when not to interfere), Bird and Prendiville resisted a happy ending, simply because there isn't one. Of the country's 52 police forces, 42 are investigating allegations of systematic child abuse in children's homes. Evil is such an absolute word to use, but what's the alternative?

Tense, perfectly paced and compelling, Care wasn't enjoyable in the slightest, but it was testament to the continuing power of television to raise issues and invigorate debate, to challenge good people to do something so that evil doesn't prevail. Our fears whisper it but, too often, we avert our eyes. Maybe Care will do something to change that.

In the end though, Davey was all alone but for a bottle of cheap vodka and an overdose of paracetamol. All alone but for the thousands of other victims of child abuse who feel the same rage, guilt, fear and invisibility.

Of all the Earth's predators known and feared, none is more shrouded in mystery than the great white shark? If only. In case you were wondering, the goddess of justice has left the Earth.

fields.headline: Up the reformation
fields.standfirst: The Law Society is still reeling from the Kamlesh Bahl affair, and a backlog of complaints has prompted Lord Irvine to question its right to regulate the profession.  Martin Wainwright  talks to the woman charged with reshaping the troubled body
fields.trailText: The Law Society is still reeling from the Kamlesh Bahl affair, and a backlog of complaints has prompted Lord Irvine to question its right to regulate the profession.  Martin Wainwright  talks to the woman charged with reshaping the troubled body
fields.body:
Show Janet Paraskeva a poisoned chalice and her response would probably be to swig it in one go, but only after checking quietly that the antidote she took earlier was the correct one. The woman charged with making the Law Society's reform programme happen is an instinctive seeker after alarming challenges; and galvanising the solicitors' venerable but troubled body is definitely one of those.

The complaints system is a mess, the staff are recovering from the bullying traumas of former vice-president Kamlesh Bahl, and relations with the Lord Chancellor, Derry Irvine, are delicate. A judge would still uphold the two-year-old verdict of Sir Dennis Stevenson, the management guru now heading the House of Lords' peer-picking committee, who was called in to review the Law Society's workings. He concluded that the committee-heavy body just didn't work.

The profession will find itself looking down its nose at the Paraskeva part of the solution, because its new chief executive is small and quick. She is also systematic and very determined. The public's great grouse against snail-like complaints handling will be top priority. Lord Irvine meanwhile faces a nimble advocate for open, fair ("And where are all the ethnic minority, women and solicitor QCs and judges, Derry?") procedures in the mist-surrounded appointment system that has him and the society at odds.

The fact that the solicitors badly wanted Paraskeva for the new, £120,000-a-year post, and have launched her with a tribute from president Michael Napier to new "vision, determination and energy," is telling. At an early stage in the process, the Daily Mail will have been exhibit A, with its regular chipping at her support for cannabis legalisation and juxtapositions of gay and lesbian grants from the National Lottery Charities Board (NLCB, whose huge English operation she has directed from the start) and the fact that she is divorced and wears trouser suits.

But the sound of tutting from solicitors' offices has been wonderfully inaudible, not just in London (where the Evening Standard savaged Ann Widdecombe's contrasting views on drug law last week) but also in the regions. It is this part of the 175-year-old Law Society's membership that may get to meet the new chief exec first. One of her main legacies at the NLCB is a rock-solid regional structure with the HQ in Leicester rather than London.

Settling into her new Chancery Lane office, she looks forward to that but puts the need for an overall efficient system first. "The most important lesson I bring from the Charities Board is that you need to handle paperwork quickly. That, and a lot of experience in managing people who object to decisions - to NLCB grants or to the way grant applications were evaluated."

She and her colleagues - not especially radical: the NLCB chairman was an Hon and his deputy a Sir - were not going to satisfy everyone, when initial odds against getting a Lottery grant were 14-1 and there was no consensus on what constituted a "good cause". But they armed themselves with a huge preliminary consultation of 8,000 voluntary groups. "Then we set up a clear set of processes and procedures, properly looked-at, properly constituted and fair to all."

It didn't always look like that in early NLCB days, with computers emitting steam and staff working way beyond closing time, but there wasn't the bullying or rigid party line that often comes with system-freaks. Recovering from the legacy of Bahl, who had staff in tears (and may again next month, when she brings race and sex discrimination charges at an employment tribunal), the Law Society needs that less than most.

Paraskeva can be ruthless, and some well-intentioned members of NLCB voluntary committees got the bullet for straying over very strict rules about links with grant applications; but every decision came with a transparent, A-Z explanation of why it had been taken. The words "audit office" were held over staff entrusted with hundreds of millions of public money, and all Dail Mail attempts to show that refugees or ex-cons or even pigs at an urban farm (with snout-operated showers) were unworthy, were satisfyingly stuffed.

The NLCB was a new institution, however, and Paraskeva acknowledges the different challenge of an ancient body, where tensions over change have seen internal dramas, factions, and see-saws over strops with the Lord Chancellor. She will ease herself in: "The consultation process over changes is already well under way. I will be putting my tuppenceworth in, but above all listening to people at every level and maybe especially at the coal face. You need to be constantly on the lookout for someone who comes up with that bright idea you didn't have."

At 54, she wanted the job "because I've got time for one more big challenge". She also has the overt enthusiasm that only curmudgeons resent. She zoomed from a Greek-Cypriot, restaurant-owning family headed by a Greek-Cypriot father and Welsh mother, through work as a teacher and schools inspector to running the National Youth Agency, coupled with work as a JP, member of Leicester university council and trustee of the citizenship group Common Purpose. She is greatly proud of her two daughters, one a teacher and the other a potter. If there are curmudgeons in the Society, they may be softened by memos on postcards of ceramics by Paraskeva Junior.

fields.headline: Don Quixote at the disco
fields.standfirst: The errant knight adrift in the future?  Adrian Searle  is thrilled by a magical reworking of the Cervantes classic
fields.trailText: The errant knight adrift in the future? Adrian Searle is thrilled by a magical reworking of the Cervantes classic
fields.body:
Don Quixote is trapped inside a giant eyeball, suspended inside a vast zeppelin floating over Hong Kong, in the year 3016. Cervantes's errant-knight is an inadvertent time-traveller, having been transported in a time machine which also manages to dredge-up old refrigerators, inflatable sex dolls and jars of Christ's blood for the delectation of the future's decadent super-rich. Quixote is hopelessly adrift. Adrift, that is, above the stage of the Gran Teatre del Liceu in Barcelona, where the denizens of a fictive Hong Kong view him as an exotic exhibit, a monster in a freak show.

With 126 chapters, the entirety of Miguel de Cervantes's novel might have seemed but a blink of that giant eye to some of the more disgruntled members of the audience of Don Quixote en Barcelona, this new, three-act opera at the rebuilt El Liceu on Barcelona's famous Rambla. They were doubtless recalling Nabokov's remark, that Don Quixote is nothing but an encyclopedia of cruelties. The opera might well have reminded them, too, that the refurbished auditorium of the Liceu, rebuilt after the disastrous fire in 1994 which destroyed most of the building, is, with its recreated 19th-century plush and gilded tiers, itself a kind of hi-tech transport of nostalgia. Some of the audience are only happy travelling backwards in time.

Now, like the Quixote of this new opera, they've not been given the choice. As the third act unfolds, and the 2005 Barcelona International Congress on Cervantes degenerates into near riots on a wonderfully staged La Rambla, with a hurricane and tidal wave creating an onstage natural disaster, it becomes apparent that Quixote in Barcelona is essentially a metaphoric maelstrom. Some here complain that DQ is not an opera. What is it then? It is a Blade Runner world of gantries, mirrors and grubby future-industrial exteriors. It is part videodrome, part art installation. Everything about this work hits you with a rushing simultaneity of sight, sound and action.

What else might have been expected from a production conceived by La Fura dels Baus, the Catalan ensemble who, for more than 20 years, have astonished, terrified and delighted audiences with their violent, cathartic actions and performances around the world?

La Fura - who began life as the instigators of street performances in the manner of Viennese Aktionist Herman Nitsch, and who developed their spectacular and alarming rites and trials by fire, water, pitchforks and chainsaws into spectacular public events, most notably for the inauguration of the 1992 Barcelona Olympics, and for the Millennium celebrations - are by now something of an institution, albeit a wayward one. Nor is this their first foray into opera; they staged a version of Faust last year, in Salzburg, and it is a medium for which their energies and ambitions are ideally suited.

The real point here seems to be to create that most impure, unwieldy difficult thing: the opera as total art work. Its multiple messages and allusions are concealed within an implausible, complicated structure, just like the multitude of stories buried in Cervantes's digressive, picaresque novel. And for all the technology and the spectacular stagecraft, La Fura's conception is to create more than an animated machine. They know that it is absurd to parody a novel which itself is a series of parodies, but chose to do it anyhow, as though to add but one more layer of twists and turns.

I kept being reminded of other works, in other media. That eyeball, for instance, is a dead ringer for a work by Tony Ousler. The dirigible is like a Panamarenko. The rapid-fire montage of video clips set against live action, the splicing of live orchestration and recorded sound (some of which was composed via public participation, via software designed by La Fura, accessed on the internet), feels like familiar territory for the contemporary art buff, but done on a much grander scale than usual. Opera lovers, on the other hand, might see this as Don Quixote in space, or at a disco, or Don Quixote amongst the back-packers, looking for an opera.

DQ is astonishing, a ravishing multimedia assault. It has moments of great tenderness, sung moments, choreographed moments, moments on video. It is also in every sense a collaborative creative venture. Yet we never entirely lose our bearings. Alex Olle and Carles Padrissa of La Fura, librettist Justo Navarro and composer Jose Luis Turina play games with Cervantes and with the audi ence, just as Cervantes played games with his readers. The collaborators never lose sight, either, of Quixote's ultimately tragic and redemptive role.

The group also worked here with Enric Miralles (Catalan architect of the new Scottish Parliament), who designed an astonishing, multi- layered scenography, and with French artist Emmanuel Carlier, who devised the video montages and projections. Everything comes together in the production at an equal level.

Opera seems a good enough word for it. Miralles died during the development of the project earlier this year, and Don Quixote is dedicated to him.

 Finishes tomorrow. Details on: 00 349 3485 9900 or www.liceubarcelona.com

fields.headline: Of very little relief
fields.standfirst: Writ large
fields.trailText: Marcel Berlins: Writ large
fields.body:
 Last week I rued the fact that the appeal court's decision in the conjoined twins case would not be going up to the law lords for a final authoritative decision by the country's highest court. I've changed my mind, for a reason I'm not happy about. I'm now convinced (on very good evidence) that the law lords - there would probably have been seven of them - would not have reached a unanimous decision. Nothing would have been more unsatisfactory than a 4-3 or even a 5-2 split on such a sensitive and emotional issue, especially as each of their Lordships would probably have wanted to give his own - perhaps differing - reasons. Far from being clarified, the law might well have become more confused, and continuingly controversial. That's not a healthy reason for feeling relieved that the law lords won't be ruling.

 When This Life was on television a couple of years ago, the Law Society was bombarded with requests from young people wanting to become lawyers, just like the characters in the series. Their enthusiasm waned when they were told that sexual promiscuity and the ability to smoke 60 a day were not the only criteria for entering the profession. The further news that a certain modicum of legal knowledge would be required, and even the passing of a few exams, finally killed their interest. Now we have another series about young lawyers, which may re-awaken the attraction of the law as a cool career. North Square, set in Leeds, starts on Channel 4 on October 18. I've seen two episodes and enjoyed them, and I've got to admit that the barristers in this set of chambers are less adept at random sex and smoking than their London counterparts. But they do swear quite a lot, fight each other in and out of court, have babies and affairs, and suffer Machiavellian office politics. The barristers' chief clerk (played with gusto by Phil Davis) gets all the best lines and will make most viewers want to be him rather than any of the barristers. My usual warning: don't believe most of it. North Square is great fun, but meticulously accurate it ain't. Even in these enlightened times, a pupil (trainee) in her first week of work wouldn't suddenly be called on to take over a criminal trial for which her experienced head of chambers had been hired. Nor would our hero be allowed to play, at full blast and in the barristers robing room, his CD of My Father Was a Robber.

 I 'm delighted to return to a topic which once played a large part in these columns: the fate of London's only gentlemen's pissoir (or vespasian , if you prefer, after the Roman Emperor who introduced them) to be a listed structure. It is green, late Victorian, and erected against the outer wall of Lincoln's Inn. I was reminded of the convenience when leafing through an entertaining new book, The Walking Guide to Lawyers' London, by Andrew Goodman (Blackstone Press). As it happens, the pissoir is missing from the book (which is probably its only omission, so comprehensive does it seem in every other aspect). It was once a much patronised facility by some of the great judges of the last century; I have personally made satisfying use of it next to a Master of the Rolls and (on a different occasion) a Lord Chief Justice. It was closed when building works were carried out in the vicinity, but didn't re-open for business when the works were done. I will now make it my life's work to find out what has happened and to campaign for its re-opening. Such a stream of legal history ought not to be allowed to be washed away.

 In what city is the European Court of Human Rights? The question was asked last week on the veteran Radio Four programme Brain of Britain. I was genuinely shocked when none of the four competitors (all men) knew. The Hague, Luxembourg and Brussels were offered. The answer is Strasbourg. Even though that programme was recorded weeks ago, before the most recent flurry of publicity about the European Convention on Human Rights being incorporated here, it's not as if there had been silence before. In the past couple of years, the convention and the court in Strasbourg that interprets it have rarely been out of the news, at least in the broadsheet papers. Yet these four otherwise knowledgeable men had no idea. Perhaps informing people about our new human rights laws will be harder than I thought.

fields.headline: Funny peculiar
fields.standfirst: Brian Logan  meets a trio of anarcho-slapstickers who do strange things with Rich Tea biscuits
fields.trailText: Brian Logan meets a trio of anarcho-slapstickers who do strange things with Rich Tea biscuits
fields.body:
You'd be forgiven for thinking there was no method to the madness of Peepolykus. Take their show titles. Let the Donkey Go, the 1995 smash, had no donkeys in it. I Am a Coffee was, well, decaffeinated. Then 1998's Horses for Courses featured cossack dancing, but no racing nags. For their titles, says David Sant (for those who've seen the shows, he's the loudmouthed one), Peepolykus choose "whatever rolls in the mouth". About the only thing that can be guaranteed regarding their latest work, Goose Nights, is that avian appearances will be few and far between.

The oddball titles are a necessity. Whereas funding bodies and venues need details of their work months in advance, Peepolykus's anarcho-slapstick offerings are improvised from scratch in rehearsal and subject to chaotic developments on stage. The company's many fans - at home and, increasingly, abroad - wouldn't have it any other way. How else but spon taneously would Sant and Javier Marzan, in Let the Donkey Go, have thought to balance a mountain of Rich Tea biscuits on John Nicholson's jaw? Or - in I Am a Coffee - to send their co-star's head spiralling from an operating table into the audience's lap? Such golden theatrical moments almost never happened. After the split-up of Peepolykus Mark 1, a company he formed after circus school with "some Swiss people", Nicholson (the bumbling one) was set to begin a career in primary education.

He got as far as the interview, before recruiting Spaniards Sant and Marzan - previously fellow students at London's cosmopolitan Philippe Gaulier theatre school, now performers with the likes of Told By an Idiot and Trestle Theatre - for one last heave towards comic glory.

Locking themselves in a rehearsal room, the trio devised Let the Donkey Go, a lunatic collection of antics strung around the adventures of a defector from fictional Rajmanistan. Donkey rejoiced in its refusal to take anything seriously, so it's a surprise to learn that it was inspired by an article ("From the Guardian, in fact," says Nicholson) about the crew of a Russian ship who killed their stowaways rather than face a fine for bringing them ashore. Says Marzan: "We kept saying, 'Let's put something significant in here.'" According to Sant, "it was very difficult to really go 100 % for silliness". Nicholson, who cites the Marx Brothers and Laurel and Hardy as influences, says he "comes up against this time and again - 'Let's do something that has a bit more resonance.' But what we've come to realise is that the resonance that we really enjoy is to do with comedy. Our material is so ridiculous it actually gets inside people."

Like Stan and Ollie, the characters they play are united in their madcap world by friendship as well as shared stupidity. Nicholson wants audience members to think: "I feel comfortable with these people. I feel they're genuinely enjoying themselves and are involving me in their world." He wants to create the kind of the show where the audience "feels touched".

The trio's backgrounds are all theatrical, and much of Peepolykus's best work involves the mangling of dramatic convention, from a standpoint of qualified affection. "Classic plays well done can be fantastic," says Marzan, "but there's a lot of big companies doing them like cakes, really. At least our clowns, if they don't succeed, they try with more heart."

The company's attachment to the theatre rather than the stand-up scene may be why Peepolykus remain relatively unknown after five years in the business. For, while cabaret is increasingly borrowing theatre's clothes (witness Garth Marenghi's Fright Knight, a comic play in all but name), it remains tough for companies who straddle that divide to make their name. "We're too theatrical to be comedy," says Nicholson, "and, to hardline theatre people, we can't be theatre because we're just mucking around."

Goose Nights represents a change of tack. "We've always wanted to do a show that had a really meaty story," says Nicholson, "but whenever we tried, we got so stuck in the story that we couldn't muck around." The source material, Labours of Hercules, is rich in event and ripe with solemn theatrical traditions to goof. "We could have done a 10-hour show," says Sant. In the final, 90-minute version, the hero is a hapless Greek waiter and Demis Roussos has a cameo.

The three sense that for wider acclaim they'll have to crack TV. "The key in live performance," says Sant, "is that we see the audience's eyes, we see their reaction - it's easy to know what's going on. You can't do that on TV."

But you can distil its spirit. Given the chance to do so, Peepolykus could be a Morecambe and Wise in triplicate for the 21st century.

 Goose Nights opens at the Lyric Studio, Hammersmith, London W6 (020-8741 2311), tonight and runs till October 28.

fields.headline: Electric dream
fields.standfirst: First Tate Modern, now the Wapping Project: London's derelict power stations are rapidly becoming the capital's most exciting arts spaces.  Lyn Gardner reports
fields.trailText: First Tate Modern, now the Wapping Project: London's derelict power stations are rapidly becoming the capital's most exciting arts spaces. Lyn Gardner reports
fields.body:
Old buildings no longer die, they are regenerated and reborn. Out of the past comes the present, out of dereliction comes resurrection. We take our old industrial past, dust it down, clean it up and transform it into our own vision of a future where there is time to stop and stare. Where there once stood great machines there is now art. Hallelujah.

Following Tate Modern comes the Wapping Project, a new centre for the arts based in the old Wapping Hydraulic Power Station in east London. This is an area of London upon which the economy of Empire relied - our own industrial Venice, a complex network of waterways and working-class histories and homes. The Hydraulic power station shows us how London worked.

The Hydraulic power station was built in 1890, opposite the Prospect of Whitby pub, London's oldest surviving riverside inn, built in 1543 and originally known as the Devil's Tavern. The pub has the air of a rural cottage transposed to the city, and the Victorian power station, with its mellow brickwork and folly-like, creeper-clad tower even more so, as if its designers wanted to disguise the power that was housed within. And make no mistake, it was power. Coal delivered to the adjacent Shadwell Basin was used to fire six steam boilers and their pumping engines. The station provided power not just to the surrounding docks but throughout central London. It was the envy of a power-hungry world and was the model for similar stations as far afield as New York and Argentina.

The introduction of two electric turbine pumps in 1923 heralded the station's heyday. More than 33m gallons of water a week were pumped underneath the streets of London. Tower Bridge depended on hydraulic power, the revolving stages of both the London Palladium and the Coliseum were powered hydraulically, as were numerous lifts in City offices and West End department stores and the organ console at the Odeon Marble Arch.

But the arrival in mid-century of cheaper electricity spelled the end for the need for hydraulic power. Such stations began to shut down. The one at Wapping was the very last working hydraulic power station in the world when it closed its doors in 1977.

For the next 16 years the building and its contents fell into dereliction. Then on a November morning in 1993, Jules Wright, the artistic director of the Women's Playhouse Trust, on the look out for a suitable building for the Trust, was being taken on a tour of possible sites by the London Docklands Development Corporation. The LDDC then was keen to encourage arts activity in an area that was only just beginning to see signs of regeneration. Wright was tired, the buildings she had already seen were unpromising, but she agreed to the detour to Wapping. She walked through the door, took one look and said: "I am going to have this place."

She has, too, even though the lottery turned down her application for funding - up against competition from projects such as the Royal Opera House and Sadler's Wells in the first dash for lottery loot. Almost every penny of the £4m the building has cost so far she has raised herself. Wright, who moved to London from Australia in 1974, isn't entirely sorry about the lack of public funding. "I do like not having to spend my life ticking little boxes and doing what other people tell you," she says, with typical Australian forthrightness. She waves an arm expansively: "Who knows, if we had had £28m rather than £4m, we might have wrecked the place."

Wright, and her architects Shed 54 Limited, led by her husband Joshua Wright, haven't. The building is as idiosyncratic as Wright herself. And it is dense with atmosphere. The aim has been to keep as much of the existing building structure and machinery as possible, and to maintain both the atmosphere of the power station's industrial past and the archeological detail that underpins it.

Wright describes the architects' job as matching "the functional purity of the original. Their work is often quiet to the point of self-effacement. In some ways self-effacement is its point, simply reinforcing the existing forms, shapes and volumes and emphasising the industrial scale so that their work relates to the building, not to the human scale."

There is an air of architectural impermanence in stairs that do not touch the ground but appear to float and others made from untreated steel that will eventually achieve a dusting of rust. But just as the conversion of the building plays constant homage to its history and its watery past, so its contents will too.

The transformation of the boiler and filter houses, both stripped back to their 1890 form, has created exhibition and performance areas that are potentially the most exciting in London. At last the capital has a space for installation and performance that has the epic sweep of Glasgow's Tramway, and is both functional and eerily beautiful. This is a space that demands an artistic response that is bold, contemporary and radical.

The programme kicks off with WPC's commission of Jane Prophet's installation Conductor, which provides the link between the building's industrial past and its new life as a cultural centre. For Conductor, 120 lengths of fibre optic cables are suspended above the flooded floor of the former boiler house so that they are reflected to a seemingly infinite depth that is intermittently disrupted by ripples created by the action of a water pump.

It seems a long way from the founding of the WPT and its first ever production, a revival of Aphra Behn's rarely performed restoration satire The Lucky Chance, at the Royal Court in 1984. Yet just as that production was about reclaiming the dispossessed past, the work of WPT has also always been about ensuring that women have a place - and a space - right in the forefront of Britain's cultural life.

"I have never been interested in the WPT doing hole-in-the-wall work. Women artists need big opportunities," says Wright. The tide may go in and out when it comes to the profile of women in the arts, but expect plenty of ripples emanating from Wapping in the coming months.

 The Wapping Project opens on Saturday. Details: 020-7680 2080.

And make no mistake, it was power. Coal delivered to the adjacent Shadwell Basin was used to fire six steam boilers and their pumping engines. The station provided power not just to the surrounding docks but throughout central London. It was the envy of a power-hungry world and was the model for similar stations as far afield as New York and Argentina. The introduction of two electric turbine pumps in 1923 heralded the station's heyday. More than 33m gallons of water a week were pumped underneath the streets of London. Tower Bridge depended on hydraulic power, the revolving stages of both the London Palladium and the Coliseum were powered hydraulically, as were numerous lifts in City offices and West End department stores and the organ console at the Odeon Marble Arch. But the arrival in mid-century of cheaper electricity spelled the end for the need for hydraulic power. Such stations began to shut down. The one at Wapping was the very last working hydraulic power station in the world when it closed its doors in 1977. For the next 16 years the building and its contents fell into dereliction. Then on a November morning in 1993, Jules Wright, the artistic director of the Women's Playhouse Trust, on the look out for a suitable building for the Trust, was being taken on a tour of possible sites by the London Docklands Development Corporation. The LDDC then was keen to encourage arts activity in an area that was only just beginning to see signs of regeneration. Wright was tired, the buildings she had already seen were unpromising, but she agreed to the detour to Wapping. She walked through the door, took one look and said: "I am going to have this place." She has, too, even though the lottery turned down her application for funding - up against competition from projects such as the Royal Opera House and Sadler's Wells in the first dash for lottery loot. Almost every penny of the £4m the building has cost so far she has raised herself. Wright, who moved to London from Australia in 1974, isn't entirely sorry about the lack of public funding. "I do like not having to spend my life ticking little boxes and doing what other people tell you," she says, with typical Australian forthrightness. She waves an arm expansively: "Who knows, if we had had £28m rather than £4m, we might have wrecked the place." Wright, and her architects Shed 54 Limited, led by her husband Joshua Wright, haven't. The building is as idiosyncratic as Wright herself. And it is dense with atmosphere. The aim has been to keep as much of the existing building structure and machinery as possible, and to maintain both the atmosphere of the power station's industrial past and the archeological detail that underpins it. Wright describes the architects' job as matching "the functional purity of the original. Their work is often quiet to the point of self-effacement. In some ways self-effacement is its point, simply reinforcing the existing forms, shapes and volumes and emphasising the industrial scale so that their work relates to the building, not to the human scale." There is an air of architectural impermanence in stairs that do not touch the ground but appear to float and others made from untreated steel that will eventually achieve a dusting of rust. But just as the conversion of the building plays constant homage to its history and its watery past, so its contents will too. The transformation of the boiler and filter houses, both stripped back to their 1890 form, has created exhibition and performance areas that are potentially the most exciting in London. At last the capital has a space for installation and performance that has the epic sweep of Glasgow's Tramway, and is both functional and eerily beautiful. This is a space that demands an artistic response that is bold, contemporary and radical. The programme kicks off with WPC's commission of Jane Prophet's installation Conductor, which provides the link between the building's industrial past and its new life as a cultural centre. For Conductor, 120 lengths of fibre optic cables are suspended above the flooded floor of the former boiler house so that they are reflected to a seemingly infinite depth that is intermittently disrupted by ripples created by the action of a water pump. It seems a long way from the founding of the WPT and its first ever production, a revival of Aphra Behn's rarely performed restoration satire The Lucky Chance, at the Royal Court in 1984. Yet just as that production was about reclaiming the dispossessed past, the work of WPT has also always been about ensuring that women have a place - and a space - right in the forefront of Britain's cultural life. "I have never been interested in the WPT doing hole-in-the-wall work. Women artists need big opportunities," says Wright. The tide may go in and out when it comes to the profile of women in the arts, but expect plenty of ripples emanating from Wapping in the coming months.  The Wapping Project opens on Saturday. fields.headline: Rude awakening
fields.standfirst: The age of dissent
fields.trailText: Michele Hanson: The age of dissent
fields.body:
Every now and again, Olivia feels desperate for some culture, so last week we went to the opera, The Coronation of Poppea. I was looking forward to it. Something sublime and uplifting, I thought, in contrast to the usual: the dog's bowels, my mother's indigestion, the dismal news and general drudging round the house.

But no such luck. Soon Nerone was pulling his knickers on while his lover Poppea sung Monteverdi divinely, lying down. Personally, I thought this a bit of a mismatch - a nude chap struggling into his knickers to heavenly music - but hasn't opera changed? This one was busting with sex: an orgasm or two, a bum, trousers on and off, bodices ripped, straight, gay and oral sex, head up a skirt, clutching of genitals and bosoms, people singing away in any old position, a libretto the BBC would never allow and a set full of scaffolding.

Apparently this is what opera used to be: sexy, robust and amusing, with people singing "bugger" and such like out loud. Those Venetians always were a rude lot. And now so are we. "It was very sensual," said a cheery couple of elderly ladies on their way out. "Very sensual indeed."

In the end, the whole audience was cheery. So was Olivia. "The English are a passionate people," said she, thrilled. We never used to be, but now we can do anything and look at anything without flinching.

Sylvia had noticed this sea change at a theatre matinee some time ago. The audience was full of elderly grey-haired persons. From the stage, one sees a sea of cauliflowers. This was rather a steamy play, oral sex featured again rather boldly, centre stage, but the cauliflowers didn't bat an eyelid.

Perhaps they, like my mother, watch Channel 4 in the small hours and have seen everything going. Last night I wandered into my mother's room while cleaning my teeth and there were some penises masquerading as hamburgers on telly. My mother took this in her stride. She can now watch Eurotrash without blinking.

But there are some things too shocking even for her. Last week Frank appeared in EastEnders dressed only in a bow tie. My mother screamed with fright. She is still reeling, even though that bit wasn't showing. Thank heavens I missed it. I was at the opera.
